events.title: The Mystery of the Stolen Golden Apples and the Youngest Son's Vigil
detailed_summary: A king owned a garden with a tree that produced golden apples, which were counted regularly.
It was discovered that one apple went missing each night as they ripened.
The angered king ordered the gardener to have someone watch the tree all night.
The gardener's eldest son was assigned to watch first, but he fell asleep around midnight, and another apple disappeared.
The second son was then tasked with watching, but he too fell asleep at midnight, resulting in another missing apple.
The gardener's third son offered to watch. Despite initial reluctance from his father due to fear of harm, he was eventually allowed.
As midnight struck, the youngest son heard a rustling and saw a bird of pure gold flying towards the tree.
While the bird was about to take an apple, the son shot an arrow at it.
The arrow did not injure the bird, but it caused a golden feather to fall from its tail as it flew away.
The next morning, the golden feather was presented to the king and his council.
Everyone agreed the feather's value surpassed the kingdom's entire wealth.
However, the king declared that a single feather was insufficient and he must possess the entire bird.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which bore golden apples.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Everyone agreed that it was worth more than all the wealth of the kingdom: but the king said, ‘One feather is of no use to me, I must have the whole bird.’

events.text_segment: A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which bore golden apples. These apples were always counted, and about the time when they began to grow ripe it was found that every night one of them was gone. The king became very angry at this, and ordered the gardener to keep watch all night under the tree. The gardener set his eldest son to watch; but about twelve o’clock he fell asleep, and in the morning another of the apples was missing. Then the second son was ordered to watch; and at midnight he too fell asleep, and in the morning another apple was gone. Then the third son offered to keep watch; but the gardener at first would not let him, for fear some harm should come to him: however, at last he consented, and the young man laid himself under the tree to watch. As the clock struck twelve he heard a rustling noise in the air, and a bird came flying that was of pure gold; and as it was snapping at one of the apples with its beak, the gardener’s son jumped up and shot an arrow at it. But the arrow did the bird no harm; only it dropped a golden feather from its tail, and then flew away. The golden feather was brought to the king in the morning, and all the council was called together. Everyone agreed that it was worth more than all the wealth of the kingdom: but the king said, ‘One feather is of no use to me, I must have the whole bird.’

Every day the apples were counted, and every night one was missing. The king was very angry and ordered his gardener to watch the tree all night to catch the thief. The gardener's eldest son took the first watch, but he fell asleep at midnight, and when morning came, another apple was gone. Then the second son took his turn, but he too fell asleep at midnight, and again an apple was missing. At last, the youngest son offered to watch. Though his father feared for his safety, he was allowed to keep watch. At midnight, the young man heard a rustling and saw a bird of pure gold flying toward the tree. As the bird reached for an apple, the son shot an arrow at it. The arrow did not harm the bird, but a golden feather fell from its tail as it flew away. The next morning, the feather was shown to the king and his council, who agreed it was worth more than all the kingdom's treasure. Yet the king declared that one feather was not enough; he must have the whole golden bird.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Every day, the golden apples attracted many visitors who marveled at their beauty and wished to possess them. The king, however, was very protective of his precious tree and ordered his guards to watch over it day and night. One day, a cunning fox approached the garden and, seeing the guards asleep, managed to steal one of the golden apples. The king was furious when he discovered the theft and promised a great reward to anyone who could catch the thief.

A young shepherd boy, hearing of the king's promise, decided to help. He hid near the tree and waited patiently. When the fox returned to steal another apple, the boy caught him in the act. The fox begged for mercy and promised to reveal a secret in exchange for his freedom. The boy agreed, and the fox told him about a hidden treasure buried beneath the old oak tree at the edge of the forest.

The boy led the king to the treasure, which was filled with gold and jewels beyond imagination. The king was so pleased that he rewarded the boy generously and allowed him to keep the golden apple as a token of gratitude. From that day on, the boy became the king's trusted advisor, and the garden remained safe and prosperous. The golden apples continued to shine, symbolizing the rewards of patience, courage, and cleverness.

events.title: The Elder Sons' Disregard for Counsel and Subsequent Failures
detailed_summary: The gardener's eldest son embarked on a quest for the golden bird, expecting an easy search.
Early in his journey, he encountered a fox near a wood and prepared to shoot it.
The fox implored him not to shoot, offering valuable advice regarding his quest for the golden bird.
The fox forewarned him about a village with two opposing inns he would reach by evening, advising him to choose the poorer-looking one over the pleasant, beautiful one.
The son internally dismissed the fox's advice, doubting a mere animal's wisdom, and shot at the fox but missed as it escaped into the wood.
Upon reaching the village, he found one inn lively with singing, dancing, and feasting, while the other appeared dirty and impoverished.
Believing it foolish to choose the shabby inn over the charming one, he entered the luxurious establishment, indulged himself, and forgot about the golden bird and his homeland.
After a significant time passed with no news from the eldest son, the second son set out on the same quest.
He encountered the same fox, who provided the identical counsel about the inns.
However, upon arriving at the village, the second son saw his eldest brother at the window of the merry inn, beckoning him inside.
Unable to resist the allure, he entered, and similarly forgot his quest for the golden bird and his country.

events.text_segment:
Then the gardener’s eldest son set out and thought to find the golden bird very easily; and when he had gone but a little way, he came to a wood, and by the side of the wood he saw a fox sitting; so he took his bow and made ready to shoot at it. Then the fox said, ‘Do not shoot me, for I will give you good counsel; I know what your business is, and that you want to find the golden bird. You will reach a village in the evening; and when you get there, you will see two inns opposite to each other, one of which is very pleasant and beautiful to look at: go not in there, but rest for the night in the other, though it may appear to you to be very poor and mean.’ But the son thought to himself, ‘What can such a beast as this know about the matter?’ So he shot his arrow at the fox; but he missed it, and it set up its tail above its back and ran into the wood. Then he went his way, and in the evening came to the village where the two inns were; and in one of these were people singing, and dancing, and feasting; but the other looked very dirty, and poor. ‘I should be very silly,’ said he, ‘if I went to that shabby house, and left this charming place’; so he went into the smart house, and ate and drank at his ease, and forgot the bird, and his country too.
Time passed on; and as the eldest son did not come back, and no tidings were heard of him, the second son set out, and the same thing happened to him. He met the fox, who gave him the good advice: but when he came to the two inns, his eldest brother was standing at the window where the merrymaking was, and called to him to come in; and he could not withstand the temptation, but went in, and forgot the golden bird and his country in the same manner.

But the fox begged him so earnestly that he let him live. Then the fox said, "When you come to the village this evening, you will find two inns; one is very beautiful and full of people singing and dancing and feasting, and the other is poor and dirty. Do not go into the beautiful inn, but choose the poor one." The gardener’s son thought, "What nonsense! When the son came to the village, he saw the two inns; one was indeed very beautiful and full of people singing and dancing and feasting, and the other was poor and dirty. He thought it foolish to choose the poor inn, so he went into the beautiful one and feasted and drank and forgot all about the golden bird and his home. After a long time, no news came of the eldest son, so the gardener’s second son set out to find the golden bird. He met the same fox, who gave him the same advice about the inns. When he came to the village, he saw his eldest brother at the window of the merry inn, beckoning him to come in. The second son could not resist and went in, and like his brother, forgot his quest for the golden bird and his country.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: But the fox called out, "Do not shoot me, good youth! If you will only spare my life, I will help you to find the golden bird." The gardener’s son was surprised, but he lowered his bow and asked, "How can you help me?" The fox replied, "Follow me, and I will guide you to the tree where the golden bird sits." So the young man followed the fox deep into the forest until they came to a great tree with golden leaves and a bird with feathers of pure gold perched upon a branch. The gardener’s son was about to climb the tree when the fox warned him, "Do not try to take the bird by force, or you will lose it. Instead, wait until it flies down to drink at the clear spring nearby." The young man did as he was told and waited patiently. When the golden bird flew down to the spring, he quickly caught it in his hands. The fox then said, "Now, take the bird to your father, but be careful not to let it escape." The gardener’s son thanked the fox and hurried home with the golden bird. When he returned, his father was overjoyed and said, "You have done well, my son!" But the king, upon hearing of the golden bird, desired to have it for himself. He sent for the gardener’s son and demanded the bird. The young man, fearing the king’s wrath, gave it to him. However, the king was not satisfied and sent the gardener’s son on another quest, this time for the golden horse that stood in the king’s stables. Thus began a series of adventures, each aided by the clever fox, who proved to be a faithful and wise companion throughout the trials.

events.title: The Youngest Son's Wisdom: Heeding the Fox's Initial Advice
detailed_summary: As time continued to pass, the youngest son also expressed a desire to venture out and find the golden bird.
His father, deeply fond of him and fearing misfortune similar to his brothers, resisted for a long time.
Eventually, due to the son's persistence and unwillingness to stay home, his father consented to the journey.
Upon reaching the wood, the youngest son met the fox, who offered him the same advice given to his brothers.
Unlike his siblings, the youngest son was grateful to the fox and made no attempt to harm it.
Pleased with his attitude, the fox offered to help him travel faster if he sat on its tail.
The son accepted, and the fox ran with such speed over obstacles that their hair whistled in the wind.
When they arrived at the village, the youngest son followed the fox's guidance without hesitation, choosing the shabby inn for his overnight stay, where he rested comfortably.
The next morning, as he was about to continue his journey, the fox met him again with further instructions.
The fox directed him to a castle where soldiers would be asleep, telling him to proceed through the castle to a room where the golden bird was kept in a wooden cage.
Crucially, the fox warned him not to transfer the bird from its plain wooden cage to a nearby beautiful golden cage, or he would regret it.
The fox then extended its tail once more, and they sped off again with great velocity.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the fox stretched out his tail again, and the young man sat himself down, and away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled in the wind.

events.text_segment:
Time passed on again, and the youngest son too wished to set out into the wide world to seek for the golden bird; but his father would not listen to it for a long while, for he was very fond of his son, and was afraid that some ill luck might happen to him also, and prevent his coming back. However, at last it was agreed he should go, for he would not rest at home; and as he came to the wood, he met the fox, and heard the same good counsel. But he was thankful to the fox, and did not attempt his life as his brothers had done; so the fox said, ‘Sit upon my tail, and you will travel faster.’ So he sat down, and the fox began to run, and away they went over stock and stone so quick that their hair whistled in the wind.
When they came to the village, the son followed the fox’s counsel, and without looking about him went to the shabby inn and rested there all night at his ease. In the morning came the fox again and met him as he was beginning his journey, and said, ‘Go straight forward, till you come to a castle, before which lie a whole troop of soldiers fast asleep and snoring: take no notice of them, but go into the castle and pass on and on till you come to a room, where the golden bird sits in a wooden cage; close by it stands a beautiful golden cage; but do not try to take the bird out of the shabby cage and put it into the handsome one, otherwise you will repent it.’ Then the fox stretched out his tail again, and the young man sat himself down, and away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled in the wind.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Time passed on again, and the youngest son too wished to set out into the wide world to seek for the golden bird; but his father would not listen to it for a long while, for he was very fond of his son, and was afraid that some ill luck might happen to him also, and prevent his coming back. At last, however, the boy would not be kept at home, and his father gave way, and let him go. When he came to the wood, he met the fox, who said to him, "You are going to seek the golden bird, I suppose?" "Yes," said the boy. "Then," said the fox, "I will help you, if you will be kind to me, and not hurt me as your brothers did." The boy promised, and the fox said, "Then sit on my tail, and I will carry you quickly over the wood." The fox ran so fast that the boy's hair whistled in the wind. When they came to the village, the fox said, "Go to the inn, and choose the worst room, and there you will find rest and comfort." The boy did as he was told, and slept well. The next morning the fox met him again, and said, "Now you must go to the castle, where the soldiers are asleep. Pass through the castle to the room where the golden bird is kept in a plain wooden cage. Do not, whatever you do, put the bird into the beautiful golden cage near it, or you will be sorry." Then the fox stretched out his tail again, and away they went with great speed.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text: Time passed on again, and the youngest son too wished to set out into the wide world to seek for the golden bird; but his father would not listen to it for a long while, for he was very fond of his son, and was afraid that some ill luck might happen to him also, and prevent his coming back. At last, however, the boy would not be kept at home, and his father gave way, and let him go. When he came to the wood, he met the fox, who gave him the same advice as he had given to his brothers. But the boy was thankful to the fox, and did not try to hurt him. Then the fox said, "If you will sit on my tail, I will carry you quickly over the wood." So the boy sat on the fox's tail, and the fox ran so fast over stock and stone that the boy's hair whistled in the wind. When they came to the village, the fox told him to go straight to the inn, and to choose the shabby room without looking around, and there he would rest at his ease. The boy did as he was told, and slept well. The next morning, when he was going on his way, the fox met him again, and said, "Go straight forward to the castle, where the whole troop of soldiers are fast asleep and snoring; take no notice of them. Pass through the castle to the room where the golden bird is kept in a wooden cage. But do not take the bird out of the wooden cage, and put it into the golden cage near it, or you will repent it." Then the fox stretched out his tail again, and away they went over stock and stone, so fast that the boy's hair whistled in the wind.

events.title: The First Test: The Allure of the Golden Cage Leads to Capture
characters: King (of the castle with the bird)
detailed_summary: Upon reaching the castle, the son found everything as the fox had described: soldiers asleep at the gate.
He entered the castle and located the chamber where the golden bird resided in a simple wooden cage.
Nearby stood an ornate golden cage, and beside it lay the three missing golden apples.
The son thought it would be peculiar to carry such a magnificent bird in its current shabby container.
He opened the wooden cage's door, took the bird, and placed it into the golden cage.
Instantly, the bird let out a piercing scream, awakening all the sleeping soldiers.
The soldiers apprehended him and brought him before the king of that castle.
The following morning, the court convened to pass judgment on him.
After hearing the case, he was condemned to death unless he could bring the king the golden horse, renowned for its incredible speed.
If he succeeded in this task, he would be granted the golden bird as his own possession.

events.text_segment: Before the castle gate all was as the fox had said: so the son went in and found the chamber where the golden bird hung in a wooden cage, and below stood the golden cage, and the three golden apples that had been lost were lying close by it. Then thought he to himself, ‘It will be a very droll thing to bring away such a fine bird in this shabby cage’; so he opened the door and took hold of it and put it into the golden cage. But the bird set up such a loud scream that all the soldiers awoke, and they took him prisoner and carried him before the king. The next morning the court sat to judge him; and when all was heard, it sentenced him to die, unless he should bring the king the golden horse which could run as swiftly as the wind; and if he did this, he was to have the golden bird given him for his own.

events.title: The Second Test: The Temptation of the Golden Saddle and Another Capture
characters: Court (representing King of the castle with the horse)
detailed_summary: The son departed on this new quest, feeling disheartened and desperate.
Suddenly, his companion, the fox, appeared before him.
The fox pointed out that his current predicament was a result of not heeding its counsel.
Nevertheless, the fox offered to guide him to the golden horse, provided he followed instructions precisely.
He was to travel directly to a castle where the horse was stabled. A groom would be asleep beside it.
The fox instructed him to take the horse quietly but to ensure he used an old leather saddle instead of a nearby golden one.
The son sat on the fox's tail, and they journeyed rapidly once more.
Everything at the castle was as the fox predicted, with the groom asleep, his hand resting on the golden saddle.
However, upon seeing the magnificent horse, the son felt it was a shame to use the plain leather saddle.
He decided the horse deserved the finer, golden saddle.
As he picked up the golden saddle, the groom awoke and shouted loudly.
This alerted the guards, who rushed in and captured the son.
The next morning, he was again brought before the court, judged, and sentenced to death.
However, a condition was offered: if he could bring the beautiful princess to that kingdom, his life would be spared, and he would receive both the bird and the horse.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So he set out once more on his journey, sighing, and in great despair, when on a sudden his friend the fox met him, and said, ‘You see now what has happened on account of your not listening to my counsel.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it was agreed, that, if he could bring thither the beautiful princess, he should live, and have the bird and the horse given him for his own.

events.text_segment:
So he set out once more on his journey, sighing, and in great despair, when on a sudden his friend the fox met him, and said, ‘You see now what has happened on account of your not listening to my counsel. I will still, however, tell you how to find the golden horse, if you will do as I bid you. You must go straight on till you come to the castle where the horse stands in his stall: by his side will lie the groom fast asleep and snoring: take away the horse quietly, but be sure to put the old leathern saddle upon him, and not the golden one that is close by it.’ Then the son sat down on the fox’s tail, and away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled in the wind.
All went right, and the groom lay snoring with his hand upon the golden saddle. But when the son looked at the horse, he thought it a great pity to put the leathern saddle upon it. ‘I will give him the good one,’ said he; ‘I am sure he deserves it.’ As he took up the golden saddle the groom awoke and cried out so loud, that all the guards ran in and took him prisoner, and in the morning he was again brought before the court to be judged, and was sentenced to die. But it was agreed, that, if he could bring thither the beautiful princess, he should live, and have the bird and the horse given him for his own.

events.title: The Third Test: A Moment of Compassion Leads to a Third Capture
detailed_summary: Filled with sorrow, the young man resumed his journey.
The old fox appeared again, chiding him for his disobedience, which could have allowed him to possess both the bird and horse already.
Despite this, the fox offered counsel once more.
He was to travel straight ahead until evening, when he would reach a castle.
At midnight, the princess would go to the bathing-house; he was to approach her, give her a kiss, and she would agree to be led away by him.
The fox sternly warned him not to permit her to say farewell to her parents.
The fox then stretched out its tail, and they sped off rapidly.
Upon arriving at the castle, events unfolded as the fox had foretold.
At twelve o'clock, the young man encountered the princess on her way to the bath and kissed her.
She consented to elope with him but pleaded tearfully for permission to bid her father goodbye.
Initially, he refused, but her persistent weeping and her falling at his feet eventually swayed him to agree.
The instant she reached her father's residence, the guards awoke, and the young man was captured yet again.

events.text_segment:
Then he went his way very sorrowful; but the old fox came and said, ‘Why did not you listen to me? If you had, you would have carried away both the bird and the horse; yet will I once more give you counsel. Go straight on, and in the evening you will arrive at a castle. At twelve o’clock at night the princess goes to the bathing-house: go up to her and give her a kiss, and she will let you lead her away; but take care you do not suffer her to go and take leave of her father and mother.’ Then the fox stretched out his tail, and so away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled again.
As they came to the castle, all was as the fox had said, and at twelve o’clock the young man met the princess going to the bath and gave her the kiss, and she agreed to run away with him, but begged with many tears that he would let her take leave of her father. At first he refused, but she wept still more and more, and fell at his feet, till at last he consented; but the moment she came to her father’s house the guards awoke and he was taken prisoner again.

events.title: The Impossible Task: The Hill and the Fox's Magical Intervention
detailed_summary: The young man was brought before the king, the princess's father.
The king declared that the young man could only have his daughter if, within eight days, he removed a massive hill that obstructed the view from the king's window.
This hill was so enormous that it seemed an impossible task for anyone to remove.
After seven days of labor with very little progress, the fox appeared.
The fox instructed the young man to lie down and sleep, assuring him that it would handle the work.
When the young man awoke the next morning, the hill had vanished completely.
Joyfully, he went to the king and informed him that the condition was met and the princess must now be his.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then he was brought before the king, and the king said, ‘You shall never have my daughter unless in eight days you dig away the hill that stops the view from my window.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And in the morning he awoke and the hill was gone; so he went merrily to the king, and told him that now that it was removed he must give him the princess.

events.text_segment: Then he was brought before the king, and the king said, ‘You shall never have my daughter unless in eight days you dig away the hill that stops the view from my window.’ Now this hill was so big that the whole world could not take it away: and when he had worked for seven days, and had done very little, the fox came and said. ‘Lie down and go to sleep; I will work for you.’ And in the morning he awoke and the hill was gone; so he went merrily to the king, and told him that now that it was removed he must give him the princess.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Then he was brought before the king, and the king said, ‘You shall never have my daughter unless in eight days you dig away the hill that stops the view from my window.’

The hill was so vast and so high that it seemed an impossible task for any man to remove it in so short a time. The young man set to work with all his might, digging and hauling away the earth, but after seven days he had scarcely made a dent in the great mound.

On the seventh night, as he lay exhausted and despairing, the fox appeared beside him. ‘Lie down and sleep,’ said the fox, ‘and leave the work to me.’

The young man obeyed, and when he awoke the next morning, the hill was gone, the earth all cleared away, and the view from the king’s window was open and free.

Filled with joy, the young man went to the king and said, ‘The hill is removed, and now the princess must be mine.’

events.title: The Fox's Master Plan - Part 1: Securing the Golden Horse with the Princess
detailed_summary: The king (the princess's father) was compelled to honor his promise, and the young man departed with the princess.
The fox then appeared and announced to the young man that they would successfully acquire all three treasures: the princess, the horse, and the bird.
The young man expressed astonishment and inquired how such a feat could be achieved.
The fox explained that it was possible if he carefully followed instructions.
Upon arriving before the king who had demanded the princess (King H, for the golden horse), the young man was to present her by saying, "Here she is!".
This king would be overjoyed. The young man would then mount the golden horse that was to be given to him.
He should extend his hand to bid farewell to those present, but ensure he shook hands with the princess last.
At that moment, he was to swiftly lift her onto the horse behind him, urge the horse forward with his spurs, and gallop away as quickly as possible.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then the king was obliged to keep his word, and away went the young man and the princess; and the fox came and said to him, ‘We will have all three, the princess, the horse, and the bird.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then lift her quickly on to the horse behind you; clap your spurs to his side, and gallop away as fast as you can.’

events.text_segment:
Then the king was obliged to keep his word, and away went the young man and the princess; and the fox came and said to him, ‘We will have all three, the princess, the horse, and the bird.’ ‘Ah!’ said the young man, ‘that would be a great thing, but how can you contrive it?’
‘If you will only listen,’ said the fox, ‘it can be done. When you come to the king, and he asks for the beautiful princess, you must say, “Here she is!” Then he will be very joyful; and you will mount the golden horse that they are to give you, and put out your hand to take leave of them; but shake hands with the princess last. Then lift her quickly on to the horse behind you; clap your spurs to his side, and gallop away as fast as you can.’

‘If you do exactly as I tell you,’ said the fox, ‘it will be done. When you come before the king who demands the princess, say to him, “Here she is!” He will be so glad that he will give you the golden horse. Then mount the horse, and when you are ready to go, shake hands with all who are there, but be sure to shake hands with the princess last. At that moment, lift her quickly onto the horse behind you, urge the horse forward with your spurs, and ride away as fast as you can.’

events.title: The Fox's Master Plan - Part 2: Securing the Golden Bird, and the Fox's Parting
detailed_summary: The plan to secure the princess and the golden horse from King H succeeded perfectly.
The fox then outlined the next phase: acquiring the golden bird from King B.
The fox would wait with the princess at the castle door while the young man rode in to speak with King B.
Upon seeing that the young man had brought the correct golden horse, King B would produce the golden bird.
The young man was instructed to remain mounted and state his desire to examine the bird closely to verify its authenticity.
Once the bird was in his possession, he was to ride away swiftly.
This part of the plan also unfolded exactly as the fox had predicted; they successfully obtained the bird.
The princess remounted, and they continued their journey until they reached a large wood.
There, the fox approached the young man with a startling request: to kill it and sever its head and feet.
The young man refused to do so.
The fox then offered some final pieces of important advice: he should be wary of two things – never to ransom anyone from the gallows, and never to sit down by the bank of a river.
With that, the fox departed, and the young man considered the advice easy to follow.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: All went right: then the fox said, ‘When you come to the castle where the bird is, I will stay with the princess at the door, and you will ride in and speak to the king; and when he sees that it is the right horse, he will bring out the bird; but you must sit still, and say that you want to look at it, to see whether it is the true golden bird; and when you get it into your hand, ride away.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Well,’ thought the young man, ‘it is no hard matter to keep that advice.’

events.text_segment:
All went right: then the fox said, ‘When you come to the castle where the bird is, I will stay with the princess at the door, and you will ride in and speak to the king; and when he sees that it is the right horse, he will bring out the bird; but you must sit still, and say that you want to look at it, to see whether it is the true golden bird; and when you get it into your hand, ride away.’
This, too, happened as the fox said; they carried off the bird, the princess mounted again, and they rode on to a great wood. Then the fox came, and said, ‘Pray kill me, and cut off my head and my feet.’ But the young man refused to do it: so the fox said, ‘I will at any rate give you good counsel: beware of two things; ransom no one from the gallows, and sit down by the side of no river.’ Then away he went. ‘Well,’ thought the young man, ‘it is no hard matter to keep that advice.’

events.title: Betrayal and Loss: Ignoring Counsel Leads to Disaster
detailed_summary: The young man journeyed onward with the princess until they arrived at the village where he had previously left his two brothers.
He heard a significant commotion and, upon inquiring, learned that two men were about to be executed by hanging.
As he drew closer, he recognized the condemned men as his own brothers, who had resorted to robbery.
He asked if there was any way to save them.
The villagers replied that their freedom could only be bought if he paid all his money for the
Without a second thought, he paid the demanded sum, securing his brothers' release, thereby ignoring the fox's first piece of advice.
His brothers were freed and continued the journey homeward with him.
When they reached the wood where the fox had first encountered him, the area was cool and inviting.
His brothers suggested they rest for a while by the riverside to eat and drink.
He agreed, forgetting the fox's second warning, and sat down by the river.
While he was unsuspecting, his brothers attacked him from behind, throwing him down the riverbank.
They seized the princess, the horse, and the bird, and returned to their king (the young man's original king), claiming they had won all these treasures through their own efforts.
This news led to great celebrations, but an ominous sign appeared: the horse refused to eat, the bird refused to sing, and the princess wept continuously.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He rode on with the princess, till at last he came to the village where he had left his two brothers.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then there was great rejoicing made; but the horse would not eat, the bird would not sing, and the princess wept.

events.text_segment:
He rode on with the princess, till at last he came to the village where he had left his two brothers. And there he heard a great noise and uproar; and when he asked what was the matter, the people said, ‘Two men are going to be hanged.’ As he came nearer, he saw that the two men were his brothers, who had turned robbers; so he said, ‘Cannot they in any way be saved?’ But the people said ‘No,’ unless he would bestow all his money upon the rascals and buy their liberty. Then he did not stay to think about the matter, but paid what was asked, and his brothers were given up, and went on with him towards their home.
And as they came to the wood where the fox first met them, it was so cool and pleasant that the two brothers said, ‘Let us sit down by the side of the river, and rest a while, to eat and drink.’ So he said, ‘Yes,’ and forgot the fox’s counsel, and sat down on the side of the river; and while he suspected nothing, they came behind, and threw him down the bank, and took the princess, the horse, and the bird, and went home to the king their master, and said. ‘All this have we won by our labour.’ Then there was great rejoicing made; but the horse would not eat, the bird would not sing, and the princess wept.

events.title: Redemption and Justice: The Youngest Son Reclaims His Rewards
detailed_summary: The youngest son landed at the bottom of the riverbed. Fortunately, it was almost dry, but he suffered near-broken bones and faced a bank too steep to climb.
The old fox appeared once more, scolding him for disregarding its advice, which had led to his current misfortune.
Despite the reprimand, the fox declared it could not abandon him there and instructed him to grab its tail firmly.
The fox then pulled him out of the river. Once on the bank, the fox warned him that his brothers had set a watch to kill him if he was found within the kingdom.
Consequently, the youngest son disguised himself as a commoner and secretly made his way to the king's court.
He had barely entered the premises when the horse began to eat, the bird started to sing, and the princess ceased her weeping.
He then approached the king and revealed the full extent of his brothers' deceitful actions.
The treacherous brothers were consequently arrested and punished for their crimes.
The princess was rightfully returned to the youngest son, and after the king's eventual death, he became the heir to the kingdom.

events.text_segment: The youngest son fell to the bottom of the river’s bed: luckily it was nearly dry, but his bones were almost broken, and the bank was so steep that he could find no way to get out. Then the old fox came once more, and scolded him for not following his advice; otherwise no evil would have befallen him: ‘Yet,’ said he, ‘I cannot leave you here, so lay hold of my tail and hold fast.’ Then he pulled him out of the river, and said to him, as he got upon the bank, ‘Your brothers have set watch to kill you, if they find you in the kingdom.’ So he dressed himself as a poor man, and came secretly to the king’s court, and was scarcely within the doors when the horse began to eat, and the bird to sing, and the princess left off weeping. Then he went to the king, and told him all his brothers’ roguery; and they were seized and punished, and he had the princess given to him again; and after the king’s death he was heir to his kingdom.

events.title: The Fox's Metamorphosis: A Final Act of Loyalty Reveals a Hidden Identity
detailed_summary: A considerable time later, while taking a walk in the wood one day, the young man (now a prominent figure, likely a king or prince) encountered the old fox again.
With tears in its eyes, the fox earnestly begged him to end its life by killing it and cutting off its head and feet.
After some hesitation, the young man complied with the fox's desperate plea.
In an instant, the fox underwent a magical transformation, changing into a man.
This man was revealed to be the princess's brother, who had been missing for many, many years.

events.title: Hans Receives Payment and Trades Silver for a Horse
detailed_summary: The narrative opens by describing a category of individuals blessed with innate good fortune, introducing Hans as such a person.
After completing seven years of dedicated work, Hans informed his master of his intention to return home to his mother and requested his due wages.
The master, pleased with Hans's loyal service, paid him with a substantial lump of silver, comparable in size to Hans's head.
Hans secured the silver in his pocket-handkerchief, slung it over his shoulder, and set off towards his home.

While trudging along, he observed a man riding a horse with apparent ease and comfort, and Hans audibly wished for such a pleasant mode of travel, contrasting it with the discomfort of carrying his heavy silver.
The horseman overheard Hans's remarks and inquired why Hans was walking.
Hans explained his burden, highlighting the silver's weight and the pain it caused his shoulder.
The horseman proposed an exchange: his horse for Hans's silver, suggesting it would relieve Hans of his heavy load.
Hans enthusiastically accepted the offer, even expressing concern for the horseman's future task of carrying the silver, perceiving the horseman's offer as an act of kindness.
The exchange was made, and the horseman provided Hans with instructions on how to make the horse go faster by smacking his lips and shouting "Jip!".

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When you want to go very fast, smack your lips loudly together, and cry “Jip!”’

events.text_segment:
Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster. The world may very likely not always think of them as they think of themselves, but what care they for the world? what can it know about the matter?
One of these lucky beings was neighbour Hans. Seven long years he had worked hard for his master. At last he said, ‘Master, my time is up; I must go home and see my poor mother once more: so pray pay me my wages and let me go.’ And the master said, ‘You have been a faithful and good servant, Hans, so your pay shall be handsome.’ Then he gave him a lump of silver as big as his head.
Hans took out his pocket-handkerchief, put the piece of silver into it, threw it over his shoulder, and jogged off on his road homewards. As he went lazily on, dragging one foot after another, a man came in sight, trotting gaily along on a capital horse. ‘Ah!’ said Hans aloud, ‘what a fine thing it is to ride on horseback! There he sits as easy and happy as if he was at home, in the chair by his fireside; he trips against no stones, saves shoe-leather, and gets on he hardly knows how.’ Hans did not speak so softly but the horseman heard it all, and said, ‘Well, friend, why do you go on foot then?’ ‘Ah!’ said he, ‘I have this load to carry: to be sure it is silver, but it is so heavy that I can’t hold up my head, and you must know it hurts my shoulder sadly.’ ‘What do you say of making an exchange?’ said the horseman. ‘I will give you my horse, and you shall give me the silver; which will save you a great deal of trouble in carrying such a heavy load about with you.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said Hans: ‘but as you are so kind to me, I must tell you one thing—you will have a weary task to draw that silver about with you.’ However, the horseman got off, took the silver, helped Hans up, gave him the bridle into one hand and the whip into the other, and said, ‘When you want to go very fast, smack your lips loudly together, and cry “Jip!”’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster.

Hans was one of these lucky fellows. He had served his master for seven years, and then he said, "Now I will go home to my mother. I have worked hard, and I want my wages."

His master was pleased with him, and gave him a lump of silver as big as his head. Hans tied it up in his handkerchief, slung it over his shoulder, and set off on his journey home.

As he walked along, he saw a man riding a horse, sitting so comfortably and easily. "Oh, how I wish I could ride like that!" said Hans. "This lump of silver is so heavy, and it hurts my shoulder."

The horseman heard him and asked, "Why are you walking?"

Hans answered, "I have this heavy lump of silver, and it is too much for me to carry."

The horseman said, "If you like, you can have my horse in exchange for your silver. Then you won't have to carry that heavy lump any longer."

Hans was delighted and said, "That is very kind of you. I will gladly make the exchange. But I do hope you won't find it too hard to carry the silver."

So they exchanged, and the horseman gave Hans some advice: "If you want the horse to go faster, smack your lips and shout 'Jip!'"

Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster.

The world looks on such lucky people with envy and wonder, and says, "How lucky he is!" But the lucky man himself cares little for the world's opinion; he goes his way, and the world may say what it will.

His master was well pleased with him, and said, "You have been a faithful servant, and I will pay you handsomely." So he gave Hans a lump of silver as big as his head.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster.

There was once a man who had such good fortune that everything he touched turned to gold. He was so lucky that even when he lost, he gained something better in return. One day, he found a cat that could talk and promised to make his fortune even greater. The cat asked for a pair of boots and a bag, and with these, he set out to catch game for his master.

The cat was clever and cunning. He caught rabbits and partridges and presented them to the king, saying they were gifts from his master, the Marquis of Carabas. The king was pleased and invited the marquis to his castle. The cat then tricked a wealthy ogre into turning himself into a mouse, which the cat promptly ate, thus securing the ogre's vast lands for his master.

Thanks to the cat's wit and the man's good luck, the marquis married the princess and lived happily ever after. This tale shows that sometimes, good fortune and cleverness together can lead to great success.

But not all men are so lucky. Some must work hard and face many trials before they find happiness. Yet, even the unluckiest can find their own path if they are brave and kind.

Thus, the story reminds us that while some are born to good luck, it is often wisdom and courage that make the difference in the end.

events.title: A Brief Ride, a Fall, and a Trade: Horse for Cow
detailed_summary: Initially, Hans was thrilled with his new horse, riding along joyfully, whistling and singing a song about being carefree.
He decided to increase his speed and, using the command "Jip!", caused the horse to bolt into a full gallop.
Before Hans could react, he was thrown from the horse and landed on his back by the roadside.
A shepherd, who was passing by driving a cow, managed to stop Hans's horse before it could run off completely.
Hans, having recovered but feeling quite annoyed, complained to the shepherd about the treacherous nature of riding such a spirited animal, noting how it had damaged his coat in a puddle.
He then expressed a strong preference for the shepherd's cow, imagining the ease of walking behind it and the daily benefits of milk, butter, and cheese.
The shepherd, stating a desire to help his neighbors even at a personal loss, offered to trade his cow for Hans's horse.
Hans cheerfully agreed to the swap, privately marveling at what he perceived as the shepherd's noble and generous heart.
The shepherd then mounted the horse, bid Hans farewell, and rode away.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hans was delighted as he sat on the horse, drew himself up, squared his elbows, turned out his toes, cracked his whip, and rode merrily off, one minute whistling a merry tune, and another singing,
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the shepherd jumped upon the horse, wished Hans and the cow good morning, and away he rode.

events.text_segment:
Hans was delighted as he sat on the horse, drew himself up, squared his elbows, turned out his toes, cracked his whip, and rode merrily off, one minute whistling a merry tune, and another singing,
"No care and no sorrow,
A fig for the morrow!
We’ll laugh and be merry,
Sing neigh down derry!"
After a time he thought he should like to go a little faster, so he smacked his lips and cried ‘Jip!’ Away went the horse full gallop; and before Hans knew what he was about, he was thrown off, and lay on his back by the road-side. His horse would have ran off, if a shepherd who was coming by, driving a cow, had not stopped it. Hans soon came to himself, and got upon his legs again, sadly vexed, and said to the shepherd, ‘This riding is no joke, when a man has the luck to get upon a beast like this that stumbles and flings him off as if it would break his neck. However, I’m off now once for all: I like your cow now a great deal better than this smart beast that played me this trick, and has spoiled my best coat, you see, in this puddle; which, by the by, smells not very like a nosegay. One can walk along at one’s leisure behind that cow—keep good company, and have milk, butter, and cheese, every day, into the bargain. What would I give to have such a prize!’ ‘Well,’ said the shepherd, ‘if you are so fond of her, I will change my cow for your horse; I like to do good to my neighbours, even though I lose by it myself.’ ‘Done!’ said Hans, merrily. ‘What a noble heart that good man has!’ thought he. Then the shepherd jumped upon the horse, wished Hans and the cow good morning, and away he rode.

I have no wife to make me sigh,
I drink my beer and I am dry."

He was so happy that he thought he would never be so again. At last he said, "I will make the horse go faster," and he cried, "Jip!" and the horse sprang forward at a gallop. But Hans was not used to riding, and he was thrown off and fell on his back by the roadside.

A shepherd was driving a cow along the road and saw the horse running away. He caught it and stopped it before it could get far. Hans got up, rubbed his back, and said angrily, "What a wicked horse you are! You have thrown me off and spoiled my coat in the puddle."

Then he looked at the cow and said, "I think I would rather have your cow than my horse. It is so easy to walk behind a cow, and you get milk, butter, and cheese every day."

The shepherd said, "I want to help my neighbors, even if it costs me something. I will give you my cow for your horse."

Hans was very glad and said, "You are a good man with a noble heart."

The shepherd got on the horse, bade Hans goodbye, and rode away.

The wind blew through his hair, and the sun shone brightly upon his face. As he rode along the forest path, he thought of all the adventures that awaited him. Suddenly, he heard a rustling in the bushes. Out jumped a little fox, who looked up at Hans with bright, cunning eyes. At last, they reached a dark cave where a fearsome dragon guarded a glowing crystal. Hans drew his sword and, with a mighty cry, charged at the beast. After a fierce battle, he defeated the dragon and seized the crystal. Returning to the maiden, he held up the crystal, and the spell was broken. She smiled gratefully and thanked Hans for his bravery. Together, they rode back to the village, where Hans was hailed as a hero, his heart full of joy and pride.

events.title: The Unproductive Cow and Trading for a Pig
detailed_summary: After tidying himself up, Hans drove his new cow along, feeling very fortunate about his latest bargain.
He daydreamed about enjoying bread with his own butter and cheese, and drinking fresh milk whenever he was thirsty, considering these things the epitome of contentment.
Upon reaching an inn, he stopped, ate all the bread he had, and spent his very last penny on a glass of beer.
Continuing his journey towards his mother's village, he found himself on a vast, hot heath as noon approached, becoming extremely thirsty.
Confident he could remedy his thirst, Hans attempted to milk the cow, tying her to a tree and using his cap as a pail, only to discover she yielded no milk at all.
During his clumsy and unsuccessful milking efforts, the cow grew agitated and delivered a kick to Hans's head, rendering him unconscious for a significant time.
Fortunately, a butcher driving a pig in a wheelbarrow came by and helped Hans to his feet.
Hans recounted his unfortunate experience with the dry cow.
The butcher offered Hans a flask of ale and explained that the cow was old and only fit for slaughter, not for providing milk.
Hans lamented this turn of events, expressing regret over trading his horse for a useless cow and wishing he had a pig instead, which could at least be used for sausages.
The butcher, framing it as a kind and neighborly gesture, offered to exchange his pig for Hans's cow.
Hans accepted with gratitude, gave the cow to the butcher, took the pig, and continued his journey, feeling that his previous misfortunes were now fully rectified by this new acquisition.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Hans brushed his coat, wiped his face and hands, rested a while, and then drove off his cow quietly, and thought his bargain a very lucky one.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: How could it be otherwise with such a travelling companion as he had at last got?

events.text_segment:
Hans brushed his coat, wiped his face and hands, rested a while, and then drove off his cow quietly, and thought his bargain a very lucky one. ‘If I have only a piece of bread (and I certainly shall always be able to get that), I can, whenever I like, eat my butter and cheese with it; and when I am thirsty I can milk my cow and drink the milk: and what can I wish for more?’ When he came to an inn, he halted, ate up all his bread, and gave away his last penny for a glass of beer. When he had rested himself he set off again, driving his cow towards his mother’s village. But the heat grew greater as soon as noon came on, till at last, as he found himself on a wide heath that would take him more than an hour to cross, he began to be so hot and parched that his tongue clave to the roof of his mouth. ‘I can find a cure for this,’ thought he; ‘now I will milk my cow and quench my thirst’: so he tied her to the stump of a tree, and held his leathern cap to milk into; but not a drop was to be had. Who would have thought that this cow, which was to bring him milk and butter and cheese, was all that time utterly dry? Hans had not thought of looking to that.
While he was trying his luck in milking, and managing the matter very clumsily, the uneasy beast began to think him very troublesome; and at last gave him such a kick on the head as knocked him down; and there he lay a long while senseless. Luckily a butcher soon came by, driving a pig in a wheelbarrow. ‘What is the matter with you, my man?’ said the butcher, as he helped him up. Hans told him what had happened, how he was dry, and wanted to milk his cow, but found the cow was dry too. Then the butcher gave him a flask of ale, saying, ‘There, drink and refresh yourself; your cow will give you no milk: don’t you see she is an old beast, good for nothing but the slaughter-house?’ ‘Alas, alas!’ said Hans, ‘who would have thought it? What a shame to take my horse, and give me only a dry cow! If I kill her, what will she be good for? I hate cow-beef; it is not tender enough for me. If it were a pig now—like that fat gentleman you are driving along at his ease—one could do something with it; it would at any rate make sausages.’ ‘Well,’ said the butcher, ‘I don’t like to say no, when one is asked to do a kind, neighbourly thing. To please you I will change, and give you my fine fat pig for the cow.’ ‘Heaven reward you for your kindness and self-denial!’ said Hans, as he gave the butcher the cow; and taking the pig off the wheel-barrow, drove it away, holding it by the string that was tied to its leg.
So on he jogged, and all seemed now to go right with him: he had met with some misfortunes, to be sure; but he was now well repaid for all. How could it be otherwise with such a travelling companion as he had at last got?

Hans brushed his coat, wiped his face and hands, rested a while, and then drove off his cow quietly, and thought his bargain a very lucky one. As he went along the road, he met a man who asked him where he was going with the cow. Hans told him he had bought the cow for a few pennies and was taking it home. His mother was doubtful but helped him to milk the cow. To their great surprise, the cow gave a full pail of rich milk. Hans and his mother rejoiced, and Hans felt proud of his cleverness.

Hans continued to sell the milk and earned enough money to buy some bread and cheese. He returned home happily, thinking that his luck had truly changed.

Days passed, and the cow continued to give plenty of milk. Hans and his mother lived comfortably, and Hans was known in the village as a lucky and kind-hearted boy.

One day, a rich merchant came to the village and heard about Hans's cow. He offered to buy the cow for a large sum of money. Hans thought for a moment and agreed to sell the cow, as he had learned to be content with what he had.

With the money from the sale, Hans helped his mother improve their home and shared with the poor in the village. His kindness and good fortune made him beloved by all.

And so, Hans's simple act of kindness and his lucky bargain brought happiness not only to himself but to many others, proving that good heart and good fortune often go hand in hand.

events.title: Fear of Theft Prompts Trade: Pig for Goose
detailed_summary: Hans next encountered a countryman carrying a fine white goose.
The countryman initiated a conversation by asking the time, which led to Hans proudly recounting his string of successful trades and his overall good fortune.
The countryman then mentioned he was taking his goose, noted for its weight despite its youth, to a christening.
Hans, while acknowledging the goose's quality, boasted about the fatness of his own pig.

The countryman's demeanor then shifted; he looked grave and warned Hans that his pig might be stolen property from the local squire, which could lead to severe punishment, like being thrown into the horse-pond.
He questioned Hans's ability to swim, further alarming him.
Terrified, Hans pleaded with the countryman to help him out of this potential trouble, admitting he knew nothing of the pig's origin.
The countryman suggested an exchange: Hans's pig for the goose, portraying this as a kind act to save Hans from the scrape, though hinting it was an unequal trade in Hans's favor.
Hans readily agreed. The countryman took the pig, and Hans continued homeward with the goose, feeling carefree.

He privately concluded that the countryman had been fooled and that he, Hans, had secured the best deal, envisioning a roasted goose, months of goose-grease, and soft feathers for his pillow, all of which would delight his mother.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The next man he met was a countryman carrying a fine white goose.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Talk of a pig, indeed! Give me a fine fat goose.’

events.text_segment:
The next man he met was a countryman carrying a fine white goose. The countryman stopped to ask what was o’clock; this led to further chat; and Hans told him all his luck, how he had so many good bargains, and how all the world went gay and smiling with him. The countryman then began to tell his tale, and said he was going to take the goose to a christening. ‘Feel,’ said he, ‘how heavy it is, and yet it is only eight weeks old. Whoever roasts and eats it will find plenty of fat upon it, it has lived so well!’ ‘You’re right,’ said Hans, as he weighed it in his hand; ‘but if you talk of fat, my pig is no trifle.’ Meantime the countryman began to look grave, and shook his head. ‘Hark ye!’ said he, ‘my worthy friend, you seem a good sort of fellow, so I can’t help doing you a kind turn. Your pig may get you into a scrape. In the village I just came from, the squire has had a pig stolen out of his sty. I was dreadfully afraid when I saw you that you had got the squire’s pig. If you have, and they catch you, it will be a bad job for you. The least they will do will be to throw you into the horse-pond. Can you swim?’
Poor Hans was sadly frightened. ‘Good man,’ cried he, ‘pray get me out of this scrape. I know nothing of where the pig was either bred or born; but he may have been the squire’s for aught I can tell: you know this country better than I do, take my pig and give me the goose.’ ‘I ought to have something into the bargain,’ said the countryman; ‘give a fat goose for a pig, indeed! ‘Tis not everyone would do so much for you as that. However, I will not be hard upon you, as you are in trouble.’ Then he took the string in his hand, and drove off the pig by a side path; while Hans went on the way homewards free from care. ‘After all,’ thought he, ‘that chap is pretty well taken in. I don’t care whose pig it is, but wherever it came from it has been a very good friend to me. I have much the best of the bargain. First there will be a capital roast; then the fat will find me in goose-grease for six months; and then there are all the beautiful white feathers. I will put them into my pillow, and then I am sure I shall sleep soundly without rocking. How happy my mother will be! Talk of a pig, indeed! Give me a fine fat goose.’

The next man he met was a countryman carrying a fine white goose. The countryman greeted him kindly and asked, "Good sir, would you like to buy this fine goose? It is the best in the village, and it will bring you much joy." The man, who was weary from his travels and had little money, hesitated but was tempted by the plump bird. He agreed to buy the goose for a small sum and continued on his way.

As he walked through the forest, the man heard a rustling in the bushes. Suddenly, a little old woman appeared, leaning heavily on her staff. She looked at the goose and said, "That is a fine bird you have there. But beware, for it is enchanted. If you treat it well, it will bring you great fortune; if you neglect it, misfortune will follow."

The man thanked the old woman for her warning and promised to care for the goose. He found a quiet spot near a stream and set up a small camp. Each day, he fed the goose fresh grain and clean water, and in return, the goose laid golden eggs. The man was amazed and soon became wealthy beyond his dreams.

One day, a greedy neighbor saw the golden eggs and demanded to know the secret. The man, trusting his neighbor, told him about the enchanted goose. The neighbor, eager to have the same fortune, went to the market and bought a similar goose. But he did not care for it properly, neglecting to feed it or keep it safe.

As the old woman had warned, the neighbor's goose did not lay golden eggs. Instead, it grew sickly and died. The neighbor was left with nothing but regret.

The man, however, continued to live happily, always remembering the kindness he showed to the enchanted goose and the wise words of the old woman. He learned that fortune comes not just from luck, but from care, kindness, and respect for the gifts one receives.

And so, the man and his fine white goose lived many years in peace and prosperity, a testament to the virtues of patience and gratitude.

events.title: Enticed by Perpetual Wealth: Goose for Grindstone
detailed_summary: Upon arriving at the next village, Hans observed a scissor-grinder working at his wheel, singing happily.
Hans commented on the grinder's apparent contentment and prosperity.
The grinder affirmed that his trade was indeed lucrative, claiming that a good grinder always found money in his pocket.
After Hans detailed his sequence of trades—silver for a horse, horse for a cow, cow for a pig, and pig for the goose—the grinder proposed a way for Hans to achieve true fortune.
He suggested Hans become a grinder himself, stating that all he needed was a grindstone, and offered to trade his own, slightly used grindstone for Hans's goose.
The prospect of being able to find money in his pocket whenever he wished captivated Hans, who believed this would fulfill all his desires.
Eagerly, Hans agreed to the exchange, giving up his goose for the grindstone.
The grinder handed over what he described as a common rough stone, claiming it was a superior tool capable of sharpening even an old nail if worked properly.

Hans departed with the stone, his heart light and his eyes sparkling with joy, convinced he was born under a lucky star and that people were generously helping him become rich through these favorable bargains.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As he came to the next village, he saw a scissor-grinder with his wheel, working and singing,
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: People are so kind; they seem really to think I do them a favour in letting them make me rich, and giving me good bargains.’

events.text_segment:
As he came to the next village, he saw a scissor-grinder with his wheel, working and singing,
"O’er hill and o’er dale
So happy I roam,
Work light and live well,
All the world is my home;
Then who so blythe, so merry as I?"
Hans stood looking on for a while, and at last said, ‘You must be well off, master grinder! you seem so happy at your work.’ ‘Yes,’ said the other, ‘mine is a golden trade; a good grinder never puts his hand into his pocket without finding money in it—but where did you get that beautiful goose?’ ‘I did not buy it, I gave a pig for it.’ ‘And where did you get the pig?’ ‘I gave a cow for it.’ ‘And the cow?’ ‘I gave a horse for it.’ ‘And the horse?’ ‘I gave a lump of silver as big as my head for it.’ ‘And the silver?’ ‘Oh! I worked hard for that seven long years.’ ‘You have thriven well in the world hitherto,’ said the grinder, ‘now if you could find money in your pocket whenever you put your hand in it, your fortune would be made.’ ‘Very true: but how is that to be managed?’ ‘How? Why, you must turn grinder like myself,’ said the other; ‘you only want a grindstone; the rest will come of itself. Here is one that is but little the worse for wear: I would not ask more than the value of your goose for it—will you buy?’ ‘How can you ask?’ said Hans; ‘I should be the happiest man in the world, if I could have money whenever I put my hand in my pocket: what could I want more? there’s the goose.’ ‘Now,’ said the grinder, as he gave him a common rough stone that lay by his side, ‘this is a most capital stone; do but work it well enough, and you can make an old nail cut with it.’
Hans took the stone, and went his way with a light heart: his eyes sparkled for joy, and he said to himself, ‘Surely I must have been born in a lucky hour; everything I could want or wish for comes of itself. People are so kind; they seem really to think I do them a favour in letting them make me rich, and giving me good bargains.’

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
As he came to the next village, he saw a scissor-grinder with his wheel, working and singing,

"Turn, turn, grindstone, grind!"

and he looked so happy and contented that Hans said to him, "You seem to be a lucky fellow, and to have a good trade."

"Yes," said the grinder, "I am a lucky fellow, and a good trade it is; a good grinder always finds money in his pocket."

"How is that?" asked Hans.

"Why," said the grinder, "if you have a good grindstone, you can always find money in your pocket."

"But how did you get your grindstone?" asked Hans.

"I bought it," said the grinder.

"And what did you give for it?"

"I gave a goose for it."

"A goose!" said Hans. "I have just changed my pig for a goose."

"Then you must get a grindstone," said the grinder. "If you have a grindstone, you will always find money in your pocket."

"But how did you get your pig?" asked Hans.

"I changed a cow for it."

"And how did you get your cow?"

"I changed a horse for it."

"And how did you get your horse?"

"I changed my silver for it."

"And how did you get your silver?"

"I earned it."

"Then you see," said the grinder, "if you have a grindstone, you will always find money in your pocket."

"Well," said Hans, "if you will give me your grindstone for my goose, I will take it."

"Agreed," said the grinder, and he gave Hans a common rough stone, saying, "This is a good grindstone; it will sharpen even an old nail if you work it properly."

Hans took the stone, and went on his way, his heart light and his eyes sparkling with joy, thinking, "I am born under a lucky star; people are so kind to me, and help me to become rich by these good bargains."

events.title: The Grindstone's Burden, Accidental Loss, and Joyful Arrival
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, Hans began to feel the effects of his journey and his earlier generosity; he was tired and hungry, having spent his last penny after acquiring the cow.
The grindstone proved to be a heavy burden, eventually exhausting him to the point where he could go no further.
He managed to drag himself to the bank of a river to drink water and rest, carefully placing the stone beside him.
However, as he bent down to drink, he inadvertently nudged the stone, causing it to roll down the bank and plunge into the stream.
Hans watched the stone sink into the clear water for a moment.

Then, instead of being dismayed, he suddenly sprang up, danced with joy, and fell to his knees, tearfully thanking Heaven for its kindness in removing what he now perceived as his only burden, the "ugly heavy stone."
Exclaiming how happy and uniquely lucky he was, Hans rose with a light heart, feeling entirely free from all his troubles.
He then continued his journey until he finally reached his mother's house, where he shared with her his story of how easily he had found the path to good luck.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meantime he began to be tired, and hungry too, for he had given away his last penny in his joy at getting the cow.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then up he got with a light heart, free from all his troubles, and walked on till he reached his mother’s house, and told her how very easy the road to good luck was.

events.text_segment:
Meantime he began to be tired, and hungry too, for he had given away his last penny in his joy at getting the cow.
At last he could go no farther, for the stone tired him sadly: and he dragged himself to the side of a river, that he might take a drink of water, and rest a while. So he laid the stone carefully by his side on the bank: but, as he stooped down to drink, he forgot it, pushed it a little, and down it rolled, plump into the stream.
For a while he watched it sinking in the deep clear water; then sprang up and danced for joy, and again fell upon his knees and thanked Heaven, with tears in his eyes, for its kindness in taking away his only plague, the ugly heavy stone.
‘How happy am I!’ cried he; ‘nobody was ever so lucky as I.’ Then up he got with a light heart, free from all his troubles, and walked on till he reached his mother’s house, and told her how very easy the road to good luck was.

events.title: The Enchanted Castle and the Fairy's Curse
detailed_summary: An ancient castle in a dark forest was home to an old fairy with shapeshifting abilities.
By day, she would transform into an owl or a cat, but at night, she reverted to her form as an old woman.
Any young man who ventured within a hundred paces of her castle would be magically frozen in place until she released him, on the condition he never returned.
However, any pretty maiden who came within that same distance was turned into a bird, caged, and hung in a chamber within the castle.
The castle contained seven hundred such cages, each holding a beautiful bird.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There were seven hundred of these cages hanging in the castle, and all with beautiful birds in them.

events.text_segment: There was once an old castle, that stood in the middle of a deep gloomy wood, and in the castle lived an old fairy. Now this fairy could take any shape she pleased. All the day long she flew about in the form of an owl, or crept about the country like a cat; but at night she always became an old woman again. When any young man came within a hundred paces of her castle, he became quite fixed, and could not move a step till she came and set him free; which she would not do till he had given her his word never to come there again: but when any pretty maiden came within that space she was changed into a bird, and the fairy put her into a cage, and hung her up in a chamber in the castle. There were seven hundred of these cages hanging in the castle, and all with beautiful birds in them.

All day long she flew about as an owl, or crept about as a cat, but at night she became an old woman again. Any young man who came within a hundred paces of the castle was immediately frozen to the spot by her magic, and could not move until she released him, on condition that he never came near the castle again. But any pretty maiden who ventured within that distance was changed into a bird, and the fairy herself put her into a cage, which hung in a chamber of the castle. There were seven hundred such cages, all containing beautiful birds.

events.title: Jorinda and Jorindel's Fateful Walk and Growing Unease
detailed_summary: A maiden named Jorinda, renowned for her exceptional beauty, was betrothed to a shepherd lad named Jorindel who loved her dearly.
One day, they sought solitude by walking together in the woods.
Jorindel voiced a caution, reminding Jorinda that they needed to be careful not to stray too close to the fairy's castle.
The evening was idyllic, with the sun's fading rays illuminating the forest floor and turtle-doves cooing from the birch trees.
As Jorinda and Jorindel sat together, an inexplicable sadness overcame them, accompanied by a strong premonition that they were about to be separated forever.
They realized they had wandered a significant distance and were now lost, unsure of the way back home.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Now there was once a maiden whose name was Jorinda.

events.text_segment:
Now there was once a maiden whose name was Jorinda. She was prettier than all the pretty girls that ever were seen before, and a shepherd lad, whose name was Jorindel, was very fond of her, and they were soon to be married. One day they went to walk in the wood, that they might be alone; and Jorindel said, ‘We must take care that we don’t go too near to the fairy’s castle.’ It was a beautiful evening; the last rays of the setting sun shone bright through the long stems of the trees upon the green underwood beneath, and the turtle-doves sang from the tall birches.
Jorinda sat down to gaze upon the sun; Jorindel sat by her side; and both felt sad, they knew not why; but it seemed as if they were to be parted from one another for ever. They had wandered a long way; and when they looked to see which way they should go home, they found themselves at a loss to know what path to take.

events.title: Jorinda's Transformation and Capture by the Fairy
detailed_summary: As the sun rapidly descended, Jorindel looked around and realized with dread that they had unknowingly sat down very close to the old castle walls.
He was struck with fear, turning pale and trembling.
Jorinda was in the midst of singing a plaintive song about a ring-dove mourning its lost mate.
Her song was abruptly cut short as she was magically transformed into a nightingale, her voice ending in a bird's mournful call.
An owl with fiery eyes, revealed to be the fairy in disguise, circled them three times while emitting piercing screeches.
Jorindel found himself completely paralyzed by a spell, unable to move, weep, or speak.
The sun fully set, plunging the woods into darkness; the owl flew into a nearby bush.
A moment later, the old fairy emerged in her human form—pale, gaunt, with staring eyes and features so sharp her nose and chin nearly touched.
She muttered something under her breath, then seized the nightingale (Jorinda) and carried it away.

events.text_segment:
The sun was setting fast, and already half of its circle had sunk behind the hill: Jorindel on a sudden looked behind him, and saw through the bushes that they had, without knowing it, sat down close under the old walls of the castle. Then he shrank for fear, turned pale, and trembled. Jorinda was just singing,
‘The ring-dove sang from the willow spray,
  Well-a-day! Well-a-day!
  He mourn’d for the fate of his darling mate,
  Well-a-day!’
when her song stopped suddenly. Jorindel turned to see the reason, and beheld his Jorinda changed into a nightingale, so that her song ended with a mournful jug, jug. An owl with fiery eyes flew three times round them, and three times screamed:
‘Tu whu! Tu whu! Tu whu!’
Jorindel could not move; he stood fixed as a stone, and could neither weep, nor speak, nor stir hand or foot. And now the sun went quite down; the gloomy night came; the owl flew into a bush; and a moment after the old fairy came forth pale and meagre, with staring eyes, and a nose and chin that almost met one another.
She mumbled something to herself, seized the nightingale, and went away with it in her hand.

events.text_segment:
Poor Jorindel saw the nightingale was gone—but what could he do? He could not speak, he could not move from the spot where he stood. At last the fairy came back and sang with a hoarse voice:
 ‘Till the prisoner is fast,
  And her doom is cast,
  There stay! Oh, stay!
  When the charm is around her,
  And the spell has bound her,
  Hie away! away!’
On a sudden Jorindel found himself free. Then he fell on his knees before the fairy, and prayed her to give him back his dear Jorinda: but she laughed at him, and said he should never see her again; then she went her way.

events.title: Jorindel's Grief and a Prophetic Dream of Rescue
detailed_summary: Jorindel prayed, wept, and grieved deeply, but his sorrow brought no relief or change.
He lamented his desperate situation, wondering what would become of him.
Unable to return to his own home, he sought refuge in a different village where he found work tending sheep.
Many times, he would walk as near to the hated castle as his courage allowed, but he never saw or heard any trace of Jorinda.
One night, he had a vivid dream in which he discovered a beautiful purple flower with a costly pearl at its center.
In this dream, he picked the flower, carried it into the castle, and found that anything he touched with it was freed from enchantment, which led him to find Jorinda again.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He prayed, he wept, he sorrowed, but all in vain.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: At last he dreamt one night that he found a beautiful purple flower, and that in the middle of it lay a costly pearl; and he dreamt that he plucked the flower, and went with it in his hand into the castle, and that everything he touched with it was disenchanted, and that there he found his Jorinda again.

events.text_segment:
He prayed, he wept, he sorrowed, but all in vain. ‘Alas!’ he said, ‘what will become of me?’ He could not go back to his own home, so he went to a strange village, and employed himself in keeping sheep. Many a time did he walk round and round as near to the hated castle as he dared go, but all in vain; he heard or saw nothing of Jorinda.
At last he dreamt one night that he found a beautiful purple flower, and that in the middle of it lay a costly pearl; and he dreamt that he plucked the flower, and went with it in his hand into the castle, and that everything he touched with it was disenchanted, and that there he found his Jorinda again.

In the dream, he plucked the flower and carried it into the castle, and found that anything he touched with it was freed from enchantment. This discovery gave him hope, and he resolved to find Jorinda again and break the spell that held her captive.
