events.title: Seven at One Stroke: The Tailor's Accidental Feat and Bold Proclamation
detailed_summary: A little tailor, while sewing with enthusiasm, hears a peasant woman selling jams.
He calls her up and, after inspecting her wares, buys a very small quantity of jam, much to the woman's displeasure as she had hoped for a larger sale.
The tailor anticipates enjoying the jam on bread but decides to complete his current sewing project, a jacket, before eating.
While he sews, the aroma of the jam attracts a large number of flies, which begin to settle on it.
Initially, the tailor tries to shoo them away, but the flies, undeterred, return in greater numbers.
Losing his patience, the tailor takes a piece of cloth and strikes the swarm of flies.
Upon counting, he discovers he has killed seven flies with this single blow.
Immensely pleased with his own perceived bravery, he declares that the entire town, and indeed the world, must learn of his feat.
He quickly fashions a girdle and embroiders the words 'Seven at one stroke!' onto it in large letters, his heart swelling with pride.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One summer’s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘What, the town!’ he continued, ‘the whole world shall hear of it!’ and his heart wagged with joy like a lamb’s tail.

events.text_segment: One summer’s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might. Then came a peasant woman down the street crying: ‘Good jams, cheap! Good jams, cheap!’ This rang pleasantly in the tailor’s ears; he stretched his delicate head out of the window, and called: ‘Come up here, dear woman; here you will get rid of your goods.’ The woman came up the three steps to the tailor with her heavy basket, and he made her unpack all the pots for him. He inspected each one, lifted it up, put his nose to it, and at length said: ‘The jam seems to me to be good, so weigh me out four ounces, dear woman, and if it is a quarter of a pound that is of no consequence.’ The woman who had hoped to find a good sale, gave him what he desired, but went away quite angry and grumbling. ‘Now, this jam shall be blessed by God,’ cried the little tailor, ‘and give me health and strength’; so he brought the bread out of the cupboard, cut himself a piece right across the loaf and spread the jam over it. ‘This won’t taste bitter,’ said he, ‘but I will just finish the jacket before I take a bite.’ He laid the bread near him, sewed on, and in his joy, made bigger and bigger stitches. In the meantime the smell of the sweet jam rose to where the flies were sitting in great numbers, and they were attracted and descended on it in hosts. ‘Hi! who invited you?’ said the little tailor, and drove the unbidden guests away. The flies, however, who understood no German, would not be turned away, but came back again in ever-increasing companies. The little tailor at last lost all patience, and drew a piece of cloth from the hole under his work-table, and saying: ‘Wait, and I will give it to you,’ struck it mercilessly on them. When he drew it away and counted, there lay before him no fewer than seven, dead and with legs stretched out. ‘Are you a fellow of that sort?’ said he, and could not help admiring his own bravery. ‘The whole town shall know of this!’ And the little tailor hastened to cut himself a girdle, stitched it, and embroidered on it in large letters: ‘Seven at one stroke!’ ‘What, the town!’ he continued, ‘the whole world shall hear of it!’ and his heart wagged with joy like a lamb’s tail.

Suddenly he heard a peasant woman calling in the street below, selling jams and preserves. Curious, the tailor called down to her and asked to see her wares. The woman showed him a small jar of jam, and the tailor, after inspecting it, bought a very small quantity. The woman was displeased, for she had hoped to sell more, but the tailor was content with his purchase. He planned to enjoy the jam on some bread, but first he wanted to finish sewing a jacket he was working on. As he sewed, the sweet aroma of the jam attracted a swarm of flies, which began to settle on it. At first, the tailor tried to shoo them away, but they returned in greater numbers. Losing patience, he took a piece of cloth and struck at the flies, killing seven at one blow. Proud of his feat, he declared that the whole town and the world must know of his bravery. He quickly made a girdle and embroidered on it in large letters: 'Seven at one stroke!,' his heart swelling with pride.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text: One summer’s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might. When he looked, he found that he had killed seven flies at one stroke, their legs stretched out stiff and dead. The tailor was so pleased that he said, "Now the whole world shall know of my deed!" LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
One summer’s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might. Suddenly, he felt a sharp prick on his finger, and looking down, he saw that he had stuck his needle into his thumb. Quickly, he pressed his hand to his mouth and said, “What a fine story I will have to tell!” and with that, he sewed on with renewed vigor. Presently, he finished his work and cut out a piece of cloth, on which he stitched the words “Seven at one blow.” Proud of his accomplishment, he set out into the world to seek his fortune.

As he walked along, he came upon a great forest, where he met a giant who was so large that the tailor felt quite small beside him. The giant challenged the tailor, saying, “Who are you, little man, that dares to enter my forest?” The tailor, undaunted, replied, “I am the man who has slain seven at one blow.” The giant laughed heartily and said, “If that is true, then you must be very strong indeed.”

The tailor then told the giant the story of how he had killed seven flies with one stroke of his hand. The giant, impressed by the tailor’s courage and wit, decided to befriend him. Together, they journeyed through the forest, and the tailor’s cleverness helped them overcome many obstacles.

One day, they came upon a castle where a princess was held captive by a wicked ogre. The giant wanted to fight the ogre, but the tailor had a plan. He told the giant to hide while he would trick the ogre. The tailor went to the ogre’s lair and challenged him to a contest of strength. The ogre laughed and accepted.

The tailor then used his quick thinking to outwit the ogre, tying him up with a rope and freeing the princess. The giant and the tailor returned to the castle, where the king was so grateful that he offered the tailor half his kingdom and the princess’s hand in marriage.

The tailor, humble and wise, accepted the princess but declined the kingdom, choosing instead to live a simple life with his beloved. And so, the little tailor who had slain seven at one blow lived happily ever after, his cleverness and bravery remembered by all.

events.title: The Tailor's Cunning Triumphs Over a Giant's Might
detailed_summary: Wearing his newly embroidered girdle, the tailor decides his workshop is too confining for his newfound valor and resolves to venture into the world.
Before departing, he searches his house for provisions and finds only an old cheese and a bird caught in a thicket, both of which he puts in his pocket.
He travels boldly and without fatigue until he reaches a mountain where a large giant is sitting.
The tailor confidently addresses the giant, proposing they journey together.

The giant initially dismisses the tailor contemptuously, but upon seeing the girdle proclaiming 'Seven at one stroke,' he mistakes this for seven men killed and develops a degree of respect for the small tailor.
Wishing to test him, the giant squeezes a stone until water drips from it and challenges the tailor to do the same.
The tailor nonchalantly pulls out his soft cheese and squeezes it until the whey runs out, claiming it's child's play.
Next, the giant throws a stone so high it's barely visible.
The tailor counters by taking the bird from his pocket and throwing it into the air; the bird flies away, never to return, which the tailor presents as throwing a stone that never comes down.
Impressed, the giant then challenges the tailor to help carry a massive felled oak tree.
The tailor cleverly suggests the giant carry the trunk while he handles the 'heavier' branches and twigs. He then seats himself on a branch, letting the giant unknowingly carry both the tree and him.
When the giant tires and says he must drop the tree, the tailor quickly jumps down and pretends to have been supporting it all along, chiding the giant for his lack of strength.
Continuing together, they reach a cherry tree. The giant bends down a branch laden with ripe fruit for the tailor.
The tailor, too weak to hold the branch, is flung into the air when the giant releases it.
He quickly recovers, claiming he intentionally leaped over the tree because huntsmen were shooting nearby, thereby maintaining his facade of strength and agility before the perplexed giant.

events.text_segment:
The tailor put on the girdle, and resolved to go forth into the world, because he thought his workshop was too small for his valour. Before he went away, he sought about in the house to see if there was anything which he could take with him; however, he found nothing but an old cheese, and that he put in his pocket. In front of the door he observed a bird which had caught itself in the thicket. It had to go into his pocket with the cheese. Now he took to the road boldly, and as he was light and nimble, he felt no fatigue. The road led him up a mountain, and when he had reached the highest point of it, there sat a powerful giant looking peacefully about him. The little tailor went bravely up, spoke to him, and said: ‘Good day, comrade, so you are sitting there overlooking the wide-spread world! I am just on my way thither, and want to try my luck. Have you any inclination to go with me?’ The giant looked contemptuously at the tailor, and said: ‘You ragamuffin! You miserable creature!’
‘Oh, indeed?’ answered the little tailor, and unbuttoned his coat, and showed the giant the girdle, ‘there may you read what kind of a man I am!’ The giant read: ‘Seven at one stroke,’ and thought that they had been men whom the tailor had killed, and began to feel a little respect for the tiny fellow. Nevertheless, he wished to try him first, and took a stone in his hand and squeezed it together so that water dropped out of it. ‘Do that likewise,’ said the giant, ‘if you have strength.’ ‘Is that all?’ said the tailor, ‘that is child’s play with us!’ and put his hand into his pocket, brought out the soft cheese, and pressed it until the liquid ran out of it. ‘Faith,’ said he, ‘that was a little better, wasn’t it?’ The giant did not know what to say, and could not believe it of the little man. Then the giant picked up a stone and threw it so high that the eye could scarcely follow it. ‘Now, little mite of a man, do that likewise,’ ‘Well thrown,’ said the tailor, ‘but after all the stone came down to earth again; I will throw you one which shall never come back at all,’ and he put his hand into his pocket, took out the bird, and threw it into the air. The bird, delighted with its liberty, rose, flew away and did not come back. ‘How does that shot please you, comrade?’ asked the tailor. ‘You can certainly throw,’ said the giant, ‘but now we will see if you are able to carry anything properly.’ He took the little tailor to a mighty oak tree which lay there felled on the ground, and said: ‘If you are strong enough, help me to carry the tree out of the forest.’ ‘Readily,’ answered the little man; ‘take you the trunk on your shoulders, and I will raise up the branches and twigs; after all, they are the heaviest.’ The giant took the trunk on his shoulder, but the tailor seated himself on a branch, and the giant, who could not look round, had to carry away the whole tree, and the little tailor into the bargain: he behind, was quite merry and happy, and whistled the song: ‘Three tailors rode forth from the gate,’ as if carrying the tree were child’s play. The giant, after he had dragged the heavy burden part of the way, could go no further, and cried: ‘Hark you, I shall have to let the tree fall!’ The tailor sprang nimbly down, seized the tree with both arms as if he had been carrying it, and said to the giant: ‘You are such a great fellow, and yet cannot even carry the tree!’
They went on together, and as they passed a cherry-tree, the giant laid hold of the top of the tree where the ripest fruit was hanging, bent it down, gave it into the tailor’s hand, and bade him eat. But the little tailor was much too weak to hold the tree, and when the giant let it go, it sprang back again, and the tailor was tossed into the air with it. When he had fallen down again without injury, the giant said: ‘What is this? Have you not strength enough to hold the weak twig?’ ‘There is no lack of strength,’ answered the little tailor. ‘Do you think that could be anything to a man who has struck down seven at one blow? I leapt over the tree because the huntsmen are shooting down there in the thicket. Jump as I did, if you can do it.’ The giant made the attempt but he could not get over the tree, and remained hanging in the branches, so that in this also the tailor kept the upper hand.

events.title: A Night in the Giants' Cave and a Narrow Escape
detailed_summary: The giant, perhaps still partly convinced of the tailor's prowess, invites him to spend the night in the giants' cave.
The tailor agrees and follows him, observing that the cave, inhabited by other giants eating roasted sheep, is much larger than his workshop.
The giant directs him to a bed, but it is far too large for the tailor, who opts to sleep in a corner instead of lying in it.
Around midnight, the giant, believing the tailor is fast asleep in the bed, gets up and smashes the bed with a great iron bar, intending to kill the 'grasshopper'.
The following morning, as the giants prepare to go into the forest, having forgotten about the tailor, he suddenly appears before them, cheerful and bold.
The giants are utterly terrified, convinced he will kill them all, and they flee in a great hurry.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The giant said: ‘If you are such a valiant fellow, come with me into our cavern and spend the night with us.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The giants were terrified, they were afraid that he would strike them all dead, and ran away in a great hurry.

events.text_segment: The giant said: ‘If you are such a valiant fellow, come with me into our cavern and spend the night with us.’ The little tailor was willing, and followed him. When they went into the cave, other giants were sitting there by the fire, and each of them had a roasted sheep in his hand and was eating it. The little tailor looked round and thought: ‘It is much more spacious here than in my workshop.’ The giant showed him a bed, and said he was to lie down in it and sleep. The bed, however, was too big for the little tailor; he did not lie down in it, but crept into a corner. When it was midnight, and the giant thought that the little tailor was lying in a sound sleep, he got up, took a great iron bar, cut through the bed with one blow, and thought he had finished off the grasshopper for good. With the earliest dawn the giants went into the forest, and had quite forgotten the little tailor, when all at once he walked up to them quite merrily and boldly. The giants were terrified, they were afraid that he would strike them all dead, and ran away in a great hurry.

events.title: A Warrior's Reputation Precedes Him: The Tailor Enters Royal Service
detailed_summary: The little tailor continues his journey, eventually arriving at the courtyard of a royal palace.
Feeling weary, he lies down on the grass and falls asleep.
While he sleeps, people from the palace gather and inspect him, noticing the inscription 'Seven at one stroke' on his girdle.
Interpreting this as a sign of a great warrior, they wonder about his presence in a time of peace and conclude he must be a mighty lord.
They report their findings to the king, suggesting that such a man would be invaluable if war were to break out and should not be allowed to leave.
The king is pleased with this counsel and dispatches one of his courtiers to offer the tailor military service when he awakens.
The courtier waits by the sleeping tailor, and upon the tailor waking and stretching, conveys the king's proposal.
The tailor replies that this was precisely his reason for coming and readily accepts the offer to enter the king's service.
Consequently, he is received with honor and assigned a special dwelling.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The little tailor went onwards, always following his own pointed nose.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was therefore honourably received, and a special dwelling was assigned him.

events.text_segment: The little tailor went onwards, always following his own pointed nose. After he had walked for a long time, he came to the courtyard of a royal palace, and as he felt weary, he lay down on the grass and fell asleep. Whilst he lay there, the people came and inspected him on all sides, and read on his girdle: ‘Seven at one stroke.’ ‘Ah!’ said they, ‘what does the great warrior want here in the midst of peace? He must be a mighty lord.’ They went and announced him to the king, and gave it as their opinion that if war should break out, this would be a weighty and useful man who ought on no account to be allowed to depart. The counsel pleased the king, and he sent one of his courtiers to the little tailor to offer him military service when he awoke. The ambassador remained standing by the sleeper, waited until he stretched his limbs and opened his eyes, and then conveyed to him this proposal. ‘For this very reason have I come here,’ the tailor replied, ‘I am ready to enter the king’s service.’ He was therefore honourably received, and a special dwelling was assigned him.

events.title: Envy, a Royal Dilemma, and the Task of Two Giants
detailed_summary: The king's soldiers quickly grow resentful of the little tailor, fearing his supposed ability to kill seven at a blow and feeling unable to stand against him if a quarrel arose.
They collectively approach the king and request their dismissal, stating they are unprepared to serve alongside such a formidable individual.
The king is dismayed at the thought of losing all his loyal servants for one man and regrets having encountered the tailor, wishing to be rid of him.
However, he dares not dismiss the tailor directly, fearing the tailor might kill him and his people and seize the throne.
After much thought, the king devises a plan. He summons the tailor and, acknowledging him as a great warrior, requests a service: to deal with two giants who cause immense destruction in a forest.
The king promises his only daughter in marriage and half his kingdom as a dowry if the tailor succeeds, also offering one hundred horsemen for assistance.
The tailor, seeing this as a magnificent opportunity, confidently accepts, boasting that he who can hit seven at one blow needs no help against two.
He sets off with the horsemen but tells them to wait at the forest's edge, claiming he will handle the giants alone.
Inside the forest, he finds both giants asleep under a tree, snoring loudly.
The tailor, having gathered two pockets full of stones, climbs the tree and positions himself above the sleeping giants.
He drops stones onto the chest of one giant, who awakens and accuses his companion of hitting him; the other denies it, and they go back to sleep.
The tailor then drops a stone on the second giant, who also wakes up and accuses the first of pelting him, leading to a dispute before they fall asleep again from weariness.
Finally, the tailor hurls his largest stone with all his might onto the chest of the first giant.
This giant springs up enraged and attacks his companion, and the two giants engage in a furious battle, tearing up trees and fighting until they both fall dead.
The tailor then descends, stabs each giant a few times with his sword, and returns to the horsemen, claiming a hard-fought victory where the giants defended themselves fiercely with uprooted trees.
When asked if he is wounded, he dismisses the concern. The skeptical horsemen ride into the forest and find the giants dead, surrounded by torn-up trees, seemingly confirming the tailor's story.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The soldiers, however, were set against the little tailor, and wished him a thousand miles away.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The horsemen would not believe him, and rode into the forest; there they found the giants swimming in their blood, and all round about lay the torn-up trees.

events.text_segment:
The soldiers, however, were set against the little tailor, and wished him a thousand miles away. ‘What is to be the end of this?’ they said among themselves. ‘If we quarrel with him, and he strikes about him, seven of us will fall at every blow; not one of us can stand against him.’ They came therefore to a decision, betook themselves in a body to the king, and begged for their dismissal. ‘We are not prepared,’ said they, ‘to stay with a man who kills seven at one stroke.’ The king was sorry that for the sake of one he should lose all his faithful servants, wished that he had never set eyes on the tailor, and would willingly have been rid of him again. But he did not venture to give him his dismissal, for he dreaded lest he should strike him and all his people dead, and place himself on the royal throne. He thought about it for a long time, and at last found good counsel. He sent to the little tailor and caused him to be informed that as he was a great warrior, he had one request to make to him. In a forest of his country lived two giants, who caused great mischief with their robbing, murdering, ravaging, and burning, and no one could approach them without putting himself in danger of death. If the tailor conquered and killed these two giants, he would give him his only daughter to wife, and half of his kingdom as a dowry, likewise one hundred horsemen should go with him to assist him. ‘That would indeed be a fine thing for a man like me!’ thought the little tailor. ‘One is not offered a beautiful princess and half a kingdom every day of one’s life!’ ‘Oh, yes,’ he replied, ‘I will soon subdue the giants, and do not require the help of the hundred horsemen to do it; he who can hit seven with one blow has no need to be afraid of two.’
The little tailor went forth, and the hundred horsemen followed him. When he came to the outskirts of the forest, he said to his followers: ‘Just stay waiting here, I alone will soon finish off the giants.’ Then he bounded into the forest and looked about right and left. After a while he perceived both giants. They lay sleeping under a tree, and snored so that the branches waved up and down. The little tailor, not idle, gathered two pocketsful of stones, and with these climbed up the tree. When he was halfway up, he slipped down by a branch, until he sat just above the sleepers, and then let one stone after another fall on the breast of one of the giants. For a long time the giant felt nothing, but at last he awoke, pushed his comrade, and said: ‘Why are you knocking me?’ ‘You must be dreaming,’ said the other, ‘I am not knocking you.’ They laid themselves down to sleep again, and then the tailor threw a stone down on the second. ‘What is the meaning of this?’ cried the other ‘Why are you pelting me?’ ‘I am not pelting you,’ answered the first, growling. They disputed about it for a time, but as they were weary they let the matter rest, and their eyes closed once more. The little tailor began his game again, picked out the biggest stone, and threw it with all his might on the breast of the first giant. ‘That is too bad!’ cried he, and sprang up like a madman, and pushed his companion against the tree until it shook. The other paid him back in the same coin, and they got into such a rage that they tore up trees and belaboured each other so long, that at last they both fell down dead on the ground at the same time. Then the little tailor leapt down. ‘It is a lucky thing,’ said he, ‘that they did not tear up the tree on which I was sitting, or I should have had to sprint on to another like a squirrel; but we tailors are nimble.’ He drew out his sword and gave each of them a couple of thrusts in the breast, and then went out to the horsemen and said: ‘The work is done; I have finished both of them off, but it was hard work! They tore up trees in their sore need, and defended themselves with them, but all that is to no purpose when a man like myself comes, who can kill seven at one blow.’ ‘But are you not wounded?’ asked the horsemen. ‘You need not concern yourself about that,’ answered the tailor, ‘they have not bent one hair of mine.’ The horsemen would not believe him, and rode into the forest; there they found the giants swimming in their blood, and all round about lay the torn-up trees.

One day, as he journeyed through a dense forest, he came upon a great castle surrounded by a moat. The drawbridge was up, and the gates were closed tight. But the little tailor was not one to be stopped by mere obstacles. He looked around and found a small boat hidden among the reeds. Quietly, he slipped into the boat and rowed across the moat.

Inside the castle, he found a grand hall where a beautiful princess sat weeping. She told him that a terrible dragon had taken her captive and that no one had been brave enough to rescue her. The little tailor, with a twinkle in his eye, promised to save her.

The little tailor crept inside and, using his needle and thread, sewed the dragon's mouth shut. The dragon awoke, unable to breathe or roar, and fled into the night, never to trouble the kingdom again.

But the little tailor, humble and content, declined the riches and the royal match. Instead, he asked only for a small shop where he could continue his craft.

And so, the little tailor returned home, his name known far and wide, not just as a tailor, but as a hero whose courage and cleverness had saved a kingdom.

events.title: The King's Reluctance: Capturing a Unicorn and a Wild Boar
detailed_summary: The tailor requests his promised reward from the king, but the king, regretting his pledge, devises another task for the 'hero'.
He tells the tailor that before receiving his daughter and half the kingdom, he must capture a destructive unicorn roaming the forest.
The tailor, undaunted, states he fears a unicorn even less than two giants, as 'Seven at one blow' is his specialty.
Taking a rope and an axe, he ventures into the forest, again instructing his escorts to wait outside.
He soon encounters the unicorn, which charges directly at him.
The tailor calmly waits until the unicorn is close, then nimbly springs behind a tree.
The unicorn, unable to stop, impales the tree with its horn, becoming stuck.
The tailor declares he has 'got the bird,' emerges, puts the rope around the unicorn's neck, hews its horn from the tree with his axe, and leads the captured beast to the king.
Still reluctant, the king makes a third demand: the tailor must catch a wild boar causing great havoc in the forest, with the assistance of royal huntsmen.
The tailor agrees, calling it 'child's play,' and again declines the huntsmen's help, much to their relief as they had previous unpleasant encounters with the boar.
When the boar spots the tailor, it charges with foaming mouth and whetted tusks.
The tailor flees into a nearby chapel, jumps up to a window, and leaps out.
The boar rushes into the chapel after him, whereupon the tailor quickly runs around the outside and shuts the door, trapping the enraged beast, which is too heavy to escape through the window.
He then summons the huntsmen to witness the captured boar.
The king, now with no further recourse, is compelled to honor his promise, giving the tailor his daughter and half the kingdom.
The narrative notes that had the king known he was dealing with a mere tailor rather than a warrior, his dismay would have been even greater.
A magnificent wedding is held, though with little joy, and thus, a tailor is made into a king.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The little tailor demanded of the king the promised reward; he, however, repented of his promise, and again bethought himself how he could get rid of the hero.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The wedding was held with great magnificence and small joy, and out of a tailor a king was made.

events.text_segment:
The little tailor demanded of the king the promised reward; he, however, repented of his promise, and again bethought himself how he could get rid of the hero. ‘Before you receive my daughter, and the half of my kingdom,’ said he to him, ‘you must perform one more heroic deed. In the forest roams a unicorn which does great harm, and you must catch it first.’ ‘I fear one unicorn still less than two giants. Seven at one blow, is my kind of affair.’ He took a rope and an axe with him, went forth into the forest, and again bade those who were sent with him to wait outside. He had not long to seek. The unicorn soon came towards him, and rushed directly on the tailor, as if it would gore him with its horn without more ado. ‘Softly, softly; it can’t be done as quickly as that,’ said he, and stood still and waited until the animal was quite close, and then sprang nimbly behind the tree. The unicorn ran against the tree with all its strength, and stuck its horn so fast in the trunk that it had not the strength enough to draw it out again, and thus it was caught. ‘Now, I have got the bird,’ said the tailor, and came out from behind the tree and put the rope round its neck, and then with his axe he hewed the horn out of the tree, and when all was ready he led the beast away and took it to the king.
The king still would not give him the promised reward, and made a third demand. Before the wedding the tailor was to catch him a wild boar that made great havoc in the forest, and the huntsmen should give him their help. ‘Willingly,’ said the tailor, ‘that is child’s play!’ He did not take the huntsmen with him into the forest, and they were well pleased that he did not, for the wild boar had several times received them in such a manner that they had no inclination to lie in wait for him. When the boar perceived the tailor, it ran on him with foaming mouth and whetted tusks, and was about to throw him to the ground, but the hero fled and sprang into a chapel which was near and up to the window at once, and in one bound out again. The boar ran after him, but the tailor ran round outside and shut the door behind it, and then the raging beast, which was much too heavy and awkward to leap out of the window, was caught. The little tailor called the huntsmen thither that they might see the prisoner with their own eyes. The hero, however, went to the king, who was now, whether he liked it or not, obliged to keep his promise, and gave his daughter and the half of his kingdom. Had he known that it was no warlike hero, but a little tailor who was standing before him, it would have gone to his heart still more than it did. The wedding was held with great magnificence and small joy, and out of a tailor a king was made.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The little tailor demanded of the king the promised reward; he, however, repented of his promise, and again bethought himself how he could get rid of the hero. The king sent him out into the forest, saying, "If you can bring me the heads of two wild giants who live there, I will give you my daughter and half my kingdom." The little tailor set out at once, and soon came to the giants' dwelling. He found the giants asleep, and with great courage he crept up and cut off their heads. Then he carried them to the king, who was amazed and could not believe his eyes. But the little tailor told him the whole story, and the king was forced to keep his word.

The king, however, was still uneasy, and thought to send the little tailor on another dangerous errand. He said, "If you can bring me the wild boar that ravages my lands, I will give you my daughter and half my kingdom." The little tailor agreed, and set out to find the boar. He tracked it to a deep forest, where he found the beast asleep. Using his cunning, he trapped the boar and brought it back to the king. Once more, the king was amazed and had to keep his promise.

But the king's heart was still full of envy and fear. He thought, "If this little tailor marries my daughter and becomes my equal, I shall be disgraced." So he devised a final plan to rid himself of the tailor. He said, "If you can climb the glass mountain and bring me the golden bird that sits atop it, I will give you my daughter and half my kingdom." The little tailor accepted the challenge and set out.

When he reached the glass mountain, he found it impossible to climb. The surface was so smooth that he could not get a foothold. He sat down to think, and soon a little old woman appeared. She said, "I can help you, but you must promise to give me the golden bird when you have it." The tailor agreed, and the old woman gave him a ball of yarn. He threw it up the mountain, and it stuck fast. Then he climbed the yarn and reached the top, where the golden bird was perched.

He caught the bird and began to descend, but the yarn broke, and he fell to the bottom. The old woman appeared again and helped him up. He tried again, and this time he succeeded in bringing the golden bird down safely. He gave the bird to the old woman, who vanished.

The little tailor returned to the king with the golden bird. The king was astonished and had to keep his promise. The tailor married the princess, and they lived happily ever after. The king learned to respect the little tailor's courage and wit, and the kingdom prospered under their rule.

events.title: The Tailor King Outwits a Royal Plot and Secures His Reign
detailed_summary: Some time later, the young queen overhears her husband, the tailor-king, muttering in his sleep about tailoring tasks like making doublets and patching pantaloons.
From this, she deduces his humble origins and feels wronged.
The next morning, she complains to her father, the old king, and begs him to help her get rid of her husband, whom she now knows is merely a tailor.

The old king comforts her and outlines a plan: she is to leave her bedroom door open that night. His servants will wait outside, and once the tailor-king is asleep, they will enter, bind him, and transport him onto a ship to be carried far away.
The queen is satisfied with this arrangement.
However, the king's armour-bearer, who is friendly towards the young tailor-king, overhears the entire plot and informs him.
The tailor-king declares he will foil their plan.
That night, he goes to bed with his wife as usual. When she believes he has fallen asleep, she gets up, opens the bedroom door, and lies down again.
The tailor-king, who was only feigning sleep, begins to shout loudly and clearly, as if talking in his sleep or addressing unseen listeners.

He recounts his great feats: 'I smote seven at one blow. I killed two giants, I brought away one unicorn, and caught a wild boar,' and then rhetorically asks if he should now fear those standing outside his room.
The servants waiting outside, upon hearing the tailor-king's booming recitation of his supposed heroic deeds, are overcome with terror.
They flee as if pursued by a demonic hunter, and none dare to make any further attempt against him.
Thus, the little tailor successfully thwarts the plot and solidifies his position, remaining a king for the rest of his life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After some time the young queen heard her husband say in his dreams at night: ‘Boy, make me the doublet, and patch the pantaloons, or else I will rap the yard-measure over your ears.’

events.text_segment: After some time the young queen heard her husband say in his dreams at night: ‘Boy, make me the doublet, and patch the pantaloons, or else I will rap the yard-measure over your ears.’ Then she discovered in what state of life the young lord had been born, and next morning complained of her wrongs to her father, and begged him to help her to get rid of her husband, who was nothing else but a tailor. The king comforted her and said: ‘Leave your bedroom door open this night, and my servants shall stand outside, and when he has fallen asleep shall go in, bind him, and take him on board a ship which shall carry him into the wide world.’ The woman was satisfied with this; but the king’s armour-bearer, who had heard all, was friendly with the young lord, and informed him of the whole plot. ‘I’ll put a screw into that business,’ said the little tailor. At night he went to bed with his wife at the usual time, and when she thought that he had fallen asleep, she got up, opened the door, and then lay down again. The little tailor, who was only pretending to be asleep, began to cry out in a clear voice: ‘Boy, make me the doublet and patch me the pantaloons, or I will rap the yard-measure over your ears. I smote seven at one blow. I killed two giants, I brought away one unicorn, and caught a wild boar, and am I to fear those who are standing outside the room.’ When these men heard the tailor speaking thus, they were overcome by a great dread, and ran as if the wild huntsman were behind them, and none of them would venture anything further against him. So the little tailor was and remained a king to the end of his life.

The boy, who was the queen's own son, was very much frightened when he heard these words, and he thought to himself: 'If I do not do as the king commands, he will surely beat me.' This went on for many nights, and the boy grew weary and sorrowful.

One day, the queen, who loved her son dearly, said to him: 'My child, why do you look so sad and troubled?' The boy told her all that he had heard and how the king threatened him in his dreams. The queen pondered deeply and decided to seek the counsel of a wise old woman who lived in the forest.

The old woman listened to the queen's tale and said: 'The king is under a spell, and only a brave deed can break it. You must find the enchanted yard-measure and destroy it, or else the king will never be free from his torment.'

Determined to save her husband, the queen set out on a perilous journey through dark woods and over high mountains. After many trials, she found the enchanted yard-measure guarded by a fierce dragon. With courage and wit, she managed to seize the yard-measure and break it into pieces.

That very night, the king slept peacefully, and the boy heard no more threats. The spell was broken, and the family lived happily ever after.

events.title: The Parents' Desperate Plan to Abandon the Children
detailed_summary: A poor wood-cutter and his wife, living near a large forest, faced severe famine and struggled to provide even basic sustenance for themselves and their two children, Hansel and Gretel.
One night, consumed by worry, the wood-cutter lamented to his wife about their inability to feed the children.

The wife suggested a grim plan: to lead the children into the densest part of the forest the next morning, provide them with a last piece of bread and a fire, then abandon them at their work, ensuring they could not return.
The wood-cutter was initially aghast, expressing fear that wild animals would kill the children if left alone.

events.text_segment: Hard by a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children. The boy was called Hansel and the girl Gretel. He had little to bite and to break, and once when great dearth fell on the land, he could no longer procure even daily bread. Now when he thought over this by night in his bed, and tossed about in his anxiety, he groaned and said to his wife: ‘What is to become of us? How are we to feed our poor children, when we no longer have anything even for ourselves?’ ‘I’ll tell you what, husband,’ answered the woman, ‘early tomorrow morning we will take the children out into the forest to where it is the thickest; there we will light a fire for them, and give each of them one more piece of bread, and then we will go to our work and leave them alone. They will not find the way home again, and we shall be rid of them.’ ‘No, wife,’ said the man, ‘I will not do that; how can I bear to leave my children alone in the forest?—the wild animals would soon come and tear them to pieces.’ ‘O, you fool!’ said she, ‘then we must all four die of hunger, you may as well plane the planks for our coffins,’ and she left him no peace until he consented. ‘But I feel very sorry for the poor children, all the same,’ said the man.

Hard by a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children. The family lived in a small, humble cottage at the edge of the woods, where the father would go each day to chop wood and gather what he could to provide for his loved ones. Despite their poverty, the family was content and kind-hearted, always helping neighbors and sharing what little they had.

One day, as the wood-cutter was felling a tree deep in the forest, he heard a faint cry. Following the sound, he discovered a tiny, golden-haired child sitting beneath a tree, weeping. The child told him she was lost and could not find her way home. Moved by her plight, the wood-cutter took her back to his cottage, where his wife and children welcomed her warmly.

As days passed, the mysterious child revealed she was a fairy princess, enchanted and hidden away by a wicked sorcerer. Grateful for the family's kindness, she promised to grant them a wish. The wood-cutter and his wife wished for prosperity and happiness for their children.

The fairy princess waved her hand, and from that day forth, the family's fortunes changed. Their cottage grew into a beautiful home, their fields yielded abundant harvests, and their children thrived. The wood-cutter never forgot the magic of kindness and the blessings it brought to his humble family.

events.title: Hansel's Pebble Trail and the First Forest Journey
detailed_summary: Unable to sleep due to hunger, Hansel and Gretel overheard their stepmother detailing the abandonment plan to their father.
Gretel was overcome with despair, crying bitterly, but Hansel urged her to be calm, assuring her he would devise a way to save them.
After their parents fell asleep, Hansel slipped outside, where the bright moonlight illuminated white pebbles in front of their house.
He gathered as many pebbles as he could fit into his coat pocket.
Returning to Gretel, he comforted her, telling her to trust in God, and then went back to bed.
At dawn, before sunrise, the stepmother woke the children, announcing their trip to the forest to gather wood.
She gave each child a small piece of bread for dinner, warning them not to eat it beforehand.
Gretel hid her bread under her apron, while Hansel had his pebbles.
As they walked, Hansel repeatedly paused to look back, explaining to his concerned father that he was bidding farewell to his white cat on the roof.
The stepmother chided him, saying it was merely the morning sun on the chimney, unaware that Hansel was actually dropping pebbles to mark their path.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The two children had also not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their stepmother had said to their father.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Hansel, however, had not been looking back at the cat, but had been constantly throwing one of the white pebble-stones out of his pocket on the road.

events.text_segment: The two children had also not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their stepmother had said to their father. Gretel wept bitter tears, and said to Hansel: ‘Now all is over with us.’ ‘Be quiet, Gretel,’ said Hansel, ‘do not distress yourself, I will soon find a way to help us.’ And when the old folks had fallen asleep, he got up, put on his little coat, opened the door below, and crept outside. The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay in front of the house glittered like real silver pennies. Hansel stooped and stuffed the little pocket of his coat with as many as he could get in. Then he went back and said to Gretel: ‘Be comforted, dear little sister, and sleep in peace, God will not forsake us,’ and he lay down again in his bed. When day dawned, but before the sun had risen, the woman came and awoke the two children, saying: ‘Get up, you sluggards! we are going into the forest to fetch wood.’ She gave each a little piece of bread, and said: ‘There is something for your dinner, but do not eat it up before then, for you will get nothing else.’ Gretel took the bread under her apron, as Hansel had the pebbles in his pocket. Then they all set out together on the way to the forest. When they had walked a short time, Hansel stood still and peeped back at the house, and did so again and again. His father said: ‘Hansel, what are you looking at there and staying behind for? Pay attention, and do not forget how to use your legs.’ ‘Ah, father,’ said Hansel, ‘I am looking at my little white cat, which is sitting up on the roof, and wants to say goodbye to me.’ The wife said: ‘Fool, that is not your little cat, that is the morning sun which is shining on the chimneys.’ Hansel, however, had not been looking back at the cat, but had been constantly throwing one of the white pebble-stones out of his pocket on the road.

events.title: Abandonment in the Forest and Miraculous Return Home
detailed_summary: Upon reaching a central part of the forest, the father instructed the children to gather wood for a fire to keep warm.
Hansel and Gretel piled up brushwood, which was then lit.
When the fire was blazing, the stepmother told the children to rest by it while she and the father went to cut wood, promising to return for them.
Hansel and Gretel ate their bread at noon, hearing what they believed to be their father's axe but was actually a branch moved by the wind.
Fatigued, they fell deeply asleep and awoke to find it was dark night.
Gretel cried in fear, but Hansel reassured her, suggesting they wait for the moon to rise to find their way.
Once the full moon appeared, Hansel led Gretel by the hand, following the trail of shining pebbles back home.
They walked throughout the night, reaching their father’s house by daybreak.
When they knocked, the stepmother answered, feigning annoyance at their long absence, while their father was secretly overjoyed, as abandoning them had pained him deeply.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: ‘Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.

events.text_segment:
When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: ‘Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold.’ Hansel and Gretel gathered brushwood together, as high as a little hill. The brushwood was lighted, and when the flames were burning very high, the woman said: ‘Now, children, lay yourselves down by the fire and rest, we will go into the forest and cut some wood. When we have done, we will come back and fetch you away.’
Hansel and Gretel sat by the fire, and when noon came, each ate a little piece of bread, and as they heard the strokes of the wood-axe they believed that their father was near. It was not the axe, however, but a branch which he had fastened to a withered tree which the wind was blowing backwards and forwards. And as they had been sitting such a long time, their eyes closed with fatigue, and they fell fast asleep. When at last they awoke, it was already dark night. Gretel began to cry and said: ‘How are we to get out of the forest now?’ But Hansel comforted her and said: ‘Just wait a little, until the moon has risen, and then we will soon find the way.’ And when the full moon had risen, Hansel took his little sister by the hand, and followed the pebbles which shone like newly-coined silver pieces, and showed them the way.
They walked the whole night long, and by break of day came once more to their father’s house. They knocked at the door, and when the woman opened it and saw that it was Hansel and Gretel, she said: ‘You naughty children, why have you slept so long in the forest?—we thought you were never coming back at all!’ The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.

But the only noise they heard was the rustling of a branch in the wind. Tired, they fell into a deep sleep and awoke to find that night had fallen. Gretel wept in fear, but Hansel comforted her, saying: ‘Wait until the moon rises; then we can find our way home.’ When the full moon shone bright, Hansel took Gretel by the hand and led her along the path, following the trail of shining pebbles he had dropped earlier. They walked all through the night and reached their father's house at dawn. When they knocked, the stepmother answered, feigning annoyance at their long absence, but their father was secretly overjoyed, for abandoning his children had grieved him deeply.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: ‘Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold.’ The children gathered sticks and branches, stacking them carefully while the father struck a flint and soon a bright flame flickered to life. As the fire crackled and warmed them, the father told them to rest while he went to find some food. The children sat close together, watching the dancing flames and listening to the sounds of the forest around them.

Suddenly, a strange old woman appeared from behind the trees. She was bent and wrinkled, with eyes that gleamed like stars. ‘Good evening, children,’ she said in a voice as soft as the wind. ‘What brings you so deep into the forest at this hour?’

The children told her of their journey and their father’s plan to find food. The old woman smiled kindly and said, ‘I know where you can find berries and nuts to eat. Follow me.’

They followed her through the woods until they came to a clearing filled with bushes heavy with ripe berries and trees laden with nuts. The children gathered as much as they could carry, thanking the old woman for her kindness.

As they returned to the fire, the father came back with a small hare he had caught. Together, they cooked the hare and shared the berries and nuts, feeling grateful for the unexpected help they had received. The fire kept them warm through the night, and the forest no longer seemed so dark and frightening. They knew that as long as they stuck together and helped one another, they could face any challenge the forest might bring.

events.title: Renewed Famine and the Stepmother's Second Cruel Plan
detailed_summary: Another period of severe famine struck, and the children overheard their stepmother telling their father that, with only half a loaf of bread left, they must abandon the children again, this time deeper in the woods to prevent their return.
The father felt conflicted, believing he should share their last food with the children.
However, the stepmother was unyielding, scolding and reproaching him until he agreed, having yielded once before.
Hansel and Gretel, still awake, heard the entire discussion.
Once their parents were asleep, Hansel tried to go outside to collect pebbles as before, but found the door locked by the stepmother.
Despite this setback, he comforted Gretel, urging her not to cry and to trust that God would help them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Not long afterwards, there was once more great dearth throughout the land, and the children heard their mother saying at night to their father: ‘Everything is eaten again, we have one half loaf left, and that is the end. The children must go, we will take them farther into the wood, so that they will not find their way out again; there is no other means of saving ourselves!’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Nevertheless he comforted his little sister, and said: ‘Do not cry, Gretel, go to sleep quietly, the good God will help us.’

events.text_segment:
Not long afterwards, there was once more great dearth throughout the land, and the children heard their mother saying at night to their father: ‘Everything is eaten again, we have one half loaf left, and that is the end. The children must go, we will take them farther into the wood, so that they will not find their way out again; there is no other means of saving ourselves!’ The man’s heart was heavy, and he thought: ‘It would be better for you to share the last mouthful with your children.’ The woman, however, would listen to nothing that he had to say, but scolded and reproached him. He who says A must say B, likewise, and as he had yielded the first time, he had to do so a second time also.
The children, however, were still awake and had heard the conversation. When the old folks were asleep, Hansel again got up, and wanted to go out and pick up pebbles as he had done before, but the woman had locked the door, and Hansel could not get out. Nevertheless he comforted his little sister, and said: ‘Do not cry, Gretel, go to sleep quietly, the good God will help us.’

events.title: The Breadcrumb Trail and Deeper Abandonment
detailed_summary: Early the next morning, the stepmother woke the children and gave them pieces of bread, even smaller than before.
As they journeyed into the forest, Hansel crumbled his bread in his pocket, frequently stopping to drop morsels on the ground.
When questioned by his father, Hansel claimed he was looking back at his pigeon on the roof saying goodbye.
The stepmother dismissed this as foolishness, stating it was only the morning sun on the chimney.
Hansel continued to surreptitiously leave a trail of breadcrumbs.
The stepmother led them much deeper into the forest, to a place they had never visited.
She had them make a large fire and told them to rest or sleep, promising she and the father would return in the evening after cutting wood.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Early in the morning came the woman, and took the children out of their beds.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then a great fire was again made, and the mother said: ‘Just sit there, you children, and when you are tired you may sleep a little; we are going into the forest to cut wood, and in the evening when we are done, we will come and fetch you away.’

events.text_segment:
Early in the morning came the woman, and took the children out of their beds. Their piece of bread was given to them, but it was still smaller than the time before. On the way into the forest Hansel crumbled his in his pocket, and often stood still and threw a morsel on the ground. ‘Hansel, why do you stop and look round?’ said the father, ‘go on.’ ‘I am looking back at my little pigeon which is sitting on the roof, and wants to say goodbye to me,’ answered Hansel. ‘Fool!’ said the woman, ‘that is not your little pigeon, that is the morning sun that is shining on the chimney.’ Hansel, however little by little, threw all the crumbs on the path.
The woman led the children still deeper into the forest, where they had never in their lives been before. Then a great fire was again made, and the mother said: ‘Just sit there, you children, and when you are tired you may sleep a little; we are going into the forest to cut wood, and in the evening when we are done, we will come and fetch you away.’

That is only the morning sun shining on the chimney." They walked on and on, deeper into the forest than they had ever been before. At last, the woman said, "Here we will rest," and made a great fire. "You may lie down and sleep," she said, "and we will come back for you when we have cut wood."

events.title: Lost and Hopeless: The Eaten Breadcrumbs
detailed_summary: At noon, Gretel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, as he had used his for the trail.
They subsequently fell asleep, and evening arrived without anyone coming for them.
They awoke in complete darkness. Hansel tried to comfort a despairing Gretel, telling her to wait for the moonrise, when they would be able to see the breadcrumbs he had left to guide them home.
When the moon appeared, they set out but could not find any crumbs, as the numerous birds of the forest and fields had consumed them all.
Hansel tried to remain optimistic, saying they would find their way, but they did not.
They wandered through the entire night and the following day, from morning until evening, without escaping the forest, growing extremely hungry with only a few berries to eat.
Exhausted to the point where they could no longer walk, they collapsed under a tree and fell asleep.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When it was noon, Gretel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, who had scattered his by the way.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a tree and fell asleep.

events.text_segment: When it was noon, Gretel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, who had scattered his by the way. Then they fell asleep and evening passed, but no one came to the poor children. They did not awake until it was dark night, and Hansel comforted his little sister and said: ‘Just wait, Gretel, until the moon rises, and then we shall see the crumbs of bread which I have strewn about, they will show us our way home again.’ When the moon came they set out, but they found no crumbs, for the many thousands of birds which fly about in the woods and fields had picked them all up. Hansel said to Gretel: ‘We shall soon find the way,’ but they did not find it. They walked the whole night and all the next day too from morning till evening, but they did not get out of the forest, and were very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but two or three berries, which grew on the ground. And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a tree and fell asleep.

Then they lay down and fell asleep, and evening came, but no one came for them. When they awoke, it was quite dark. Hansel comforted his sister, saying, "Wait until the moon rises, then you will see the crumbs I have left behind to guide us home." When the moon rose, they set out, but the crumbs were gone; the birds of the forest and fields had eaten them all. Hansel tried to keep up their spirits, saying, "We will find our way home somehow," but they wandered all night and the next day, from morning until evening, without escaping the forest. They grew very hungry, eating only a few berries they found. At last, so tired they could walk no more, they lay down under a tree and fell asleep.

events.title: The Luring Gingerbread House and Deceptive Welcome
detailed_summary: Three mornings after leaving home, still lost and increasingly desperate, the children resumed walking deeper into the forest.
At midday, they encountered a beautiful snow-white bird singing enchantingly from a branch; they paused to listen.
After its song, the bird flew ahead, and they followed it until it landed on the roof of a small house.
Approaching, they saw the house was constructed from bread, roofed with cakes, and had windows of clear sugar.
Hansel proposed they eat parts of the house for a meal; he decided to try the roof, while Gretel aimed for a sweet window.
As Hansel broke off a piece of the roof and Gretel nibbled at a windowpane, a soft voice from inside asked who was damaging the house.
The children, unfazed, replied it was the wind and continued eating.
Hansel tore off a large piece of the roof, and Gretel pushed out an entire windowpane to enjoy.
Suddenly, the door opened, and an ancient woman, supporting herself with crutches, emerged.
Terrified, Hansel and Gretel dropped their food, but the old woman, nodding, kindly invited them inside, promising no harm would come to them.

She led them into her house, served them a delicious meal of milk, pancakes, sugar, apples, and nuts, and then prepared two comfortable beds with clean white linen, where the children lay down, feeling as if they were in paradise.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Afterwards two pretty little beds were covered with clean white linen, and Hansel and Gretel lay down in them, and thought they were in heaven.

events.text_segment:
It was now three mornings since they had left their father’s house. They began to walk again, but they always came deeper into the forest, and if help did not come soon, they must die of hunger and weariness. When it was mid-day, they saw a beautiful snow-white bird sitting on a bough, which sang so delightfully that they stood still and listened to it. And when its song was over, it spread its wings and flew away before them, and they followed it until they reached a little house, on the roof of which it alighted; and when they approached the little house they saw that it was built of bread and covered with cakes, but that the windows were of clear sugar. ‘We will set to work on that,’ said Hansel, ‘and have a good meal. I will eat a bit of the roof, and you Gretel, can eat some of the window, it will taste sweet.’ Hansel reached up above, and broke off a little of the roof to try how it tasted, and Gretel leant against the window and nibbled at the panes. Then a soft voice cried from the parlour:
‘Nibble, nibble, gnaw,
  Who is nibbling at my little house?’
The children answered:
‘The wind, the wind,
  The heaven-born wind,’
and went on eating without disturbing themselves. Hansel, who liked the taste of the roof, tore down a great piece of it, and Gretel pushed out the whole of one round window-pane, sat down, and enjoyed herself with it. Suddenly the door opened, and a woman as old as the hills, who supported herself on crutches, came creeping out. Hansel and Gretel were so terribly frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands. The old woman, however, nodded her head, and said: ‘Oh, you dear children, who has brought you here? do come in, and stay with me. No harm shall happen to you.’ She took them both by the hand, and led them into her little house. Then good food was set before them, milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples, and nuts. Afterwards two pretty little beds were covered with clean white linen, and Hansel and Gretel lay down in them, and thought they were in heaven.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It was now three mornings since they had left their father’s house. They had wandered far into the forest, and hunger and weariness were beginning to weigh heavily upon them. Yet still they pressed on, hoping to find their way home or some shelter. At midday, as they walked beneath the tall trees, they heard a sweet and enchanting song. Looking up, they saw a beautiful snow-white bird perched upon a branch, singing with such melody that it seemed to fill the whole forest with joy. The children paused to listen, and when the bird ceased its song, it took flight, leading them onward. They followed the bird until it came to rest upon the roof of a small house. Approaching, Hansel and Gretel beheld a wondrous sight: the house was made of bread, the roof was covered with cakes, and the windows were of clear, shining sugar. Hansel, his hunger overcoming all caution, said, "Let us eat some of this house, for it looks so delicious." He broke off a piece of the roof, while Gretel nibbled at a sugar windowpane. Suddenly, a soft voice called from within, "Who is eating my house?" The children, startled but unafraid, answered, "It is the wind." Hansel tore off a larger piece of the roof, and Gretel pushed out an entire windowpane to enjoy. At that moment, the door opened, and an old woman, leaning on crutches, appeared. Terrified, the children dropped their stolen morsels, but the old woman smiled kindly and beckoned them inside, assuring them no harm would come to them. She led them into her cozy home, where she served them a delicious meal of milk, pancakes, sugar, apples, and nuts. Afterward, she prepared two comfortable beds with clean white linen, where Hansel and Gretel lay down, feeling as if they were in paradise.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was now three mornings since they had left their father’s house. The two brothers, Hans and Fritz, had set out on their journey with nothing but a small bundle of provisions and their father’s blessing. Their mother had wept as they departed, warning them of the dangers that lurked in the dark forest that lay ahead. But the boys were determined to seek their fortunes and prove their bravery.

As they walked deeper into the woods, the trees grew taller and the shadows longer. The birdsong faded, replaced by the rustling of leaves and the occasional snap of a twig. Hans, the elder, kept a steady pace, while Fritz, ever curious, darted from path to path, eager to explore.

On the third evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, they came upon a clearing where a magnificent castle stood. Its walls gleamed in the fading light, and the gates were wide open, inviting them in. Cautiously, they stepped inside and found themselves in a grand hall adorned with tapestries and chandeliers.

Suddenly, a voice echoed through the chamber. "Who dares enter my domain?" it boomed. From the shadows emerged a giant, his eyes blazing with fury. The boys trembled but stood their ground. Hans spoke bravely, "We are travelers seeking shelter and adventure. We mean no harm."

The giant studied them for a moment, then smiled. "Very well. If you can prove your courage and wit, you may stay."

He set them a series of tasks: to retrieve a golden apple from the tallest tree, to solve a riddle that had baffled many, and to brave the dark cave where the fire-breathing dragon dwelled.

With determination, the brothers faced each challenge. Hans climbed the towering tree, plucking the golden apple with care. Fritz pondered the riddle, his sharp mind unraveling its mystery. Together, they ventured into the cave, their hearts pounding, and confronted the dragon, who, impressed by their bravery, allowed them safe passage.

Having completed the tasks, they returned to the giant, who welcomed them as his guests. In time, the brothers learned that the giant was a cursed prince, and their courage had broken the spell. Grateful, he bestowed upon them treasures beyond their wildest dreams.

Hans and Fritz returned home, their hearts full of stories and their pockets heavy with gold, forever remembered as the brave brothers who conquered the giant’s challenges.

events.title: The Witch's True Nature and Hansel's Captivity
detailed_summary: The old woman's apparent kindness was a deceit; she was a malevolent witch who constructed the bread house solely to trap children.
Her practice was to kill, cook, and eat any child she captured, marking such occasions as feast days.
Witches possess red eyes and poor vision but have an acute sense of smell like animals, enabling them to detect nearby humans.
Upon Hansel and Gretel's arrival in her vicinity, she had laughed wickedly, confident they wouldn't escape her.
Early the next morning, before the children awoke, she observed them sleeping, admiring their plump, rosy appearance, and muttered about the dainty meal they would make.
She then seized Hansel with her withered hand, carried him to a small stable, and locked him behind a grated door, ignoring his screams.
Afterward, she woke Gretel by shaking her, ordering the terrified child to fetch water and cook good food for Hansel, explaining he was being fattened in the stable to be eaten.
Gretel wept profusely but was compelled to obey the wicked witch's commands.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The old woman had only pretended to be so kind; she was in reality a wicked witch, who lay in wait for children, and had only built the little house of bread in order to entice them there.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Gretel began to weep bitterly, but it was all in vain, for she was forced to do what the wicked witch commanded.

events.text_segment: The old woman had only pretended to be so kind; she was in reality a wicked witch, who lay in wait for children, and had only built the little house of bread in order to entice them there. When a child fell into her power, she killed it, cooked and ate it, and that was a feast day with her. Witches have red eyes, and cannot see far, but they have a keen scent like the beasts, and are aware when human beings draw near. When Hansel and Gretel came into her neighbourhood, she laughed with malice, and said mockingly: ‘I have them, they shall not escape me again!’ Early in the morning before the children were awake, she was already up, and when she saw both of them sleeping and looking so pretty, with their plump and rosy cheeks she muttered to herself: ‘That will be a dainty mouthful!’ Then she seized Hansel with her shrivelled hand, carried him into a little stable, and locked him in behind a grated door. Scream as he might, it would not help him. Then she went to Gretel, shook her till she awoke, and cried: ‘Get up, lazy thing, fetch some water, and cook something good for your brother, he is in the stable outside, and is to be made fat. When he is fat, I will eat him.’ Gretel began to weep bitterly, but it was all in vain, for she was forced to do what the wicked witch commanded.

events.title: Gretel's Clever Defeat of the Wicked Witch
detailed_summary: Excellent food was prepared for Hansel, while Gretel received only crab-shells.
Each morning, the witch would go to Hansel's stable and ask him to extend his finger so she could check if he was getting fat.
Hansel, however, cleverly offered her a small bone instead. The old woman, having poor eyesight, couldn't discern the trick and was baffled by his apparent lack of weight gain.
After four weeks passed with Hansel remaining seemingly thin, the witch grew impatient and decided she would wait no longer.
She ordered Gretel to fetch water, declaring that Hansel would be killed and cooked the next day, regardless of his condition.
Gretel was deeply distressed by this, lamenting and crying as she carried out her tasks, wishing they had died together in the forest.
The old woman harshly told her to be quiet, saying her cries were useless.
Early the next morning, Gretel had to prepare the cauldron and light the fire.
The witch announced they would bake first, stating she had already heated the oven and prepared the dough.
She directed Gretel towards the oven, from which flames were already issuing, and told her to crawl inside to check if it was hot enough for the bread.
The witch's secret plan was to trap Gretel inside and bake her as well.
Gretel, however, perceived the witch's intention and feigned ignorance, asking how she was supposed to get into the oven.
The old woman called her a silly goose, remarking that the door was large enough and demonstrated by leaning in and putting her own head into the oven.
At that moment, Gretel gave her a strong push, sending the witch deep into the oven. Gretel then slammed the iron door shut and bolted it.
The witch began to howl terribly, but Gretel fled, leaving the godless witch to burn to death.

events.text_segment:
And now the best food was cooked for poor Hansel, but Gretel got nothing but crab-shells. Every morning the woman crept to the little stable, and cried: ‘Hansel, stretch out your finger that I may feel if you will soon be fat.’ Hansel, however, stretched out a little bone to her, and the old woman, who had dim eyes, could not see it, and thought it was Hansel’s finger, and was astonished that there was no way of fattening him. When four weeks had gone by, and Hansel still remained thin, she was seized with impatience and would not wait any longer. ‘Now, then, Gretel,’ she cried to the girl, ‘stir yourself, and bring some water. Let Hansel be fat or lean, tomorrow I will kill him, and cook him.’ Ah, how the poor little sister did lament when she had to fetch the water, and how her tears did flow down her cheeks! ‘Dear God, do help us,’ she cried. ‘If the wild beasts in the forest had but devoured us, we should at any rate have died together.’ ‘Just keep your noise to yourself,’ said the old woman, ‘it won’t help you at all.’
Early in the morning, Gretel had to go out and hang up the cauldron with the water, and light the fire. ‘We will bake first,’ said the old woman, ‘I have already heated the oven, and kneaded the dough.’ She pushed poor Gretel out to the oven, from which flames of fire were already darting. ‘Creep in,’ said the witch, ‘and see if it is properly heated, so that we can put the bread in.’ And once Gretel was inside, she intended to shut the oven and let her bake in it, and then she would eat her, too. But Gretel saw what she had in mind, and said: ‘I do not know how I am to do it; how do I get in?’ ‘Silly goose,’ said the old woman. ‘The door is big enough; just look, I can get in myself!’ and she crept up and thrust her head into the oven. Then Gretel gave her a push that drove her far into it, and shut the iron door, and fastened the bolt. Oh! then she began to howl quite horribly, but Gretel ran away and the godless witch was miserably burnt to death.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
And now the best food was cooked for poor Hansel, but Gretel got nothing but crab-shells. The stepmother was cruel and jealous, and she wished to get rid of the children so that her own son might inherit all the wealth. One day, she took Hansel and Gretel deep into the forest and left them there, hoping they would never find their way home. But Hansel, who was clever, had dropped white pebbles along the path, and by moonlight, they followed the shining stones back to their house.

The stepmother was furious, but she did not give up. A second time, she led them even farther into the woods and left them again. This time, Hansel had no pebbles, so he dropped crumbs of bread to mark the way. But the birds ate the crumbs, and the children were lost. They wandered through the forest until they came upon a strange house made of bread, cake, and sugar. Hungry and tired, they began to eat the house.

Suddenly, an old woman appeared. She was a witch who lured children to her home to eat them. She captured Hansel and locked him in a cage, planning to fatten him up. Gretel was forced to do chores. But Gretel was brave and clever. When the witch told her to check if the oven was hot enough, Gretel pretended not to understand. The witch grew impatient and leaned into the oven to demonstrate. Quick as a flash, Gretel pushed the witch into the oven and shut the door.

Hansel was freed, and the children found treasure in the witch's house. They filled their pockets and made their way home. When they returned, they found their stepmother had died, and their father was overjoyed to see them. With the witch's treasure, they lived happily ever after, never fearing hunger or cruelty again.

events.title: Liberation, Riches, and Joyful Homecoming
detailed_summary: Gretel immediately ran to Hansel's stable, opened it, and joyfully announced their salvation because the old witch was dead.
Hansel emerged with delight, and the siblings celebrated their freedom with embraces and kisses.
No longer fearing the witch, they explored her house and found chests filled with pearls and jewels in every corner.
Hansel declared these treasures far superior to pebbles and filled his pockets, while Gretel filled her apron.
Hansel then urged that they must depart from the witch's forest.
After walking for two hours, they arrived at a large expanse of water, with no visible means to cross.
Gretel noticed a white duck swimming nearby and called out to it, asking for help to cross.
The duck approached, and Hansel prepared to mount its back with Gretel, but Gretel suggested it would be too heavy for the duck to carry them both at once, proposing they cross one after the other.
The kind duck obliged, ferrying them safely across individually.
Once on the other side, the forest began to look increasingly familiar, and eventually, they spotted their father's house in the distance.
They ran towards it, rushed into the parlor, and threw themselves into their father's arms.
The man had not experienced a moment of happiness since abandoning them; meanwhile, their stepmother had passed away.
Gretel emptied her apron, scattering pearls and precious stones, and Hansel added more from his pockets.
With their anxieties ended, they lived together in perfect happiness.
The narrative concludes with a traditional fairytale closing line about a mouse.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Gretel, however, ran like lightning to Hansel, opened his little stable, and cried: ‘Hansel, we are saved! The old witch is dead!’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: My tale is done, there runs a mouse; whosoever catches it, may make himself a big fur cap out of it.

events.text_segment:
Gretel, however, ran like lightning to Hansel, opened his little stable, and cried: ‘Hansel, we are saved! The old witch is dead!’ Then Hansel sprang like a bird from its cage when the door is opened. How they did rejoice and embrace each other, and dance about and kiss each other! And as they had no longer any need to fear her, they went into the witch’s house, and in every corner there stood chests full of pearls and jewels. ‘These are far better than pebbles!’ said Hansel, and thrust into his pockets whatever could be got in, and Gretel said: ‘I, too, will take something home with me,’ and filled her pinafore full. ‘But now we must be off,’ said Hansel, ‘that we may get out of the witch’s forest.’
When they had walked for two hours, they came to a great stretch of water. ‘We cannot cross,’ said Hansel, ‘I see no foot-plank, and no bridge.’ ‘And there is also no ferry,’ answered Gretel, ‘but a white duck is swimming there: if I ask her, she will help us over.’ Then she cried:
‘Little duck, little duck, dost thou see,
  Hansel and Gretel are waiting for thee?
  There’s never a plank, or bridge in sight,
  Take us across on thy back so white.’
The duck came to them, and Hansel seated himself on its back, and told his sister to sit by him. ‘No,’ replied Gretel, ‘that will be too heavy for the little duck; she shall take us across, one after the other.’ The good little duck did so, and when they were once safely across and had walked for a short time, the forest seemed to be more and more familiar to them, and at length they saw from afar their father’s house. Then they began to run, rushed into the parlour, and threw themselves round their father’s neck. The man had not known one happy hour since he had left the children in the forest; the woman, however, was dead. Gretel emptied her pinafore until pearls and precious stones ran about the room, and Hansel threw one handful after another out of his pocket to add to them. Then all anxiety was at an end, and they lived together in perfect happiness. My tale is done, there runs a mouse; whosoever catches it, may make himself a big fur cap out of it.

And if they have not died, then they live happily to this day, as the mouse said.
