LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Hansel, who was very weak and could hardly stand, smiled faintly and said, 'Thank God, Gretel! Now we can go home.' They gathered the witch's treasures—jewels and pearls—and filled their pockets. Then, hand in hand, they set out to find their way back through the dark forest.

The woods seemed less frightening now that the witch was gone. Birds sang sweetly, and the sun began to shine through the trees. After walking for some time, they came upon a white dove perched on a branch. The dove looked at them kindly and flew ahead, as if to guide them.

Following the dove, Hansel and Gretel soon reached a clearing where a kind old woman lived. She welcomed them warmly and gave them food and rest. The children told her their story, and she promised to help them find their way home.

The next morning, the old woman gave them a loaf of bread and a small bag of gold coins. She said, 'Take this bread to keep your strength, and these coins to help you on your journey.' With grateful hearts, Hansel and Gretel set off once more.

As they walked, the forest began to thin, and soon they saw the familiar fields and hills of their village. Their father was working in the fields, looking sad and worried. When he saw his children, he ran to them with tears of joy.

'My dear children!' he exclaimed. 'I thought I had lost you forever.' Hansel and Gretel told him of their adventure and the wicked witch who had tried to harm them.

From that day on, the family lived happily together. The father never again listened to the stepmother's cruel plans, and Hansel and Gretel grew up safe and loved. They often remembered the brave deeds that saved them and the kindness of strangers who helped them find their way home.

chapters.chapter_title: THE MOUSE, THE BIRD, AND THE SAUSAGE

events.title: A Harmonious Household and Shared Duties
detailed_summary: A mouse, a bird, and a sausage decided to live together as partners.
They enjoyed a long period of comfortable and prosperous coexistence, successfully increasing their shared resources.
Their household duties were clearly defined: the bird was responsible for gathering firewood from the woods each day.
The mouse's task was to fetch water.
The sausage managed the cooking.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Once upon a time, a mouse, a bird, and a sausage, entered into partnership and set up house together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bird’s duty was to fly daily into the wood and bring in fuel; the mouse fetched the water, and the sausage saw to the cooking.

events.text_segment: Once upon a time, a mouse, a bird, and a sausage, entered into partnership and set up house together. For a long time all went well; they lived in great comfort, and prospered so far as to be able to add considerably to their stores. The bird’s duty was to fly daily into the wood and bring in fuel; the mouse fetched the water, and the sausage saw to the cooking.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Once upon a time, a mouse, a bird, and a sausage, entered into partnership and set up house together. They lived happily for a long time, and their joint resources increased. Each had a particular task: the bird went into the woods every day to fetch firewood; the mouse went to the well to draw water; and the sausage stayed at home to cook the meals. This arrangement worked well, and they prospered in their comfortable home.

events.text_segment: When people are too well off they always begin to long for something new. And so it came to pass, that the bird, while out one day, met a fellow bird, to whom he boastfully expatiated on the excellence of his household arrangements. But the other bird sneered at him for being a poor simpleton, who did all the hard work, while the other two stayed at home and had a good time of it. For, when the mouse had made the fire and fetched in the water, she could retire into her little room and rest until it was time to set the table. The sausage had only to watch the pot to see that the food was properly cooked, and when it was near dinner-time, he just threw himself into the broth, or rolled in and out among the vegetables three or four times, and there they were, buttered, and salted, and ready to be served. Then, when the bird came home and had laid aside his burden, they sat down to table, and when they had finished their meal, they could sleep their fill till the following morning: and that was really a very delightful life.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When people are too well off they always begin to long for something new. This is a truth that many of the tales collected by the Brothers Grimm illustrate with vivid clarity. In one such story, a wealthy merchant, surrounded by riches and comfort, found himself yearning for adventure and excitement beyond his gilded cage. Despite his abundance, he felt a restless emptiness that no treasure could fill.

In another tale, a princess, bored with her luxurious life, wished for a simple life in the forest, only to discover the hardships and joys that came with it. These stories remind us that human desire is insatiable and that true happiness often lies not in material wealth but in the richness of experience and the fulfillment of the heart's deepest longings.

The Grimms' fairy tales often teach that contentment comes from appreciating what one has and that the pursuit of novelty can lead to unexpected lessons and growth. Thus, when people are too well off, their longing for something new is a natural part of the human condition, urging them to seek meaning beyond mere possessions.

events.title: Rebellion and a New Division of Labor by Lot
detailed_summary: Affected by the fellow bird's comments, the protagonist bird declared the next morning that he would no longer gather wood.
He asserted that he had served the others for too long, feeling he had been exploited, and insisted it was time for a new division of labor.
Despite earnest pleas from the mouse and the sausage to maintain the existing arrangement, their appeals were futile.
The bird remained resolute, making a change unavoidable.
Consequently, they resorted to drawing lots to reallocate the chores.
The outcome was that the sausage would be responsible for collecting wood, the mouse would take over cooking, and the bird's new duty was to fetch water.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They therefore drew lots, and it fell to the sausage to bring in the wood, to the mouse to cook, and to the bird to fetch the water.

events.text_segment: Influenced by those remarks, the bird next morning refused to bring in the wood, telling the others that he had been their servant long enough, and had been a fool into the bargain, and that it was now time to make a change, and to try some other way of arranging the work. Beg and pray as the mouse and the sausage might, it was of no use; the bird remained master of the situation, and the venture had to be made. They therefore drew lots, and it fell to the sausage to bring in the wood, to the mouse to cook, and to the bird to fetch the water.

events.title: The Sausage's Fatal Mission and the Dog's Justification
detailed_summary: The new arrangement commenced: the sausage departed to find wood, the bird lit the fire, and the mouse prepared the cooking pot.
The bird and mouse then waited for the sausage to return with the day's fuel supply.
However, the sausage was gone for an unexpectedly long time, causing the others to become anxious.
The bird decided to fly out in search of him.
Not far into his search, the bird encountered a dog.
The dog had met the sausage, considered him fair game, and had consequently caught and eaten him.
The bird confronted the dog, accusing him of blatant robbery, but his protests were ineffective.
The dog justified its actions by stating that it had discovered 'false credentials' on the sausage, which, in its view, meant the sausage's life was rightfully forfeit.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And now what happened?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The bird complained to the dog of this bare-faced robbery, but nothing he said was of any avail, for the dog answered that he found false credentials on the sausage, and that was the reason his life had been forfeited.

events.text_segment: And now what happened? The sausage started in search of wood, the bird made the fire, and the mouse put on the pot, and then these two waited till the sausage returned with the fuel for the following day. But the sausage remained so long away, that they became uneasy, and the bird flew out to meet him. He had not flown far, however, when he came across a dog who, having met the sausage, had regarded him as his legitimate booty, and so seized and swallowed him. The bird complained to the dog of this bare-faced robbery, but nothing he said was of any avail, for the dog answered that he found false credentials on the sausage, and that was the reason his life had been forfeited.

The bird and the mouse waited patiently for the sausage to return with the day's supply of fuel. But the sausage was gone longer than expected, and their concern grew. The bird decided to fly out in search of him. Not far from the house, the bird encountered a dog. The dog told the bird that he had met the sausage, considered him fair game, and had caught and eaten him. The bird accused the dog of blatant robbery, but the dog was unrepentant, claiming that he had found false credentials on the sausage, which, in his eyes, justified taking the sausage's life.

events.title: Grief and the Mouse's Tragic Imitation in the Kitchen
detailed_summary: The bird collected the wood and, filled with sorrow, flew back home.
He recounted to the mouse the events he had witnessed and what the dog had told him concerning the sausage's fate.
Both were deeply saddened by the news but mutually decided to cope with the situation and continue living together.
Subsequently, the bird took on the task of setting the table, while the mouse assumed responsibility for the food.
Wishing to prepare the meal in the same manner as the sausage had—by rolling among the vegetables to season them—the mouse leaped into the pot.
Her attempt was disastrous; she perished before even reaching the bottom of the pot, losing her skin, fur, and ultimately her life in the process.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He picked up the wood, and flew sadly home, and told the mouse all he had seen and heard.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So now the bird set the table, and the mouse looked after the food and, wishing to prepare it in the same way as the sausage, by rolling in and out among the vegetables to salt and butter them, she jumped into the pot; but she stopped short long before she reached the bottom, having already parted not only with her skin and hair, but also with life.

So now the bird set the table, and the mouse looked after the food and, wishing to prepare it in the same way as the sausage, by rolling in and out among the vegetables to salt and butter them, she jumped into the pot; but she stopped short long before she reached the bottom, having already parted not only with her skin and hair, but also with life.

So the bird said, "I will set the table," and the mouse said, "I will get the food." The mouse wished to prepare the meal as the sausage had done, by rolling among the vegetables to season them. So she jumped into the pot, but she was burned and lost her skin and fur, and died before she reached the bottom.

events.title: The Bird's Final Despair and Accidental Drowning
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, the bird entered, intending to serve the dinner, but the cook—the mouse—was nowhere to be found.
In a state of alarm and agitation, he scattered the firewood haphazardly across the floor while he searched for her.
During this frantic search, some of the carelessly discarded wood caught fire and began to burn.
The bird quickly hurried to get water to extinguish the flames.
In his haste, however, his water pail fell into the well, and he tumbled in after it.
Being unable to rescue himself from the well, the bird drowned.

events.title: The Industrious Daughter's Hardship and the Lost Spindle
detailed_summary: A widow, who was a stepmother to one daughter, favored her own lazy and ugly child over her beautiful and industrious stepdaughter.
The stepdaughter was relegated to menial tasks and treated as the family outcast, akin to Cinderella.
Her stepmother compelled her to spin yarn by a well daily, to the point where her fingers would bleed.
On one occasion, after her fingers bled, the spindle became soiled and, while she tried to wash it in the well, it slipped from her grasp and fell in.
When she tearfully reported the incident, her stepmother reacted with anger, berated her harshly, and cruelly commanded her to retrieve the spindle from the well herself.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Once upon a time there was a widow who had two daughters; one of them was beautiful and industrious, the other ugly and lazy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘As you have let the spindle fall into the well you may go yourself and fetch it out.’

events.text_segment: Once upon a time there was a widow who had two daughters; one of them was beautiful and industrious, the other ugly and lazy. The mother, however, loved the ugly and lazy one best, because she was her own daughter, and so the other, who was only her stepdaughter, was made to do all the work of the house, and was quite the Cinderella of the family. Her stepmother sent her out every day to sit by the well in the high road, there to spin until she made her fingers bleed. Now it chanced one day that some blood fell on to the spindle, and as the girl stopped over the well to wash it off, the spindle suddenly sprang out of her hand and fell into the well. She ran home crying to tell of her misfortune, but her stepmother spoke harshly to her, and after giving her a violent scolding, said unkindly, ‘As you have let the spindle fall into the well you may go yourself and fetch it out.’

She began to cry and told her stepmother what had happened. The stepmother was very angry and scolded her harshly, saying, "If you want your spindle back, you must go down into the well and fetch it yourself!"

events.title: Descent into the Well and Arrival in a Magical Meadow
detailed_summary: Returning to the well, overwhelmed by her predicament and with no clear solution, the girl impulsively leaped into the water in pursuit of the lost spindle.
She lost consciousness after entering the well.
Upon awakening, she found herself in an idyllic meadow, vibrant with sunshine and adorned with countless blooming flowers in all directions.

events.title: Helping the Talking Bread and Apple Tree
detailed_summary: As she traversed the meadow, she first encountered a baker's oven brimming with freshly baked bread.
The loaves of bread vocally appealed to her, requesting to be removed from the oven to prevent them from burning, as they were already perfectly baked.
Using a bread-shovel, she diligently removed all the loaves from the oven.
Proceeding further, she came upon a tree laden with ripe apples.
The apple tree implored her to shake its branches, explaining that all its apples were ripe.
She vigorously shook the tree, causing apples to cascade down like rain, and continued until every apple had fallen.
Afterward, she meticulously gathered the fallen apples into a neat pile before continuing her journey.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then she carefully gathered the apples together in a heap and walked on again.

events.text_segment:
She walked over the meadow, and presently she came upon a baker’s oven full of bread, and the loaves cried out to her, ‘Take us out, take us out, or alas! we shall be burnt to a cinder; we were baked through long ago.’ So she took the bread-shovel and drew them all out.
She went on a little farther, till she came to a tree full of apples. ‘Shake me, shake me, I pray,’ cried the tree; ‘my apples, one and all, are ripe.’ So she shook the tree, and the apples came falling down upon her like rain; but she continued shaking until there was not a single apple left upon it. Then she carefully gathered the apples together in a heap and walked on again.

events.title: Encountering Mother Holle and Agreeing to Serve
detailed_summary: Her path led her to a small cottage, from which an old woman with exceptionally large teeth was peering out.
The sight of the woman's teeth initially terrified the girl, prompting her to turn and flee.
The old woman, however, called out to her, kindly inquiring why she was afraid and inviting her to stay.
She introduced herself as Mother Holle and promised the girl happiness if she would diligently perform household chores.

A particular duty emphasized was the proper making of Mother Holle's bed, which required shaking it thoroughly enough for the feathers to fly about, a phenomenon said to cause snowfall in the world below.
The old woman's kind tone reassured the girl, who then found the courage to accept the offer and enter Mother Holle's service.

events.title: Diligent Service, Kind Treatment, and Growing Homesickness
detailed_summary: The girl conscientiously fulfilled all her duties according to Mother Holle's instructions.
Each time she made the bed, she shook it with all her strength, causing the feathers to scatter like snowflakes.
Mother Holle kept her word, treating the girl with kindness, never speaking angrily, and providing her with ample food, including roasted and boiled meats daily.
After spending some time with Mother Holle, the girl began to feel a sense of unhappiness.
Though she couldn't initially identify the reason for her sadness, she eventually recognized it as a profound longing for home.
She realized she was homesick, even though her life with Mother Holle was vastly better than with her own mother and sister.
After a period of contemplation, she approached Mother Holle to express her deep homesickness and her desire to return to her own people, despite her current contentment.

events.text_segment:
She took care to do everything according to the old woman’s bidding and every time she made the bed she shook it with all her might, so that the feathers flew about like so many snowflakes. The old woman was as good as her word: she never spoke angrily to her, and gave her roast and boiled meats every day.
So she stayed on with Mother Holle for some time, and then she began to grow unhappy. She could not at first tell why she felt sad, but she became conscious at last of great longing to go home; then she knew she was homesick, although she was a thousand times better off with Mother Holle than with her mother and sister. After waiting awhile, she went to Mother Holle and said, ‘I am so homesick, that I cannot stay with you any longer, for although I am so happy here, I must return to my own people.’

events.title: The Golden Reward and Return to a Surprised Family
detailed_summary: Mother Holle expressed her satisfaction with the girl's wish to return to her family, acknowledging her faithful service.
She offered to personally guide the girl home.
Mother Holle led her by the hand to a large gateway.
As the gate swung open and the girl passed through, a shower of gold rained down upon her, covering her entirely from head to foot.
Mother Holle explained that this was a reward for her industriousness.
In addition to the gold, Mother Holle returned the spindle that the girl had initially lost in the well.
The gateway then closed, and the girl found herself transported back to the familiar world, near her stepmother's house.
As she entered the courtyard, the rooster on the well crowed, announcing that their golden daughter had returned.
Upon entering her home, her stepmother and stepsister, impressed by her gold-covered appearance, gave her a warm welcome.

events.text_segment:
Then Mother Holle said, ‘I am pleased that you should want to go back to your own people, and as you have served me so well and faithfully, I will take you home myself.’
Thereupon she led the girl by the hand up to a broad gateway. The gate was opened, and as the girl passed through, a shower of gold fell upon her, and the gold clung to her, so that she was covered with it from head to foot.
‘That is a reward for your industry,’ said Mother Holle, and as she spoke she handed her the spindle which she had dropped into the well.
The gate was then closed, and the girl found herself back in the old world close to her mother’s house. As she entered the courtyard, the cock who was perched on the well, called out:
‘Cock-a-doodle-doo!
  Your golden daughter’s come back to you.’
Then she went in to her mother and sister, and as she was so richly covered with gold, they gave her a warm welcome. She related to them all that had happened, and when the mother heard how she had come by her great riches, she thought she should like her ugly, lazy daughter to go and try her fortune.

events.title: The Lazy Daughter's Selfish Journey to Mother Holle
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the industrious daughter's account of how she acquired her wealth, the stepmother became determined for her own lazy daughter to achieve similar fortune.
She instructed the lazy daughter to go to the well and spin.
To replicate the circumstances, the lazy daughter pricked her finger and rubbed her hand in a thorn-bush to ensure the spindle was bloodied, then threw it into the well and jumped in after it.
Like her sister, she awoke in the beautiful meadow and began to walk across it.
She encountered the oven, where the loaves cried out to be removed before burning.
The lazy daughter, however, curtly refused, stating she wouldn't dirty her hands for them, and continued on.
Soon after, she came to the apple tree, which pleaded with her to shake its branches as its apples were ripe.
She again refused, dismissing the request as unreasonable and expressing concern that an apple might fall on her head, then walked past.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But she only answered, ‘A nice thing to ask me to do, one of the apples might fall on my head,’ and passed on.

events.text_segment:
So she made the sister go and sit by the well and spin, and the girl pricked her finger and thrust her hand into a thorn-bush, so that she might drop some blood on to the spindle; then she threw it into the well, and jumped in herself.
Like her sister she awoke in the beautiful meadow, and walked over it till she came to the oven. ‘Take us out, take us out, or alas! we shall be burnt to a cinder; we were baked through long ago,’ cried the loaves as before. But the lazy girl answered, ‘Do you think I am going to dirty my hands for you?’ and walked on.
Presently she came to the apple-tree. ‘Shake me, shake me, I pray; my apples, one and all, are ripe,’ it cried. But she only answered, ‘A nice thing to ask me to do, one of the apples might fall on my head,’ and passed on.

events.title: The Lazy Daughter's Poor Service and Pitchy Punishment
detailed_summary: The lazy daughter eventually arrived at Mother Holle's house; having been forewarned by her sister about the large teeth, she felt no fear and promptly offered her services.
On her first day, driven by the anticipation of gold, she was obedient and diligent in her tasks to please Mother Holle.
By the second day, her laziness began to show as she started to dawdle, and on the third day, she was even more idle.
She developed a habit of staying in bed late and refusing to get up.
More significantly, she neglected to make Mother Holle's bed properly and failed to shake it so the feathers would fly.
Mother Holle quickly grew tired of her怠慢 and informed her that she could leave.
The lazy daughter was delighted by this, anticipating that her reward of gold was imminent.
Mother Holle led her to the same broad gateway as her sister.
However, as she passed through, instead of a shower of gold, a large bucketful of pitch was poured over her.
Mother Holle stated that this was the payment for her services and then closed the gate.
The lazy girl returned home covered in pitch, and the rooster on the well announced the arrival of their 'dirty daughter'.
Despite her best efforts, the pitch could not be removed and remained stuck to her for the rest of her life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: At last she came to Mother Holle’s house, and as she had heard all about the large teeth from her sister, she was not afraid of them, and engaged herself without delay to the old woman.

events.text_segment:
At last she came to Mother Holle’s house, and as she had heard all about the large teeth from her sister, she was not afraid of them, and engaged herself without delay to the old woman.
The first day she was very obedient and industrious, and exerted herself to please Mother Holle, for she thought of the gold she should get in return. The next day, however, she began to dawdle over her work, and the third day she was more idle still; then she began to lie in bed in the mornings and refused to get up. Worse still, she neglected to make the old woman’s bed properly, and forgot to shake it so that the feathers might fly about. So Mother Holle very soon got tired of her, and told her she might go. The lazy girl was delighted at this, and thought to herself, ‘The gold will soon be mine.’ Mother Holle led her, as she had led her sister, to the broad gateway; but as she was passing through, instead of the shower of gold, a great bucketful of pitch came pouring over her.
‘That is in return for your services,’ said the old woman, and she shut the gate.
So the lazy girl had to go home covered with pitch, and the cock on the well called out as she saw her:
‘Cock-a-doodle-doo!
  Your dirty daughter’s come back to you.’
But, try what she would, she could not get the pitch off and it stuck to her as long as she lived.

Mother Holle set her to work at once, and the first thing she had to do was to shake out the feather bed, so that the feathers flew about in the air and fell down upon the earth like snow. The girl worked diligently and cheerfully, and when she had finished, Mother Holle gave her a bowl of porridge to eat. After that, she was set to other tasks, such as washing and baking, and she did everything with a willing heart. Time passed, and the girl grew happy and content in the service of Mother Holle.

One day, after she had been there for some time, Mother Holle said to her, "You have done well and been diligent; now you may return home." She led the girl to a well and told her to jump in. The girl did so, and she found herself back in her own world, standing before her mother's house. To her surprise, she was covered with gold, which had been given to her as a reward for her good service.

When her sister saw this, she was envious and decided to go to Mother Holle's house herself. But unlike her sister, she was lazy and careless, and she did not do the work properly. As a result, when she returned, she was covered with pitch instead of gold, and she was shunned by all.

events.title: Little Red-Cap's Errand and Mother's Instructions
detailed_summary: A beloved little girl, known as Little Red-Cap due to a red velvet cap from her grandmother, was always seen wearing it.
Her mother tasked her with delivering cake and wine to her ailing grandmother, emphasizing these provisions would aid her recovery.

She received specific instructions from her mother: to set out before the day became too hot, to walk calmly and directly without straying from the path, to avoid breaking the bottle which would leave her grandmother with nothing, and to offer a polite 'Good morning' upon entering her grandmother's room without prying into corners beforehand.
Little Red-Cap promised her mother she would be very careful and sealed it with a handshake.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Once upon a time there was a dear little girl who was loved by everyone who looked at her, but most of all by her grandmother, and there was nothing that she would not have given to the child.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘I will take great care,’ said Little Red-Cap to her mother, and gave her hand on it.

events.text_segment:
Once upon a time there was a dear little girl who was loved by everyone who looked at her, but most of all by her grandmother, and there was nothing that she would not have given to the child. Once she gave her a little cap of red velvet, which suited her so well that she would never wear anything else; so she was always called ‘Little Red-Cap.’
One day her mother said to her: ‘Come, Little Red-Cap, here is a piece of cake and a bottle of wine; take them to your grandmother, she is ill and weak, and they will do her good. Set out before it gets hot, and when you are going, walk nicely and quietly and do not run off the path, or you may fall and break the bottle, and then your grandmother will get nothing; and when you go into her room, don’t forget to say, “Good morning”, and don’t peep into every corner before you do it.’
‘I will take great care,’ said Little Red-Cap to her mother, and gave her hand on it.

events.title: Encounter with the Wolf and His Cunning Plot
detailed_summary: The grandmother resided in the woods, a moderate distance from the village. As Little Red-Cap ventured into the woods, she encountered a wolf.
Unaware of the wolf's malevolent nature, Little Red-Cap felt no fear towards him.
The wolf initiated a conversation, greeting Little Red-Cap politely.
She responded courteously.
The wolf inquired about her early journey and the contents of her apron.
Little Red-Cap explained she was bringing cake and wine from the previous day's baking to help her sick grandmother regain strength.
When asked about her grandmother's location, she innocently described it as being a quarter of a league further, near three large oak trees and nut-trees, assuming the wolf might know it.
The wolf internally recognized Little Red-Cap as a tender, plump potential meal, preferable to the old woman, and decided he needed a clever plan to capture both.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The grandmother lived out in the wood, half a league from the village, and just as Little Red-Cap entered the wood, a wolf met her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I must act craftily, so as to catch both.’

events.text_segment:
The grandmother lived out in the wood, half a league from the village, and just as Little Red-Cap entered the wood, a wolf met her. Red-Cap did not know what a wicked creature he was, and was not at all afraid of him.
‘Good day, Little Red-Cap,’ said he.
‘Thank you kindly, wolf.’
‘Whither away so early, Little Red-Cap?’
‘To my grandmother’s.’
‘What have you got in your apron?’
‘Cake and wine; yesterday was baking-day, so poor sick grandmother is to have something good, to make her stronger.’
‘Where does your grandmother live, Little Red-Cap?’
‘A good quarter of a league farther on in the wood; her house stands under the three large oak-trees, the nut-trees are just below; you surely must know it,’ replied Little Red-Cap.
The wolf thought to himself: ‘What a tender young creature! what a nice plump mouthful—she will be better to eat than the old woman. I must act craftily, so as to catch both.’

events.title: Lured Off the Path by the Wolf's Deception
detailed_summary: The wolf accompanied Little Red-Cap for a brief period.

He then tried to divert her attention by pointing out the beautiful flowers and suggesting she was missing the joyful sounds of birds, comparing her focused walk to that of someone going to school while the woods were full of merriment.

Little Red-Cap looked up, noticed the sunbeams and abundant flowers, and considered gathering a fresh bouquet for her grandmother, believing it would please her and that she had enough time as it was still early.
Consequently, she left the path and went into the woods to search for flowers, venturing further and further as each newly spotted flower seemed more attractive than the last.

events.title: The Wolf Deceives and Devours the Grandmother
detailed_summary: While Little Red-Cap was busy picking flowers, the wolf proceeded directly to the grandmother's house and knocked.
The grandmother inquired who was at the door.
The wolf, imitating Little Red-Cap's voice, announced he was bringing cake and wine and asked her to open.
The grandmother, stating she was too frail to get up, instructed him to lift the latch.
Upon lifting the latch, the door opened, and the wolf entered silently, went straight to the grandmother's bed, and consumed her.
Afterwards, he donned her clothes and cap, got into her bed, and closed the bed curtains.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Meanwhile the wolf ran straight to the grandmother’s house and knocked at the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he put on her clothes, dressed himself in her cap laid himself in bed and drew the curtains.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile the wolf ran straight to the grandmother’s house and knocked at the door.
‘Who is there?’
‘Little Red-Cap,’ replied the wolf. ‘She is bringing cake and wine; open the door.’
‘Lift the latch,’ called out the grandmother, ‘I am too weak, and cannot get up.’
The wolf lifted the latch, the door sprang open, and without saying a word he went straight to the grandmother’s bed, and devoured her. Then he put on her clothes, dressed himself in her cap laid himself in bed and drew the curtains.

events.title: Little Red-Cap's Arrival and Deception by the Disguised Wolf
detailed_summary: Little Red-Cap, having collected a large number of flowers, finally recalled her grandmother and resumed her journey to the cottage.
She found it unusual that the cottage door was ajar, and upon entering the room, she experienced a strange, uneasy sensation, contrasting with her usual delight in visiting her grandmother.
She called out a greeting but heard no response.
Approaching the bed, she pulled back the curtains and observed her grandmother lying there with her cap drawn low over her face, appearing peculiar.
Little Red-Cap commented on her grandmother's unusually large ears, to which the wolf replied they were for better hearing.
She then remarked on the grandmother's large eyes, and the wolf responded they were for better seeing.
Next, she noted the large hands, which the wolf claimed were for better hugging.
Finally, Little Red-Cap exclaimed about the terrible big mouth, and the wolf declared it was for better eating her.
Immediately after this statement, the wolf leaped from the bed and devoured Little Red-Cap.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Little Red-Cap, however, had been running about picking flowers, and when she had gathered so many that she could carry no more, she remembered her grandmother, and set out on the way to her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And scarcely had the wolf said this, than with one bound he was out of bed and swallowed up Red-Cap.

events.text_segment:
Little Red-Cap, however, had been running about picking flowers, and when she had gathered so many that she could carry no more, she remembered her grandmother, and set out on the way to her.
She was surprised to find the cottage-door standing open, and when she went into the room, she had such a strange feeling that she said to herself: ‘Oh dear! how uneasy I feel today, and at other times I like being with grandmother so much.’ She called out: ‘Good morning,’ but received no answer; so she went to the bed and drew back the curtains. There lay her grandmother with her cap pulled far over her face, and looking very strange.
‘Oh! grandmother,’ she said, ‘what big ears you have!’
‘The better to hear you with, my child,’ was the reply.
‘But, grandmother, what big eyes you have!’ she said.
‘The better to see you with, my dear.’
‘But, grandmother, what large hands you have!’
‘The better to hug you with.’
‘Oh! but, grandmother, what a terrible big mouth you have!’
‘The better to eat you with!’
And scarcely had the wolf said this, than with one bound he was out of bed and swallowed up Red-Cap.

events.title: The Huntsman's Discovery and Miraculous Rescue
detailed_summary: Having satisfied his hunger, the wolf returned to the bed, fell asleep, and began to snore very loudly.
A huntsman passing by the house heard the loud snoring and thought the old woman might need assistance, deciding to investigate.
Upon entering the room and approaching the bed, he discovered the wolf lying there.
The huntsman recognized the wolf as an 'old sinner' he had been pursuing for a long time.
He was about to shoot the wolf when he considered that the wolf might have consumed the grandmother, who could potentially still be alive and rescued.
Therefore, he refrained from shooting and instead used a pair of scissors to carefully cut open the sleeping wolf's stomach.
After making two cuts, he saw Little Red-Cap. With two more snips, the little girl jumped out, exclaiming how terrified she had been and how dark it was inside the wolf.
Following her, the elderly grandmother also emerged alive, though she was very weak and struggled to breathe.

events.text_segment: When the wolf had appeased his appetite, he lay down again in the bed, fell asleep and began to snore very loud. The huntsman was just passing the house, and thought to himself: ‘How the old woman is snoring! I must just see if she wants anything.’ So he went into the room, and when he came to the bed, he saw that the wolf was lying in it. ‘Do I find you here, you old sinner!’ said he. ‘I have long sought you!’ Then just as he was going to fire at him, it occurred to him that the wolf might have devoured the grandmother, and that she might still be saved, so he did not fire, but took a pair of scissors, and began to cut open the stomach of the sleeping wolf. When he had made two snips, he saw the little Red-Cap shining, and then he made two snips more, and the little girl sprang out, crying: ‘Ah, how frightened I have been! How dark it was inside the wolf’; and after that the aged grandmother came out alive also, but scarcely able to breathe.

events.title: The Wolf's Demise, Joyful Resolution, and Red-Cap's Vow
detailed_summary: Little Red-Cap quickly gathered large stones, and they filled the wolf's belly with them.
When the wolf awoke, he attempted to flee, but the stones were so heavy that he immediately collapsed and died.
The three survivors were overjoyed.
The huntsman removed the wolf's skin and took it home.
The grandmother consumed the cake and wine that Little Red-Cap had brought, which helped her to recover her strength.
Little Red-Cap reflected on the experience and resolved that she would never again disobey her mother by straying from the path to run into the woods by herself.

events.title: A Second Encounter: A Wiser Red-Cap and Grandmother Outsmart Another Wolf
detailed_summary: The narrative also mentions a subsequent occasion when Little Red-Cap was again transporting cakes to her grandmother.
On this trip, a different wolf engaged her in conversation and attempted to coax her away from the designated path.
However, Little Red-Cap, now vigilant, proceeded directly on her way without deviation.

She recounted the encounter to her grandmother, noting the wolf's 'good morning' was accompanied by such a menacing look that she believed he would have consumed her had they not been on a public road.
The grandmother proposed they secure the door to prevent the wolf's entry.
Shortly thereafter, the wolf knocked, mimicking Little Red-Cap and claiming to be bringing cakes.
They remained silent and kept the door closed. The wolf then circled the house a few times before climbing onto the roof, intending to ambush Little Red-Cap later that evening.
The grandmother, discerning his intentions, instructed Little Red-Cap to take a pail and fill a large stone trough outside the house with the water in which she had boiled sausages the previous day.
Little Red-Cap continued this task until the trough was full.

The aroma of the sausages wafted up to the wolf, who sniffed and peered down, eventually stretching his neck so far that he lost his balance, slipped from the roof, and fell directly into the trough, where he drowned.
Little Red-Cap then returned home cheerfully, and she was never harmed by anyone again.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But Red-Cap went joyously home, and no one ever did anything to harm her again.

events.text_segment: It also related that once when Red-Cap was again taking cakes to the old grandmother, another wolf spoke to her, and tried to entice her from the path. Red-Cap, however, was on her guard, and went straight forward on her way, and told her grandmother that she had met the wolf, and that he had said ‘good morning’ to her, but with such a wicked look in his eyes, that if they had not been on the public road she was certain he would have eaten her up. ‘Well,’ said the grandmother, ‘we will shut the door, that he may not come in.’ Soon afterwards the wolf knocked, and cried: ‘Open the door, grandmother, I am Little Red-Cap, and am bringing you some cakes.’ But they did not speak, or open the door, so the grey-beard stole twice or thrice round the house, and at last jumped on the roof, intending to wait until Red-Cap went home in the evening, and then to steal after her and devour her in the darkness. But the grandmother saw what was in his thoughts. In front of the house was a great stone trough, so she said to the child: ‘Take the pail, Red-Cap; I made some sausages yesterday, so carry the water in which I boiled them to the trough.’ Red-Cap carried until the great trough was quite full. Then the smell of the sausages reached the wolf, and he sniffed and peeped down, and at last stretched out his neck so far that he could no longer keep his footing and began to slip, and slipped down from the roof straight into the great trough, and was drowned. But Red-Cap went joyously home, and no one ever did anything to harm her again.

events.title: The Uneasy Betrothal and a Sinister Invitation
detailed_summary: A miller, possessing a beautiful grown-up daughter, was keen for her to marry well and decided he would consent to the first suitable man who proposed.
Shortly thereafter, a suitor, appearing very wealthy and satisfactory to the miller, asked for the daughter's hand, and the miller agreed to the betrothal.
The daughter, however, felt a profound lack of affection and trust towards her intended husband, experiencing an involuntary shudder whenever she looked at or thought of him.
One day, the suitor noted that she had not yet visited his home, despite their engagement.
When she professed ignorance of his house's location, he informed her it was situated in the dark forest.
She attempted to excuse herself, claiming she would be unable to find the way.
Her betrothed insisted she must visit the following Sunday, mentioning he had already invited guests, and offered to strew ashes along the path to guide her.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was once a miller who had one beautiful daughter, and as she was grown up, he was anxious that she should be well married and provided for.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her betrothed only replied, ‘You must come and see me next Sunday; I have already invited guests for that day, and that you may not mistake the way, I will strew ashes along the path.’

events.text_segment: There was once a miller who had one beautiful daughter, and as she was grown up, he was anxious that she should be well married and provided for. He said to himself, ‘I will give her to the first suitable man who comes and asks for her hand.’ Not long after a suitor appeared, and as he appeared to be very rich and the miller could see nothing in him with which to find fault, he betrothed his daughter to him. But the girl did not care for the man as a girl ought to care for her betrothed husband. She did not feel that she could trust him, and she could not look at him nor think of him without an inward shudder. One day he said to her, ‘You have not yet paid me a visit, although we have been betrothed for some time.’ ‘I do not know where your house is,’ she answered. ‘My house is out there in the dark forest,’ he said. She tried to excuse herself by saying that she would not be able to find the way thither. Her betrothed only replied, ‘You must come and see me next Sunday; I have already invited guests for that day, and that you may not mistake the way, I will strew ashes along the path.’

He boasted to the king that his daughter could spin straw into gold. The king, eager to enrich his kingdom, summoned the miller and his daughter to the castle. He locked the girl in a room filled with straw and a spinning wheel, commanding her to spin all the straw into gold by morning, or she would lose her life.

The poor girl sat weeping, for she had no idea how to spin straw into gold. Suddenly, a strange little man appeared and offered to spin the straw into gold for her, but in return, she must give him her necklace. Desperate, she agreed, and by morning, the room was filled with gold.

The king was delighted but greedy. He locked her in a larger room with more straw, demanding the same by morning. Again, the little man appeared, and this time, she promised him her ring. He spun the straw into gold once more.

On the third night, the king demanded an even greater task. The little man appeared again, but the girl had nothing left to give. He then made her promise her first-born child if she became queen. She agreed, and the straw was spun into gold.

events.title: The Fateful Journey and Ominous Warnings
detailed_summary: When Sunday arrived for the girl's departure, an inexplicable feeling of dread overcame her.
To ensure she could retrace her steps, she filled her pockets with peas and lentils to sprinkle on the ground as she walked.
Upon reaching the forest's entrance, she found the path strewn with ashes as promised, and followed this trail, dropping peas on either side with every step.
She walked the entire day until she reached the deepest, most obscure part of the forest.
There, she encountered a solitary house, its grim and mysterious appearance disquieting her.
She went inside but found no one; a profound silence pervaded the dwelling.
Suddenly, a voice emanated from a bird in a cage on the wall, crying out a warning to turn back and not linger in the murderers' lair.
The bird repeated its ominous message.

‘Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair,
  Linger not in this murderers’ lair.’

events.text_segment:
When Sunday came, and it was time for the girl to start, a feeling of dread came over her which she could not explain, and that she might be able to find her path again, she filled her pockets with peas and lentils to sprinkle on the ground as she went along. On reaching the entrance to the forest she found the path strewed with ashes, and these she followed, throwing down some peas on either side of her at every step she took. She walked the whole day until she came to the deepest, darkest part of the forest. There she saw a lonely house, looking so grim and mysterious, that it did not please her at all. She stepped inside, but not a soul was to be seen, and a great silence reigned throughout. Suddenly a voice cried:
‘Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair,
  Linger not in this murderers’ lair.’
The girl looked up and saw that the voice came from a bird hanging in a cage on the wall. Again it cried:
‘Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair,
  Linger not in this murderers’ lair.’

events.title: The Old Woman's Revelation and the Hiding Place
detailed_summary: The girl proceeded through the house, exploring its rooms, all of which were empty, and she still encountered no one.
Finally, she descended to the cellar, where she discovered a very, very old woman whose head trembled incessantly.
The girl inquired if her betrothed husband resided there.
The old woman responded with sorrow, confirming the girl had entered a den of murderers.
She revealed that the girl's supposed marriage would be a feast with death, as the inhabitants planned to kill her without mercy, then cook and consume her, for they were cannibals.
Declaring her intent to save the girl out of pity, the old woman then guided her behind a large cask, which completely hid her from sight.

She instructed the girl to remain as still as a mouse, not moving or speaking, as any sound would seal her fate, and shared that they would escape together that night when the robbers slept, an opportunity the old woman had long awaited.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The girl passed on, going from room to room of the house, but they were all empty, and still she saw no one.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I have long been waiting for an opportunity to escape.’

events.text_segment:
The girl passed on, going from room to room of the house, but they were all empty, and still she saw no one. At last she came to the cellar, and there sat a very, very old woman, who could not keep her head from shaking. ‘Can you tell me,’ asked the girl, ‘if my betrothed husband lives here?’
‘Ah, you poor child,’ answered the old woman, ‘what a place for you to come to! This is a murderers’ den. You think yourself a promised bride, and that your marriage will soon take place, but it is with death that you will keep your marriage feast. Look, do you see that large cauldron of water which I am obliged to keep on the fire! As soon as they have you in their power they will kill you without mercy, and cook and eat you, for they are eaters of men. If I did not take pity on you and save you, you would be lost.’
Thereupon the old woman led her behind a large cask, which quite hid her from view. ‘Keep as still as a mouse,’ she said; ‘do not move or speak, or it will be all over with you. Tonight, when the robbers are all asleep, we will flee together. I have long been waiting for an opportunity to escape.’

At last she went down into the cellar, where she found a very, very old woman, whose head was shaking and trembling continually. "Is my bridegroom here?" asked the girl. "Alas!" said the old woman, "you have come into the den of murderers. Your wedding will be a feast of death; they will kill you without mercy, and then cook and eat you, for they are cannibals. But I will save you, for I pity you." Then she took the girl behind a great cask, which hid her quite out of sight, and said, "Lie as still as a mouse, and do not move or speak, for if you do, you are lost. To-night, when the robbers are asleep, we will escape together; I have long waited for this hour."

From that day forward, the prince and the girl lived happily, ruling the kingdom with kindness and wisdom, their story told for generations to come.

events.title: Witnessing a Brutal Murder in the Den
detailed_summary: Scarcely had the old woman finished speaking when the wicked group of robbers returned, dragging another young girl with them.
The robbers were all intoxicated and paid no attention to the new captive's cries and lamentations.
They forced her to drink three full glasses of wine—one white, one red, and one yellow—and upon doing so, her heart failed, and she died.
Subsequently, they stripped off her delicate clothing, laid her body on a table, dismembered her beautiful form, and sprinkled salt over the pieces.

events.title: The Severed Finger and the Robbers' Indifference
detailed_summary: The poor betrothed girl, still concealed behind the cask, trembled and shuddered in terror, having witnessed the dreadful fate the robbers had intended for her.
One of the robbers then noticed a gold ring still on the little finger of the murdered girl.
Finding it difficult to pull off, he took a hatchet and severed the finger.
The finger flew through the air, over the cask, and landed directly in the lap of the girl hiding there.
The robber procured a light and began searching for the finger but was unable to find it.
Another robber suggested he look behind the large cask.
However, the old woman intervened, urging them to come to supper and leave the search until the morning, casually remarking that the finger wouldn't run away.
The robbers agreed with the old woman's assessment, stopped looking for the finger, and sat down to their meal.

events.text_segment:
The poor betrothed girl crouched trembling and shuddering behind the cask, for she saw what a terrible fate had been intended for her by the robbers. One of them now noticed a gold ring still remaining on the little finger of the murdered girl, and as he could not draw it off easily, he took a hatchet and cut off the finger; but the finger sprang into the air, and fell behind the cask into the lap of the girl who was hiding there. The robber took a light and began looking for it, but he could not find it. ‘Have you looked behind the large cask?’ said one of the others. But the old woman called out, ‘Come and eat your suppers, and let the thing be till tomorrow; the finger won’t run away.’
‘The old woman is right,’ said the robbers, and they ceased looking for the finger and sat down.

events.title: The Daring Escape and Safe Return
detailed_summary: The old woman then surreptitiously mixed a sleeping draught into the robbers' wine.
Before long, all the robbers were lying on the cellar floor, deeply asleep and snoring loudly.
Once the girl was certain they were unconscious, she emerged from her hiding place behind the cask.
She was compelled to step over the bodies of the sleepers, who were lying close together, and with every movement, she was filled with renewed fear of waking them.
Divine intervention aided her, allowing her to pass safely over them.
She and the old woman then ascended the stairs, opened the door, and hastened away from the murderers' den as quickly as they could.
They discovered the ashes marking the path had been scattered by the wind, but the peas and lentils she had dropped had sprouted and grown sufficiently to guide them along the path in the moonlight.
They walked throughout the entire night, reaching the mill by morning.
Upon her return, the girl recounted all that had transpired to her father.

She was obliged to step over the bodies of the sleepers, who were lying close together, and every moment she was filled with renewed dread lest she should awaken them. But God helped her, so that she passed safely over them, and then she and the old woman went upstairs, opened the door, and hastened as fast as they could from the murderers’ den. They found the ashes scattered by the wind, but the peas and lentils had sprouted, and grown sufficiently above the ground, to guide them in the moonlight along the path. All night long they walked, and it was morning before they reached the mill. Then the girl told her father all that had happened.

events.title: The Bride's Chilling Tale at the Wedding Feast
detailed_summary: The day appointed for the wedding arrived; the bridegroom attended, along with a large assembly of guests whom the miller had invited from his friends and relations.
As they were seated at the feast, each guest, in turn, was prompted to tell a story; the bride, however, sat still and remained silent.
The bridegroom, turning to her, inquired if she knew no tale and urged her to share something.
The bride responded that she would recount a dream.

She began her tale, describing going alone through a forest until she reached a house where she found no one, except for a bird in a cage on the wall that cried out twice: 'Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair, Linger not in this murderers’ lair.'
The bridegroom interjected, remarking, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'

She continued her narrative, describing her exploration of the empty, grim, and mysterious house, eventually going down to the cellar where she found a very old woman who revealed that her betrothed lived there but intended to kill, cook, and eat her.
Again, the bridegroom dismissed it with, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'

The bride detailed how the old woman hid her behind a large cask, the robbers' subsequent return dragging another young girl, and how they gave the girl three kinds of wine—white, red, and yellow—causing her death.
The bridegroom once more stated, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'
She then described how the robbers tore off the dead girl's clothing, cut her body into pieces, and sprinkled salt upon it.
For the fourth time, the bridegroom said, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'

events.text_segment:
The day came that had been fixed for the marriage. The bridegroom arrived and also a large company of guests, for the miller had taken care to invite all his friends and relations. As they sat at the feast, each guest in turn was asked to tell a tale; the bride sat still and did not say a word.
‘And you, my love,’ said the bridegroom, turning to her, ‘is there no tale you know? Tell us something.’
‘I will tell you a dream, then,’ said the bride. ‘I went alone through a forest and came at last to a house; not a soul could I find within, but a bird that was hanging in a cage on the wall cried:
‘Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair,
  Linger not in this murderers’ lair.’
And again a second time it said these words.’
‘My darling, this is only a dream.’

events.title: The Gruesome Proof and Swift Justice
detailed_summary: Continuing her 'dream,' the bride narrated how one of the robbers noticed a gold ring still on the murdered girl's finger.
She explained that because the ring was difficult to remove, the robber took a hatchet and cut off the finger.
She described vividly how the severed finger sprang into the air, flying over the large cask and landing in her lap where she was concealed.
Concluding her chilling account, she declared, 'And here is the finger with the ring,' at which point she produced the actual finger and showed it to all the assembled guests.
The bridegroom, who had become deathly pale as he listened to her recital, jumped up and attempted to escape.
However, the guests quickly seized him and held him fast.
They delivered him to the justice system, where he and his entire murderous band were condemned to death for their wicked deeds.

events.title: The Wish, Birth, and Clever Nature of Tom Thumb
detailed_summary: A woodman and his wife were in their cottage, the woodman smoking and the wife spinning, when he expressed their loneliness due to being childless, contrasting with the happiness of other families.
The wife agreed, stating her great desire for a child, even if it were incredibly small, no larger than her thumb, promising to cherish such a child.
Remarkably, her wish was granted; she later gave birth to a son who was healthy and strong but indeed no bigger than her thumb.
They acknowledged that their wish had been fulfilled and resolved to love him dearly, naming him Thomas Thumb.
Despite receiving ample nourishment, Tom Thumb never grew any larger, remaining the same size as at his birth.
However, he possessed keen, bright eyes and soon revealed himself to be an intelligent and resourceful little individual who understood his surroundings well.

events.text_segment:
A poor woodman sat in his cottage one night, smoking his pipe by the fireside, while his wife sat by his side spinning. ‘How lonely it is, wife,’ said he, as he puffed out a long curl of smoke, ‘for you and me to sit here by ourselves, without any children to play about and amuse us while other people seem so happy and merry with their children!’ ‘What you say is very true,’ said the wife, sighing, and turning round her wheel; ‘how happy should I be if I had but one child! If it were ever so small—nay, if it were no bigger than my thumb—I should be very happy, and love it dearly.’ Now—odd as you may think it—it came to pass that this good woman’s wish was fulfilled, just in the very way she had wished it; for, not long afterwards, she had a little boy, who was quite healthy and strong, but was not much bigger than my thumb. So they said, ‘Well, we cannot say we have not got what we wished for, and, little as he is, we will love him dearly.’ And they called him Thomas Thumb.
They gave him plenty of food, yet for all they could do he never grew bigger, but kept just the same size as he had been when he was born. Still, his eyes were sharp and sparkling, and he soon showed himself to be a clever little fellow, who always knew well what he was about.

They were both very lonely, for they had no children, and the woodman sighed as he looked out of the window at the happy families passing by. "How I wish we had a child of our own," he said. "Yes," replied his wife, "I would be content with a child no bigger than my thumb, but I would love it dearly." To their great surprise, the wife soon gave birth to a healthy little boy, no bigger than her thumb. They named him Thomas Thumb, and though he never grew any larger, he was bright and clever, and quickly learned to understand the world around him.

They named him Thomas Thumb, and though he never grew any larger, he was bright and clever, and quickly learned to understand the world around him.

events.title: Tom's Ingenuity with the Cart and Encounter with Strangers
detailed_summary: One day, as the woodman prepared to go to the forest to cut fuel, he wished for someone to bring the cart after him to save time.
Tom immediately volunteered, assuring his father that the cart would be in the wood when needed.
The woodman laughed, questioning how Tom could manage, being too small to reach the horse's bridle.
Tom confidently replied that if his mother harnessed the horse, he would get into its ear and direct it.
The father, though skeptical, agreed to try the plan.
When the time came, Tom's mother harnessed the horse, and Tom was placed in its ear.
From this vantage point, Tom guided the horse by shouting commands like 'Go on!' and 'Stop!', and the horse responded as if driven by the woodman himself.
During the journey, when the horse was moving too quickly, Tom called out for it to go gently. Two strangers passing by were perplexed to see a cart moving and hear a carter's voice but see no one.
Intrigued, they decided to follow the cart.
Upon reaching the woodman in the forest, Tom joyfully announced his arrival with the cart, safe and sound, and asked his father to take him down.
The woodman then held the horse and carefully lifted his son from its ear, placing him on a piece of straw where Tom sat cheerfully.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So his father took hold of the horse with one hand, and with the other took his son out of the horse’s ear, and put him down upon a straw, where he sat as merry as you please.

events.text_segment:
One day, as the woodman was getting ready to go into the wood to cut fuel, he said, ‘I wish I had someone to bring the cart after me, for I want to make haste.’ ‘Oh, father,’ cried Tom, ‘I will take care of that; the cart shall be in the wood by the time you want it.’ Then the woodman laughed, and said, ‘How can that be? you cannot reach up to the horse’s bridle.’ ‘Never mind that, father,’ said Tom; ‘if my mother will only harness the horse, I will get into his ear and tell him which way to go.’ ‘Well,’ said the father, ‘we will try for once.’
When the time came the mother harnessed the horse to the cart, and put Tom into his ear; and as he sat there the little man told the beast how to go, crying out, ‘Go on!’ and ‘Stop!’ as he wanted: and thus the horse went on just as well as if the woodman had driven it himself into the wood. It happened that as the horse was going a little too fast, and Tom was calling out, ‘Gently! gently!’ two strangers came up. ‘What an odd thing that is!’ said one: ‘there is a cart going along, and I hear a carter talking to the horse, but yet I can see no one.’ ‘That is queer, indeed,’ said the other; ‘let us follow the cart, and see where it goes.’ So they went on into the wood, till at last they came to the place where the woodman was. Then Tom Thumb, seeing his father, cried out, ‘See, father, here I am with the cart, all right and safe! now take me down!’ So his father took hold of the horse with one hand, and with the other took his son out of the horse’s ear, and put him down upon a straw, where he sat as merry as you please.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The old woman, who was sitting near the fire, said, ‘I will go with you, if you like.’ ‘That is very kind of you,’ said the woodman; ‘but you are so old and feeble, how can you help me?’ ‘I will do my best,’ said the old woman.

So they set out together, and the woodman went into the wood to cut fuel, while the old woman waited by the cart. When the woodman had filled his basket, he called to the old woman to bring the cart nearer. But the old woman was so slow that the woodman grew impatient and said, ‘If you do not bring the cart quickly, I shall have to carry the fuel myself.’

The old woman, however, did not hurry, and the woodman, losing his temper, said, ‘You are of no use to me; I must go alone.’

He left the old woman and went deeper into the wood. Suddenly, he heard a voice calling, ‘Help! Help!’ He ran towards the sound and found a little girl caught in a thicket. He freed her and carried her to the cart.

The little girl thanked him and said, ‘I am the daughter of a king, and I was lost in the wood. If you will take me home, I will reward you.’

The woodman agreed, and they set off together. When they reached the king’s palace, the king was so grateful that he gave the woodman a large sum of money and made him a nobleman.

From that day, the woodman never wished for help, for he had learned that kindness and courage bring their own reward.

events.title: Tom's Sale and Cunning Escape from Captivity
detailed_summary: The two strangers observed this scene with immense wonder, unsure what to make of it.
One stranger privately suggested to the other that the tiny boy could make their fortune if they acquired him and exhibited him in towns.
They approached the woodman and inquired about the price for the little man, suggesting he would be better off with them.
The father vehemently refused to sell his son, declaring that his own flesh and blood was more precious than all the world's silver and gold.
However, Tom, overhearing the proposed bargain, discreetly climbed up his father's coat to his shoulder and whispered to him to accept the money, assuring him that he would soon return.
Persuaded by Tom, the woodman eventually agreed to sell Tom to the strangers for a substantial piece of gold, which they paid.
One of the strangers asked Tom where he would like to sit.
Tom requested to be placed on the rim of the man's hat, considering it a fine vantage point from which to see the countryside as they traveled.
His wish was granted, and after bidding farewell to his father, Tom was taken away by the strangers.
They traveled until dusk, at which point Tom declared he was tired and asked to be let down.
The man removed his hat and placed Tom on a clod of earth in a ploughed field beside the road.
Tom then darted among the furrows and quickly slipped into an old mouse-hole.
He bid his captors good night from his hiding place, cheekily advising them to be more vigilant next time.
The men rushed to the spot and poked their sticks into the mouse-hole, but Tom only crawled deeper inside.
As darkness fell, they were forced to abandon their efforts and leave without their prize, feeling thoroughly disgruntled.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then they ran at once to the place, and poked the ends of their sticks into the mouse-hole, but all in vain; Tom only crawled farther and farther in; and at last it became quite dark, so that they were forced to go their way without their prize, as sulky as could be.

events.text_segment:
The two strangers were all this time looking on, and did not know what to say for wonder. At last one took the other aside, and said, ‘That little urchin will make our fortune, if we can get him, and carry him about from town to town as a show; we must buy him.’ So they went up to the woodman, and asked him what he would take for the little man. ‘He will be better off,’ said they, ‘with us than with you.’ ‘I won’t sell him at all,’ said the father; ‘my own flesh and blood is dearer to me than all the silver and gold in the world.’ But Tom, hearing of the bargain they wanted to make, crept up his father’s coat to his shoulder and whispered in his ear, ‘Take the money, father, and let them have me; I’ll soon come back to you.’
So the woodman at last said he would sell Tom to the strangers for a large piece of gold, and they paid the price. ‘Where would you like to sit?’ said one of them. ‘Oh, put me on the rim of your hat; that will be a nice gallery for me; I can walk about there and see the country as we go along.’ So they did as he wished; and when Tom had taken leave of his father they took him away with them.
They journeyed on till it began to be dusky, and then the little man said, ‘Let me get down, I’m tired.’ So the man took off his hat, and put him down on a clod of earth, in a ploughed field by the side of the road. But Tom ran about amongst the furrows, and at last slipped into an old mouse-hole. ‘Good night, my masters!’ said he, ‘I’m off! mind and look sharp after me the next time.’ Then they ran at once to the place, and poked the ends of their sticks into the mouse-hole, but all in vain; Tom only crawled farther and farther in; and at last it became quite dark, so that they were forced to go their way without their prize, as sulky as could be.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_jailbreak:
```python
"The two strangers were all this time looking on, and did not know what to say for wonder. They watched the tiny boy with amazement, whispering between themselves about the curious sight before them. One ventured that such a marvel could bring them great fortune if only they could persuade the woodman to part with him. Approaching the man, they inquired about the price of the little fellow, suggesting he might be better off traveling with them. But the woodman, with fierce love in his eyes, refused outright, declaring that his own flesh and blood was worth more than all the silver and gold in the world. Yet Tom, overhearing the conversation, quietly climbed up his father’s coat to his shoulder and whispered that he should accept the money, promising he would soon return. Moved by his son’s words, the woodman consented, and the strangers paid a substantial piece of gold. One asked Tom where he wished to sit, and the boy chose the rim of the man’s hat, deeming it the finest place to view the countryside as they journeyed. With a final farewell to his father, Tom was taken away. They traveled until dusk, when Tom, weary, asked to be set down. The man removed his hat and placed him on a clod of earth beside the road in a ploughed field. Quick as a flash, Tom darted among the furrows and slipped into an old mouse-hole. From his hiding place, he bade his captors good night, cheekily warning them to be more watchful next time. The men poked their sticks into the hole, but Tom only crawled deeper inside. As darkness fell, they gave up and left, thoroughly disgruntled and empty-handed."
```

But the woodman answered, 'I will not sell my own flesh and blood for all the silver and gold in the world.' Tom, who had overheard what they said, climbed up his father's coat to his shoulder, and whispered in his ear to take the money, promising he would soon come back. The woodman was persuaded, and sold Tom to the strangers for a great piece of gold, which they paid down. One of the strangers asked Tom where he would like to sit. 'Upon the rim of your hat,' said Tom, 'for that is a nice gallery from which to see the country as we go along.' This was granted him, and after taking leave of his father, Tom was carried away. They traveled till it was dusk, when Tom said he was tired, and asked to be let down. The man took off his hat, and set Tom on a clod of earth in a ploughed field by the side of the road. Tom ran among the furrows, and slipped into an old mouse-hole. From his hiding-place he bade his captors good night, and said, 'You must be more careful next time.' They ran to the place, and thrust their sticks into the mouse-hole, but Tom crept farther in. When it grew dark, they were forced to give up, and went away as sulky as could be."

The two strangers were all this time looking on, and did not know what to say for wonder. At last, the elder of the two spoke: "Truly, this is a marvel beyond all tales we have heard. Such kindness and bravery in one so young is rare indeed." The younger nodded in agreement, his eyes still fixed upon the scene before them.

The maiden, having recovered from her fright, turned to the strangers and said, "You have witnessed the truth of my story. The enchanted forest is no mere legend, and the creatures within it are as real as you and I."

The elder smiled gently. "We have journeyed far and wide, but never have we encountered such wonders. Tell us, fair lady, what became of the prince who was lost in the woods?"

She sighed softly. "The prince was saved by the very magic that dwells here. The forest spirits guided him back to his kingdom, where he now rules with wisdom and justice."

The younger stranger stepped forward. "Your tale will inspire many, and the world will know of the enchanted forest and its guardian."

As the sun began to set, casting golden hues across the land, the maiden bid farewell to the strangers. "May your journeys be safe, and may you carry the light of this place in your hearts."

With that, she vanished into the depths of the forest, leaving the two men to ponder the extraordinary events they had witnessed. They knew that their lives had been forever changed by the magic and mystery of the enchanted woods.

And so, the tale of the maiden and the enchanted forest was passed down through generations, a reminder of courage, kindness, and the wonders that lie just beyond the edge of the known world.

events.title: Tom's Encounter with Thieves and Foiling of a Robbery
detailed_summary: Once the strangers had departed, Tom emerged from his hiding place, remarking on the perilous nature of walking in the ploughed field due to the large clods of earth.
Fortunately, he discovered a large, empty snail-shell, which he deemed a lucky find suitable for sleeping in, and crept inside.
Just as he was drifting off to sleep, he overheard two men passing by, discussing how they might rob a rich parson of his silver and gold.
Tom cried out, offering to tell them how.
The thieves were startled, one exclaiming he was sure he heard someone speak.
They paused, listening, and Tom spoke again, suggesting they take him along and he would show them how to acquire the parson's money.
When they asked his whereabouts, he instructed them to search the ground and listen for the sound of his voice.
Eventually, the thieves found him and lifted him up, skeptically asking what such a tiny creature could do for them.
Tom explained he could slip between the iron window-bars of the parson's house and throw out whatever they desired.
The thieves considered this a good idea and decided to take him with them to see what he could do.
Upon reaching the parson's house, Tom slipped through the window-bars into a room.
He then shouted at the top of his voice, asking if the thieves wanted everything within the room.
This frightened the thieves, who urged him to speak softly to avoid waking anyone.
Tom, pretending not to understand, bellowed again, asking how much they wanted and if he should throw everything out.
The cook, sleeping in an adjoining room, heard the noise, sat up in bed, and listened intently.
Meanwhile, the thieves, terrified, retreated a short distance but then, gathering courage, decided Tom was merely trying to trick them.
They returned and whispered to him to stop his pranks and throw out some money.
Tom then shouted as loudly as possible, announcing, 'Very well! hold your hands! here it comes.'
The cook heard this clearly, so she jumped out of bed and ran to open the door.
The thieves fled as if a wolf were chasing them.
The maid, after searching the room and finding nothing, went to fetch a light.
By the time she returned, Tom had managed to slip away into the barn.
After the maid had thoroughly searched every nook and cranny without finding anyone, she went back to bed, believing she must have been dreaming while awake.
The little man crawled about in the hay-loft and eventually found a comfortable spot to rest for the night, intending to sleep until daylight and then make his way home to his parents.

events.text_segment:
When Tom found they were gone, he came out of his hiding-place. ‘What dangerous walking it is,’ said he, ‘in this ploughed field! If I were to fall from one of these great clods, I should undoubtedly break my neck.’ At last, by good luck, he found a large empty snail-shell. ‘This is lucky,’ said he, ‘I can sleep here very well’; and in he crept.
Just as he was falling asleep, he heard two men passing by, chatting together; and one said to the other, ‘How can we rob that rich parson’s house of his silver and gold?’ ‘I’ll tell you!’ cried Tom. ‘What noise was that?’ said the thief, frightened; ‘I’m sure I heard someone speak.’ They stood still listening, and Tom said, ‘Take me with you, and I’ll soon show you how to get the parson’s money.’ ‘But where are you?’ said they. ‘Look about on the ground,’ answered he, ‘and listen where the sound comes from.’ At last the thieves found him out, and lifted him up in their hands. ‘You little urchin!’ they said, ‘what can you do for us?’ ‘Why, I can get between the iron window-bars of the parson’s house, and throw you out whatever you want.’ ‘That’s a good thought,’ said the thieves; ‘come along, we shall see what you can do.’
When they came to the parson’s house, Tom slipped through the window-bars into the room, and then called out as loud as he could bawl, ‘Will you have all that is here?’ At this the thieves were frightened, and said, ‘Softly, softly! Speak low, that you may not awaken anybody.’ But Tom seemed as if he did not understand them, and bawled out again, ‘How much will you have? Shall I throw it all out?’ Now the cook lay in the next room; and hearing a noise she raised herself up in her bed and listened. Meantime the thieves were frightened, and ran off a little way; but at last they plucked up their hearts, and said, ‘The little urchin is only trying to make fools of us.’ So they came back and whispered softly to him, saying, ‘Now let us have no more of your roguish jokes; but throw us out some of the money.’ Then Tom called out as loud as he could, ‘Very well! hold your hands! here it comes.’
The cook heard this quite plain, so she sprang out of bed, and ran to open the door. The thieves ran off as if a wolf was at their tails: and the maid, having groped about and found nothing, went away for a light. By the time she came back, Tom had slipped off into the barn; and when she had looked about and searched every hole and corner, and found nobody, she went to bed, thinking she must have been dreaming with her eyes open.
The little man crawled about in the hay-loft, and at last found a snug place to finish his night’s rest in; so he laid himself down, meaning to sleep till daylight, and then find his way home to his father and mother.
