LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
When Tom found they were gone, he came out of his hiding-place. The house was silent, and the only sound was the ticking of the old clock on the mantelpiece. He looked around cautiously, then crept to the window to see if anyone was nearby. The street was empty, and the sun was beginning to set, casting long shadows across the cobblestones.

Tom knew he had to act quickly. The mysterious disappearance of the villagers had left the town in a state of fear and confusion. No one knew where they had gone or why. Some whispered of dark magic, others of a curse that had befallen the land.

Determined to uncover the truth, Tom decided to visit the old forest at the edge of the village. It was said that strange creatures dwelled there, and that the forest held secrets older than time itself. As he stepped into the dense woods, the air grew cooler, and the light dimmed beneath the thick canopy of leaves.

He walked deeper into the forest, guided by a faint, shimmering light that seemed to beckon him forward. Suddenly, he came upon a clearing where a circle of ancient stones stood. In the center was a small, glowing orb pulsating with a soft blue light.

Tom reached out to touch the orb, and as his fingers brushed its surface, a voice echoed in his mind. "Brave one, you have been chosen to break the spell that binds your people."

Startled but resolute, Tom asked, "What must I do?"

The voice replied, "You must find the three keys hidden within the forest: the Key of Courage, the Key of Wisdom, and the Key of Heart. Only then can you unlock the spell and free your village."

With a nod, Tom set off on his quest. His first challenge was to find the Key of Courage. He ventured toward the dark cave where the bravest warriors dared not enter. Inside, he faced his fears—shadows that whispered doubts and illusions that tried to turn him back. But Tom pressed on, his heart steady and his resolve unshaken.

At the cave's end, he found a gleaming sword embedded in stone. Grasping its hilt, he felt a surge of strength and courage. The sword transformed into the Key of Courage, glowing warmly in his hand.

Next, Tom sought the Key of Wisdom. He climbed the tallest tree in the forest, where the ancient owl resided. The owl challenged him with riddles and puzzles, testing his mind and understanding. After many trials, Tom answered correctly and was gifted the Key of Wisdom, a shining feather that sparkled with knowledge.

Finally, Tom searched for the Key of Heart. He came upon a wounded deer trapped in a hunter's snare. Gently freeing the creature, he tended to its wounds with care and kindness. The deer transformed into a radiant light, bestowing upon Tom the Key of Heart—a glowing gem that pulsed with compassion.

With all three keys in hand, Tom returned to the circle of stones. Placing each key into its corresponding slot, the orb's light intensified, enveloping the forest and spreading toward the village.

Suddenly, the villagers reappeared, freed from the spell that had held them captive. They rejoiced and thanked Tom for his bravery, wisdom, and kindness.

From that day forward, the village prospered, and Tom was remembered as the hero who saved them all. The forest, once feared, became a place of wonder and magic, reminding everyone that courage, wisdom, and heart could overcome even the darkest of spells.

events.title: Tom's Misadventure Inside a Cow and its Fatal Consequence
detailed_summary: Tom's plans were unfortunately disrupted by a series of misfortunes.
The cook rose early before daybreak to feed the cows.
She went directly to the hay-loft and took a large bundle of hay, unknowingly carrying Tom, who was fast asleep within it.
Tom continued to sleep and only awoke when he found himself in the mouth of a cow; the cook had placed the hay in the cow's manger, and the cow had scooped Tom up in a mouthful.
He initially exclaimed his surprise, wondering how he had ended up in a mill.
However, he soon realized his actual location and knew he had to be very careful to avoid being crushed between the cow's teeth.
Eventually, he slid down into the cow's stomach.
He commented on the darkness, noting the lack of windows and remarking that a candle would have been useful.
Although he tried to make the best of his unfortunate situation, he greatly disliked his new quarters.
His discomfort was compounded by the continuous arrival of more hay, which progressively reduced the space available to him.
Finally, he cried out as loudly as he could, pleading for no more hay to be brought.

The maid happened to be milking the cow at that very moment. Hearing someone speak but seeing no one, and being certain it was the same voice she had heard during the night, she was so terrified that she fell from her stool, knocking over the milk-pail.
As soon as she recovered, she ran as fast as possible to her master, the parson, exclaiming that the cow was talking.
The parson dismissed her claim, telling her she must be mad.
Nevertheless, he accompanied her to the cow-house to investigate the matter.
They had barely crossed the threshold when Tom called out again, 'Don’t bring me any more hay!'
This time, the parson himself was frightened and, concluding the cow must be bewitched, ordered his man to kill her immediately.
The cow was consequently killed and butchered, and its stomach, where Tom was trapped, was thrown out onto a dunghill.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But alas! how woefully he was undone! what crosses and sorrows happen to us all in this world!
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So the cow was killed, and cut up; and the stomach, in which Tom lay, was thrown out upon a dunghill.

events.text_segment:
But alas! how woefully he was undone! what crosses and sorrows happen to us all in this world! The cook got up early, before daybreak, to feed the cows; and going straight to the hay-loft, carried away a large bundle of hay, with the little man in the middle of it, fast asleep. He still, however, slept on, and did not awake till he found himself in the mouth of the cow; for the cook had put the hay into the cow’s rick, and the cow had taken Tom up in a mouthful of it. ‘Good lack-a-day!’ said he, ‘how came I to tumble into the mill?’ But he soon found out where he really was; and was forced to have all his wits about him, that he might not get between the cow’s teeth, and so be crushed to death. At last down he went into her stomach. ‘It is rather dark,’ said he; ‘they forgot to build windows in this room to let the sun in; a candle would be no bad thing.’
Though he made the best of his bad luck, he did not like his quarters at all; and the worst of it was, that more and more hay was always coming down, and the space left for him became smaller and smaller. At last he cried out as loud as he could, ‘Don’t bring me any more hay! Don’t bring me any more hay!’
The maid happened to be just then milking the cow; and hearing someone speak, but seeing nobody, and yet being quite sure it was the same voice that she had heard in the night, she was so frightened that she fell off her stool, and overset the milk-pail. As soon as she could pick herself up out of the dirt, she ran off as fast as she could to her master the parson, and said, ‘Sir, sir, the cow is talking!’ But the parson said, ‘Woman, thou art surely mad!’ However, he went with her into the cow-house, to try and see what was the matter.
Scarcely had they set foot on the threshold, when Tom called out, ‘Don’t bring me any more hay!’ Then the parson himself was frightened; and thinking the cow was surely bewitched, told his man to kill her on the spot. So the cow was killed, and cut up; and the stomach, in which Tom lay, was thrown out upon a dunghill.

But alas! how woefully he was undone! what crosses and sorrows happen to us all in this world! The poor man, who had set out with such high hopes and a heart full of courage, found himself beset by troubles at every turn. His journey, which began with the promise of fortune and happiness, soon became a tale of hardship and despair.

He wandered through dark forests where the shadows seemed to whisper of his misfortunes. The birds that once sang sweet melodies now seemed to mock his plight with their mournful cries. Each step he took was heavier than the last, burdened by the weight of his sorrows.

One day, as he sat beneath a withered tree, he encountered a wise old woman who looked upon him with kind eyes. "Why do you weep, young man?" she asked gently.

"I am undone," he replied, "for all my hopes have been dashed, and I know not where to turn."

The old woman smiled softly and said, "Though the road is hard and the night is long, remember that dawn always follows darkness. Take heart, for your trials are but a passage to a brighter day."

Encouraged by her words, the man rose and continued on his way. Though the path remained fraught with challenges, he faced them with renewed strength and determination. Along the way, he helped those he met, sharing what little he had, and in doing so, found a measure of peace.

At last, after many days and nights, he reached a village where kindness and joy abounded. The people welcomed him warmly, and he found a new home among them. His sorrows, though not forgotten, became the foundation upon which he built a life of happiness and contentment.

Thus, the tale reminds us that though we all endure crosses and sorrows in this world, perseverance and kindness can lead us through the darkest times to the light beyond.

events.title: Swallowed by a Wolf, Ingenious Trickery, and Miraculous Rescue
detailed_summary: Tom immediately began working to free himself from the cow's stomach, a task that proved difficult.
Just as he had managed to create enough space to get his head out, another misfortune befell him.
A hungry wolf appeared, swallowed the entire stomach with Tom inside in a single gulp, and then ran off.
Tom, however, remained undaunted. Believing the wolf might enjoy a conversation, he called out, offering to show his 'good friend' a fantastic treat.
When the wolf inquired about its location, Tom described his own father's house.

He provided specific instructions on how the wolf could crawl through the drain into the kitchen and then into the pantry, where it would find an abundance of delicacies like cakes, ham, beef, and more.
The wolf needed no second invitation and that very night, it went to the house, entered as Tom had described, and feasted to its satisfaction.
When it had eaten its fill and tried to leave, it discovered it had consumed so much that it could no longer fit back through the drain.
This was precisely what Tom had anticipated. He then began to shout and make as much noise as possible.
The wolf begged him to be quiet, warning that he would wake everyone in the house.
Tom retorted defiantly, stating that since the wolf had enjoyed its frolic, he now intended to be merry himself, and he continued to sing and shout at the top of his lungs.
The woodman and his wife, awakened by the commotion, peeked through a crack in the door and were terrified to see a wolf.
The woodman fetched his axe, and his wife a scythe.
The woodman instructed his wife to stay behind and, after he had struck the wolf on the head, she was to cut it open with the scythe.
Tom heard these instructions and cried out, 'Father, father! I am here, the wolf has swallowed me.'
His father, overjoyed, exclaimed that they had found their dear child again and told his wife not to use the scythe for fear of harming Tom.
The woodman then aimed a powerful blow at the wolf's head, killing it instantly.
Once the wolf was dead, they cut open its body and freed Tommy.
The father expressed the great fears they had experienced for Tom's safety.
Tom replied that he felt he had traveled all over the world in various ways since they last parted, and he was now very glad to be home and breathe fresh air again.
When his father asked where he had been, Tom recounted his adventures: in a mouse-hole, a snail-shell, down a cow's throat, and inside a wolf's belly, yet he had returned safe and sound.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘I have been in a mouse-hole—and in a snail-shell—and down a cow’s throat—and in the wolf’s belly; and yet here I am again, safe and sound.’

events.text_segment:
Tom soon set himself to work to get out, which was not a very easy task; but at last, just as he had made room to get his head out, fresh ill-luck befell him. A hungry wolf sprang out, and swallowed up the whole stomach, with Tom in it, at one gulp, and ran away.
Tom, however, was still not disheartened; and thinking the wolf would not dislike having some chat with him as he was going along, he called out, ‘My good friend, I can show you a famous treat.’ ‘Where’s that?’ said the wolf. ‘In such and such a house,’ said Tom, describing his own father’s house. ‘You can crawl through the drain into the kitchen and then into the pantry, and there you will find cakes, ham, beef, cold chicken, roast pig, apple-dumplings, and everything that your heart can wish.’
The wolf did not want to be asked twice; so that very night he went to the house and crawled through the drain into the kitchen, and then into the pantry, and ate and drank there to his heart’s content. As soon as he had had enough he wanted to get away; but he had eaten so much that he could not go out by the same way he came in.
This was just what Tom had reckoned upon; and now he began to set up a great shout, making all the noise he could. ‘Will you be easy?’ said the wolf; ‘you’ll awaken everybody in the house if you make such a clatter.’ ‘What’s that to me?’ said the little man; ‘you have had your frolic, now I’ve a mind to be merry myself’; and he began, singing and shouting as loud as he could.
The woodman and his wife, being awakened by the noise, peeped through a crack in the door; but when they saw a wolf was there, you may well suppose that they were sadly frightened; and the woodman ran for his axe, and gave his wife a scythe. ‘Do you stay behind,’ said the woodman, ‘and when I have knocked him on the head you must rip him up with the scythe.’ Tom heard all this, and cried out, ‘Father, father! I am here, the wolf has swallowed me.’ And his father said, ‘Heaven be praised! we have found our dear child again’; and he told his wife not to use the scythe for fear she should hurt him. Then he aimed a great blow, and struck the wolf on the head, and killed him on the spot! and when he was dead they cut open his body, and set Tommy free. ‘Ah!’ said the father, ‘what fears we have had for you!’ ‘Yes, father,’ answered he; ‘I have travelled all over the world, I think, in one way or other, since we parted; and now I am very glad to come home and get fresh air again.’ ‘Why, where have you been?’ said his father. ‘I have been in a mouse-hole—and in a snail-shell—and down a cow’s throat—and in the wolf’s belly; and yet here I am again, safe and sound.’

This tale, like many in the collection of Grimms' Fairy Tales, reminds us that even in the darkest moments, hope and perseverance can lead to salvation. Tom's story is one of many that teach valuable lessons about bravery, kindness, and the strength of the human spirit.

events.title: Joyful Reunion, Renewed Promises, and the Comfort of Home
detailed_summary: His parents declared that now he was back, they would not sell him again for all the riches in the world.
They hugged and kissed their beloved little son, and gave him plenty of food and drink, for he was very hungry.
They then fetched new clothes for him, as his old ones had been completely spoiled during his journey.
So Master Thumb stayed at home with his father and mother, living in peace.
Although he had been a great traveller, had experienced many remarkable things, and enjoyed recounting his adventures, he always acknowledged that, ultimately, there is no place like home.

events.title: The Miller's Impossible Boast and the King's Cruel Demand
detailed_summary: A miller, residing near a wood and a stream, had a very beautiful, shrewd, and clever daughter.
The miller, filled with pride, boasted to the king of the land that his daughter possessed the ability to spin straw into gold.
The king, who was very avaricious, was enticed by this claim and immediately summoned the miller's daughter to his presence.
He led her to a chamber in his palace filled with a large quantity of straw, provided her with a spinning-wheel, and issued a dire ultimatum.
The king commanded her to transform all the straw into gold before the morning, threatening her life if she failed.
The poor maiden protested in vain, explaining that her father's statement was merely a foolish boast and that she lacked any such skill.
Despite her pleas, the chamber door was locked, leaving her alone and in despair.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By the side of a wood, in a country a long way off, ran a fine stream of water; and upon the stream there stood a mill.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was in vain that the poor maiden said that it was only a silly boast of her father, for that she could do no such thing as spin straw into gold: the chamber door was locked, and she was left alone.

events.text_segment: By the side of a wood, in a country a long way off, ran a fine stream of water; and upon the stream there stood a mill. The miller’s house was close by, and the miller, you must know, had a very beautiful daughter. She was, moreover, very shrewd and clever; and the miller was so proud of her, that he one day told the king of the land, who used to come and hunt in the wood, that his daughter could spin gold out of straw. Now this king was very fond of money; and when he heard the miller’s boast his greediness was raised, and he sent for the girl to be brought before him. Then he led her to a chamber in his palace where there was a great heap of straw, and gave her a spinning-wheel, and said, ‘All this must be spun into gold before morning, as you love your life.’ It was in vain that the poor maiden said that it was only a silly boast of her father, for that she could do no such thing as spin straw into gold: the chamber door was locked, and she was left alone.

In this mill lived a miller, who had a very beautiful daughter. She was so beautiful, indeed, that no one could look at her without admiring her; and she was so clever and shrewd that she could spin the finest flax and wool. One day the miller, proud of his daughter's beauty and cleverness, went to the king and boasted that his daughter could spin straw into gold. The king, who was very greedy, was delighted to hear this, and immediately sent for the miller's daughter. When she came, he led her to a large chamber filled with straw, and gave her a spinning-wheel, saying, "If by morning you have not spun all this straw into gold, you shall lose your life." The poor girl was terrified, for she had no such skill, and begged the king to spare her, explaining that her father had only told a foolish lie. But the king locked the door and left her alone in the chamber, with the dreadful task before her.

events.title: The Mysterious Helper and the First Golden Transformation
detailed_summary: Confined to a corner of the room, the miller's daughter began to lament her unfortunate situation.
Suddenly, the door opened, and an amusingly odd little man entered and inquired about the cause of her tears.
She explained her predicament: she was required to spin straw into gold, a task she did not know how to perform.
The hobgoblin then asked what she would give him if he were to accomplish the task for her.
The maiden offered her necklace in return for his help.
He accepted her offer, positioned himself at the spinning wheel, and, while whistling and singing a rhythmic chant, began his work.
The wheel spun rapidly and joyfully, and soon all the straw was successfully transformed into gold.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: She sat down in one corner of the room, and began to bewail her hard fate; when on a sudden the door opened, and a droll-looking little man hobbled in, and said, ‘Good morrow to you, my good lass; what are you weeping for?’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And round about the wheel went merrily; the work was quickly done, and the straw was all spun into gold.

events.text_segment:
She sat down in one corner of the room, and began to bewail her hard fate; when on a sudden the door opened, and a droll-looking little man hobbled in, and said, ‘Good morrow to you, my good lass; what are you weeping for?’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘I must spin this straw into gold, and I know not how.’ ‘What will you give me,’ said the hobgoblin, ‘to do it for you?’ ‘My necklace,’ replied the maiden. He took her at her word, and sat himself down to the wheel, and whistled and sang:
‘Round about, round about,
    Lo and behold!
  Reel away, reel away,
    Straw into gold!’
And round about the wheel went merrily; the work was quickly done, and the straw was all spun into gold.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
She sat down in one corner of the room, and began to bewail her hard fate; when on a sudden the door opened, and a droll-looking little man hobbled in, and said, ‘Good morrow to you, my good lass; what are you weeping for?’

‘I am to spin straw into gold,’ she answered, ‘and I do not know how to do it.’

‘Ah!’ said the little man, ‘what will you give me if I spin it for you?’

‘My necklace,’ she answered.

‘Agreed,’ said the little man; and he sat down to the wheel, and began to whistle and sing:

“Turn, turn, little wheel,
Spin the gold as I sing and tell.”

The wheel went round and round, and the little man sang and whistled, and before morning all the straw was spun into gold.

events.title: The King's Escalating Greed and a Second Bargain

Overwhelmed and unsure of what to do, she sat down and wept again.

Her small helper accepted the ring, returned to the spinning wheel, and resumed his work, accompanied by his usual whistling and song.

events.title: The Ultimate Demand, a Queen's Promise, and a Desperate Pact
detailed_summary: The king was extremely delighted to see the vast amount of glittering treasure, yet his desire for more remained unquenched.

He promised that if she succeeded, she would become his queen.

The little man then proposed that she promise him her first child, should she become queen.
The miller's daughter, thinking such an event might never occur and seeing no other way to complete the task, agreed to his terms.
The wheel spun once more to the familiar song, and the manikin again transformed the entire heap into gold.
When the king arrived in the morning and found all his demands met, he was compelled to honor his promise, marrying the miller's daughter and making her queen.

events.title: The Forgotten Promise and the Dwarf's Grim Condition
detailed_summary: Upon the birth of her first child, the new queen was immensely happy and had forgotten about the dwarf and her promise.
However, one day, while she was in her room playing with her baby, the dwarf appeared and reminded her of their agreement.
The queen was deeply distressed by this reminder of her misfortune.
She offered him all the wealth of the kingdom if he would release her from the promise, but he refused.
Finally, her evident sorrow and tears softened him somewhat.
He proposed a condition: he would give her three days, and if, within that time, she could tell him his name, she would be allowed to keep her child.

events.title: The Queen's Frantic Search for the Dwarf's Name
detailed_summary: The queen spent the entire night wide awake, racking her brain for every unusual name she had ever encountered.
She also dispatched messengers throughout the land to search for new and uncommon names.
The following day, when the little man arrived, she began listing names such as Timothy, Ichabod, Benjamin, and Jeremiah, along with every other name she could recall.
To each name she proposed, the little man simply replied, 'Madam, that is not my name.'
On the second day, the queen tried presenting all the comical names she had managed to gather, like Bandy-legs, Hunchback, and Crook-shanks.
However, the little gentleman consistently responded to each of these suggestions with the same dismissal: 'Madam, that is not my name.'

events.title: A Messenger's Fortuitous Discovery of the Secret Name
characters: Little man (dwarf, as observed by messenger)
detailed_summary: On the third day, one of the queen's messengers returned from his search.
He reported that he had traveled for two days without discovering any new names.
However, on the previous day, while ascending a high hill amidst a forest where foxes and hares coexisted, he came across a small hut.
In front of this hut, a fire was burning, and around it, a peculiar little dwarf was dancing on one leg.
The dwarf was simultaneously singing a song which revealed his identity.

The lyrics of his song were: "Merrily the feast I’ll make. Today I’ll brew, tomorrow bake; Merrily I’ll dance and sing, For next day will a stranger bring. Little does my lady dream Rumpelstiltskin is my name!"

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Rumpelstiltskin is my name!”

“Merrily the feast I’ll make.
  Today I’ll brew, tomorrow bake;
  Merrily I’ll dance and sing,
  For next day will a stranger bring.
  Little does my lady dream
  Rumpelstiltskin is my name!”

events.title: Rumpelstiltskin Revealed and His Furious Demise
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the name 'Rumpelstiltskin', the queen leaped with joy.
As soon as her diminutive visitor arrived, she seated herself on her throne and summoned her entire court to witness the unfolding events, seemingly for amusement.
The nurse stood beside her, holding the baby as if fully prepared to surrender him.
The little man began to chuckle, anticipating taking the child to his woodland hut.
He then triumphantly asked, 'Now, lady, what is my name?'
The queen playfully offered incorrect guesses such as 'Is it JOHN?' and 'Is it TOM?', then 'Is it JEMMY?', all of which he denied.
Then, with a sly demeanor, she inquired, 'Can your name be RUMPELSTILTSKIN?'
The little man, utterly astonished and enraged, cried out that a witch must have revealed his name.
In his fury, he stamped his right foot so forcefully into the floor that it became stuck, requiring him to use both hands to pull it free.
He then departed as swiftly as possible, while the nurse laughed, the baby cooed, and the entire court jeered at him for his fruitless efforts.
They mockingly wished him a good morning and a merry feast, addressing him as 'Mr RUMPLESTILTSKIN!'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the queen heard this she jumped for joy, and as soon as her little friend came she sat down upon her throne, and called all her court round to enjoy the fun; and the nurse stood by her side with the baby in her arms, as if it was quite ready to be given up.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘We wish you a very good morning, and a merry feast, Mr RUMPLESTILTSKIN!’

events.text_segment:
When the queen heard this she jumped for joy, and as soon as her little friend came she sat down upon her throne, and called all her court round to enjoy the fun; and the nurse stood by her side with the baby in her arms, as if it was quite ready to be given up. Then the little man began to chuckle at the thought of having the poor child, to take home with him to his hut in the woods; and he cried out, ‘Now, lady, what is my name?’ ‘Is it JOHN?’ asked she. ‘No, madam!’ ‘Is it TOM?’ ‘No, madam!’ ‘Is it JEMMY?’ ‘It is not.’ ‘Can your name be RUMPELSTILTSKIN?’ said the lady slyly. ‘Some witch told you that!—some witch told you that!’ cried the little man, and dashed his right foot in a rage so deep into the floor, that he was forced to lay hold of it with both hands to pull it out.
Then he made the best of his way off, while the nurse laughed and the baby crowed; and all the court jeered at him for having had so much trouble for nothing, and said, ‘We wish you a very good morning, and a merry feast, Mr RUMPLESTILTSKIN!’

As the festivities continued, the queen's heart swelled with happiness, knowing that her beloved child was surrounded by love and kindness. The kingdom rejoiced, and tales of the baby's arrival spread far and wide, bringing hope and joy to all who heard them. Thus, the day was marked as one of great blessing and celebration in the realm.

events.title: Gretel's Self-Appreciation and Culinary Habits
detailed_summary: Gretel, a cook, takes pleasure in her appearance, particularly her red-heeled shoes, and considers herself pretty.
Upon returning home, she customarily drinks wine out of happiness.
The wine stimulates her appetite, leading her to sample the food she is cooking until she feels satisfied.
She justifies this habit by reasoning that a cook must be familiar with the taste of the dishes prepared.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘The cook must know what the food is like.’

events.text_segment: There was once a cook named Gretel, who wore shoes with red heels, and when she walked out with them on, she turned herself this way and that, was quite happy and thought: ‘You certainly are a pretty girl!’ And when she came home she drank, in her gladness of heart, a draught of wine, and as wine excites a desire to eat, she tasted the best of whatever she was cooking until she was satisfied, and said: ‘The cook must know what the food is like.’

events.title: Guest Preparation and Gretel's First Indulgence
detailed_summary: The master instructs Gretel to prepare two fowls with great care for an evening guest.
Gretel prepares the chickens, puts them on a spit, and sets them by the fire to roast as evening approaches.
As the fowls are nearly cooked, the guest has not yet shown up.
Gretel warns her master that the fowls must be removed from the fire soon to prevent them from being overcooked and that it would be a shame if they weren't eaten at their peak juiciness.
The master decides to personally go and bring the guest.
With the master gone, Gretel feels hot and thirsty from being near the fire and contemplates that the guest's arrival is uncertain.
She decides to go to the cellar for a drink.
She pours herself wine, blesses it, takes a substantial drink, and then another, believing wine's enjoyment should be continuous.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It came to pass that the master one day said to her: ‘Gretel, there is a guest coming this evening; prepare me two fowls very daintily.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: She ran down, set a jug, said: ‘God bless it for you, Gretel,’ and took a good drink, and thought that wine should flow on, and should not be interrupted, and took yet another hearty draught.

events.text_segment: It came to pass that the master one day said to her: ‘Gretel, there is a guest coming this evening; prepare me two fowls very daintily.’ ‘I will see to it, master,’ answered Gretel. She killed two fowls, scalded them, plucked them, put them on the spit, and towards evening set them before the fire, that they might roast. The fowls began to turn brown, and were nearly ready, but the guest had not yet arrived. Then Gretel called out to her master: ‘If the guest does not come, I must take the fowls away from the fire, but it will be a sin and a shame if they are not eaten the moment they are at their juiciest.’ The master said: ‘I will run myself, and fetch the guest.’ When the master had turned his back, Gretel laid the spit with the fowls on one side, and thought: ‘Standing so long by the fire there, makes one sweat and thirsty; who knows when they will come? Meanwhile, I will run into the cellar, and take a drink.’ She ran down, set a jug, said: ‘God bless it for you, Gretel,’ and took a good drink, and thought that wine should flow on, and should not be interrupted, and took yet another hearty draught.

Then, feeling the pleasure of the wine, she took another, reasoning that the enjoyment of wine should be continuous.

events.title: Gretel Succumbs to Temptation and Consumes Both Chickens
detailed_summary: Gretel returns to the kitchen, puts the fowls back by the fire, bastes them, and turns the spit with enthusiasm.
The appealing smell of the roasting meat tempts Gretel to taste it, thinking something might be amiss.
She touches the fowl with her finger, exclaims how delicious it is, and laments that it's not being eaten at the optimal time.
She checks the window for her master and the guest but sees no one, then returns to the fowls.
Noticing one wing appears to be burning, she decides to cut it off and eat it, which she does with enjoyment.
After finishing the first wing, she reasons that the other wing must also be eaten to prevent the master from noticing anything missing, so she consumes it too.
Still seeing no sign of her master, she speculates that perhaps they are not coming at all and have gone elsewhere.
She then decides to enjoy herself further, takes another large drink from the cellar, and eats the entire first chicken with great pleasure, reasoning that God's gifts shouldn't be wasted.
With the first chicken consumed and the master still absent, Gretel looks at the second chicken and rationalizes that what applies to one should apply to the other, as they belong together.
Believing another drink wouldn't hurt, she takes one more hearty swig and proceeds to eat the second chicken as well.

events.text_segment: Then she went and put the fowls down again to the fire, basted them, and drove the spit merrily round. But as the roast meat smelt so good, Gretel thought: ‘Something might be wrong, it ought to be tasted!’ She touched it with her finger, and said: ‘Ah! how good fowls are! It certainly is a sin and a shame that they are not eaten at the right time!’ She ran to the window, to see if the master was not coming with his guest, but she saw no one, and went back to the fowls and thought: ‘One of the wings is burning! I had better take it off and eat it.’ So she cut it off, ate it, and enjoyed it, and when she had done, she thought: ‘The other must go down too, or else master will observe that something is missing.’ When the two wings were eaten, she went and looked for her master, and did not see him. It suddenly occurred to her: ‘Who knows? They are perhaps not coming at all, and have turned in somewhere.’ Then she said: ‘Well, Gretel, enjoy yourself, one fowl has been cut into, take another drink, and eat it up entirely; when it is eaten you will have some peace, why should God’s good gifts be spoilt?’ So she ran into the cellar again, took an enormous drink and ate up the one chicken in great glee. When one of the chickens was swallowed down, and still her master did not come, Gretel looked at the other and said: ‘What one is, the other should be likewise, the two go together; what’s right for the one is right for the other; I think if I were to take another draught it would do me no harm.’ So she took another hearty drink, and let the second chicken follow the first.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Then she went and put the fowls down again to the fire, basted them, and drove the spit merrily round. As she did so, she thought to herself, "If only the prince would come and see me now, he would surely be pleased with my cooking." The kitchen was warm and fragrant, filled with the savory aroma of roasting meat and herbs. Outside, the sun was setting, casting a golden glow through the small window.

Suddenly, there was a knock at the door. Startled, she wiped her hands on her apron and went to open it. To her surprise, there stood the prince himself, looking weary from his travels but smiling kindly. "Good evening," he said. "I was passing by and caught the delightful scent of your cooking. Might I share your meal?"

She blushed but nodded eagerly, inviting him inside. They sat together by the fire, and she served the fowls, which were tender and flavorful. As they ate, the prince told her tales of distant lands and brave adventures. She listened with wide eyes, enchanted by his stories.

When the meal was finished, the prince took her hand and said, "Your kindness and skill have warmed my heart more than this fire ever could. Will you come with me to the castle and be my bride?"

Tears of joy filled her eyes as she agreed. From that day forward, they lived happily together, the humble cook and the noble prince, proving that kindness and courage can change one's destiny.

events.title: Gretel's Deception and the Guest's Terrified Flight
detailed_summary: While Gretel is finishing the chickens, her master arrives, announcing that the guest is following closely behind him.
Gretel assures her master that she will serve the meal shortly.
Meanwhile, the master checks the table setting and begins to sharpen the large carving knife on the steps.
The guest arrives and knocks politely at the door.
Gretel goes to see who it is, and upon seeing the guest, she puts her finger to her lips, urging silence.
She frantically tells the guest to leave as quickly as possible, warning him that if her master finds him, it will be bad for him.
Gretel falsely claims that although her master invited him to supper, his actual plan is to cut off the guest's two ears, pointing to the sound of the knife being sharpened as proof.
The guest hears the sound of the knife sharpening and, terrified, hurries down the steps as fast as he can.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: While she was making the most of it, her master came and cried: ‘Hurry up, Gretel, the guest is coming directly after me!’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The guest heard the sharpening, and hurried down the steps again as fast as he could.

events.text_segment: While she was making the most of it, her master came and cried: ‘Hurry up, Gretel, the guest is coming directly after me!’ ‘Yes, sir, I will soon serve up,’ answered Gretel. Meantime the master looked to see that the table was properly laid, and took the great knife, wherewith he was going to carve the chickens, and sharpened it on the steps. Presently the guest came, and knocked politely and courteously at the house-door. Gretel ran, and looked to see who was there, and when she saw the guest, she put her finger to her lips and said: ‘Hush! hush! go away as quickly as you can, if my master catches you it will be the worse for you; he certainly did ask you to supper, but his intention is to cut off your two ears. Just listen how he is sharpening the knife for it!’ The guest heard the sharpening, and hurried down the steps again as fast as he could.

‘Never fear,’ said Gretel, ‘I will serve the meal directly.’

Soon after, the guest arrived and knocked politely at the door.

‘But my master invited me to supper,’ said the guest.

‘That is true,’ said Gretel, ‘but he plans to cut off your two ears. Listen to the knife being sharpened!’

The guest heard the sound of the knife being sharpened and, terrified, he hurried down the steps as fast as he could.

events.title: Gretel's False Accusation and the Master's Misunderstood Pursuit
detailed_summary: Gretel immediately runs to her master, screaming and sarcastically remarking on the 'fine guest' he invited.
When the master asks what she means, Gretel claims the guest snatched the chickens from the dish just as she was about to serve them and ran away.
The master expresses his dismay at this 'nice trick' and bemoans the loss of the delicious chickens.
He wishes aloud that the guest had at least left him one chicken so he would have something to eat.
The master calls out for the guest to stop, but the guest, fearing for his safety, feigns deafness.
The master then pursues the guest, still holding the carving knife, shouting 'Just one, just one!'
He intends for the guest to leave him one chicken, but the guest misinterprets this cry, believing the master wants one of his ears.
Consequently, the guest runs as if his life depends on it, determined to escape with both his ears unharmed.

events.text_segment: Gretel was not idle; she ran screaming to her master, and cried: ‘You have invited a fine guest!’ ‘Why, Gretel? What do you mean by that?’ ‘Yes,’ said she, ‘he has taken the chickens which I was just going to serve up, off the dish, and has run away with them!’ ‘That’s a nice trick!’ said her master, and lamented the fine chickens. ‘If he had but left me one, so that something remained for me to eat.’ He called to him to stop, but the guest pretended not to hear. Then he ran after him with the knife still in his hand, crying: ‘Just one, just one,’ meaning that the guest should leave him just one chicken, and not take both. The guest, however, thought no otherwise than that he was to give up one of his ears, and ran as if fire were burning under him, in order to take them both with him.

chapters.chapter_title: THE OLD MAN AND HIS GRANDSON

events.title: The Old Man's Mistreatment and Isolation
detailed_summary: An elderly man experienced significant physical decline, including dimmed vision, hearing loss, trembling knees, and difficulty eating without spilling.
His son and daughter-in-law were repulsed by his condition and messy eating habits.
Consequently, they forced the grandfather to eat in isolation in a corner behind the stove.
He was served insufficient food in a basic earthenware bowl.
The old man would often gaze tearfully towards the family table, longing for inclusion.
During one meal, his trembling hands failed to hold the bowl, causing it to fall and break.
The young wife verbally reprimanded him for this, but he only responded with a sigh of resignation.
As a replacement, they provided him with a cheap wooden bowl from which he had to eat his meals.

events.text_segment: There was once a very old man, whose eyes had become dim, his ears dull of hearing, his knees trembled, and when he sat at table he could hardly hold the spoon, and spilt the broth upon the table-cloth or let it run out of his mouth. His son and his son’s wife were disgusted at this, so the old grandfather at last had to sit in the corner behind the stove, and they gave him his food in an earthenware bowl, and not even enough of it. And he used to look towards the table with his eyes full of tears. Once, too, his trembling hands could not hold the bowl, and it fell to the ground and broke. The young wife scolded him, but he said nothing and only sighed. Then they brought him a wooden bowl for a few half-pence, out of which he had to eat.

events.title: The Grandson's Innocent Words and Profound Lesson
detailed_summary: While the family was in this situation, the four-year-old grandson was observed on the ground, busily gathering small pieces of wood.
His father, who was the old man's son, noticed this and questioned him about his activity.
The child innocently explained that he was constructing a small feeding trough.
He further clarified that this trough was intended for his own father and mother to use for their meals when he became an adult, mirroring their treatment of the grandfather.

events.title: The Parents' Realization, Repentance, and Reconciliation
detailed_summary: Upon hearing their son's innocent yet profound statement, the husband and wife exchanged a meaningful look, struck by the implication of their child's actions.
Overcome with remorse and understanding of the lesson their child had inadvertently taught them, they both began to weep.
They immediately went to the old grandfather and brought him back to join them at the main family table.
From that point onward, they ensured he always ate his meals with the rest of the family, restoring his dignity.
Furthermore, they resolved to be patient and understanding, no longer expressing displeasure or scolding him if he happened to spill anything during meals.

events.title: The Wooden Calf Deception and Acquisition of a Real Cow
detailed_summary: A destitute peasant and his wife yearned for a cow but lacked the means to acquire one.
The peasant conceived a plan to have their acquaintance, the carpenter, construct a lifelike wooden calf, painted brown, which they hoped would eventually be mistaken for a real one or lead to one.
The carpenter fashioned the wooden calf, positioning its head as if it were grazing.
The following morning, the peasant instructed the cow-herd to take his small calf, which he claimed needed to be carried, to the pasture.
The cow-herd obliged, carrying the wooden calf to the pasture and placing it among the grass, remarking that it looked like it was already eating and would soon run on its own.
That evening, when the cow-herd was bringing the cattle home, he told the wooden calf that if it could eat its fill, it could also walk home, as he wasn't going to carry it.
The little peasant, waiting by his door, inquired about his missing calf when the herd returned without it.
The cow-herd replied that the calf was still in the field eating and had refused to accompany them.
The peasant insisted he must have his animal back, and they returned to the meadow together.
Upon arriving, they found the wooden calf was gone, evidently stolen.
The cow-herd suggested the calf had run away, but the peasant dismissed this notion.
The peasant brought the cow-herd before the mayor, who found the cow-herd negligent and ordered him to provide the peasant with a real cow as compensation for the lost calf.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was a certain village wherein no one lived but really rich peasants, and just one poor one, whom they called the little peasant.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The peasant, however, said: ‘Don’t tell me that,’ and led the cow-herd before the mayor, who for his carelessness condemned him to give the peasant a cow for the calf which had run away.

events.text_segment:
There was a certain village wherein no one lived but really rich peasants, and just one poor one, whom they called the little peasant. He had not even so much as a cow, and still less money to buy one, and yet he and his wife did so wish to have one. One day he said to her: ‘Listen, I have a good idea, there is our gossip the carpenter, he shall make us a wooden calf, and paint it brown, so that it looks like any other, and in time it will certainly get big and be a cow.’ the woman also liked the idea, and their gossip the carpenter cut and planed the calf, and painted it as it ought to be, and made it with its head hanging down as if it were eating.
Next morning when the cows were being driven out, the little peasant called the cow-herd in and said: ‘Look, I have a little calf there, but it is still small and has to be carried.’ The cow-herd said: ‘All right,’ and took it in his arms and carried it to the pasture, and set it among the grass. The little calf always remained standing like one which was eating, and the cow-herd said: ‘It will soon run by itself, just look how it eats already!’ At night when he was going to drive the herd home again, he said to the calf: ‘If you can stand there and eat your fill, you can also go on your four legs; I don’t care to drag you home again in my arms.’ But the little peasant stood at his door, and waited for his little calf, and when the cow-herd drove the cows through the village, and the calf was missing, he inquired where it was. The cow-herd answered: ‘It is still standing out there eating. It would not stop and come with us.’ But the little peasant said: ‘Oh, but I must have my beast back again.’ Then they went back to the meadow together, but someone had stolen the calf, and it was gone. The cow-herd said: ‘It must have run away.’ The peasant, however, said: ‘Don’t tell me that,’ and led the cow-herd before the mayor, who for his carelessness condemned him to give the peasant a cow for the calf which had run away.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
There was a certain village wherein no one lived but really rich peasants, and just one poor one, whom they called the little peasant. This little peasant and his wife were so poor that they had nothing but a small hut and a few chickens. Yet, they longed for a cow, for with a cow they could have milk and cheese and perhaps a little income. But alas, they had no money to buy one.

One day, the little peasant had an idea. He went to the carpenter and said, "Good man, could you make me a calf out of wood? Paint it brown, so it looks like a real one."

The carpenter agreed and set to work. He carved a small wooden calf, painting it brown and shaping its head as if it were grazing. When it was done, the little peasant was very pleased.

The next morning, he called the cow-herd and said, "Take my little calf to the pasture. It is small and cannot walk well, so you must carry it."

The cow-herd took the wooden calf in his arms and went to the meadow. There, he placed it among the grass and said, "Look, it is already eating, and soon it will run about on its own."

That evening, when the cow-herd was bringing the cattle home, he spoke to the wooden calf, "If you can eat your fill, then you can also walk home, for I will not carry you."

The little peasant waited by his door and asked, "Where is my calf?"

The cow-herd replied, "It is still in the field, eating, and will not come with us."

The peasant insisted, "I must have my calf back."

So they went together to the meadow, but the wooden calf was gone. It had been stolen.

The cow-herd said, "It must have run away."

But the little peasant said, "A wooden calf cannot run away."

He took the cow-herd before the mayor, who judged the matter. The mayor found the cow-herd negligent and ordered him to provide the little peasant with a real cow as compensation for the lost calf.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
There was a certain village wherein no one lived but really rich peasants, and just one poor one, whom they called the little peasant. This little peasant was so poor that he had nothing but a small piece of land and a little cottage. Despite his poverty, he was kind-hearted and always willing to help others.

One day, the little peasant went into the forest to gather firewood. As he was walking, he came upon a strange old man who was sitting by the side of the road. The old man looked tired and hungry, so the little peasant offered him some bread and water. The old man was very grateful and said, "Because you have shown me kindness, I will grant you a wish."

The little peasant thought for a moment and said, "I wish to be as rich as the other peasants in the village."

The old man smiled and said, "Very well. But remember, true wealth is not just gold and silver, but also kindness and happiness."

With that, the old man disappeared. The little peasant returned to his village, and to his surprise, he found that his small cottage had turned into a grand house, and his piece of land was now a vast estate. The other peasants were amazed and envious of his sudden wealth.

However, the little peasant did not change. He continued to be kind and generous, helping those in need and sharing his wealth with the poor. Because of his good heart, the village prospered, and everyone lived happily together.

One day, the little peasant heard that the old man was actually a magical being who tested people's hearts. The little peasant realized that his true wealth came from his kindness and the happiness he brought to others. From that day on, he lived a life full of joy and contentment, proving that true riches come from within.

events.title: The Peasant's Makeshift Soothsayer and the Unveiling of a Hidden Feast
detailed_summary: The peasant and his wife finally possessed the cow they had long desired but lacked food for it, compelling them to slaughter it soon after.
They preserved the meat by salting it, and the peasant intended to sell the cow's skin in town to finance the purchase of a new calf.
En route, he passed a mill where he found a raven with injured wings; moved by pity, he took the raven and wrapped it in the cow skin he was carrying.
Severe weather, including a storm of rain and wind, prevented him from continuing his journey, forcing him to turn back to the mill to ask for shelter.
The miller's wife, who was alone in the house, allowed him to rest on some straw and provided him with a piece of bread and cheese.
The peasant ate and then lay down with the skin containing the raven beside him, while the miller's wife assumed he was tired and asleep.
Shortly thereafter, the parson arrived, and the miller's wife welcomed him warmly, stating that since her husband was out, they could enjoy a feast together.
The peasant, overhearing their plans for a feast, felt irritated that he had to be content with just bread and cheese.
The miller's wife then served a spread of four different items: roast meat, salad, cakes, and wine for herself and the parson.
Just as they were preparing to eat, a knock was heard at the door.

The miller's wife, alarmed, exclaimed it was her husband and quickly concealed the food items: the roast meat in the tiled stove, the wine under the pillow, the salad on the bed, and the cakes under the bed. She also hid the parson in a closet on the porch.
She then opened the door for her husband, remarking on his timely return and the severity of the storm.
The miller noticed the peasant on the straw and inquired about his presence.
His wife explained that the poor man had sought refuge from the storm and she had offered him some bread, cheese, and a place on the straw.
The miller expressed no objection and asked his wife to quickly prepare something for him to eat.
The wife claimed she only had bread and cheese.
The husband, stating he was content with anything, invited the peasant to join him in eating more bread and cheese.
The peasant accepted the offer and ate with the miller.
Afterwards, the miller saw the skin lying on the ground and asked what the peasant had in it.
The peasant replied that he had a soothsayer inside the skin.
When the miller asked if it could tell his fortune, the peasant affirmed, adding that it reveals four things but keeps a fifth to itself.
Intrigued, the miller requested a prophecy.
The peasant pinched the raven's head, causing it to croak.
The peasant then 'interpreted' the first prophecy: there was wine hidden under the pillow. The miller searched and found the wine.
The peasant made the raven croak again and 'interpreted' the second prophecy: roast meat was hidden in the tiled stove. The miller found it.
A third croak 'revealed' salad on the bed, which the miller also discovered.
Finally, the peasant elicited another croak and 'prophesied' that cakes were under the bed. The miller found these as well.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And now the little peasant and his wife had the cow for which they had so long wished, and they were heartily glad, but they had no food for it, and could give it nothing to eat, so it soon had to be killed.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘That would be a fine thing!’ cried the miller, and looked there, and found the cakes.

events.text_segment:
And now the little peasant and his wife had the cow for which they had so long wished, and they were heartily glad, but they had no food for it, and could give it nothing to eat, so it soon had to be killed. They salted the flesh, and the peasant went into the town and wanted to sell the skin there, so that he might buy a new calf with the proceeds. On the way he passed by a mill, and there sat a raven with broken wings, and out of pity he took him and wrapped him in the skin. But as the weather grew so bad and there was a storm of rain and wind, he could go no farther, and turned back to the mill and begged for shelter. The miller’s wife was alone in the house, and said to the peasant: ‘Lay yourself on the straw there,’ and gave him a slice of bread and cheese. The peasant ate it, and lay down with his skin beside him, and the woman thought: ‘He is tired and has gone to sleep.’ In the meantime came the parson; the miller’s wife received him well, and said: ‘My husband is out, so we will have a feast.’ The peasant listened, and when he heard them talk about feasting he was vexed that he had been forced to make shift with a slice of bread and cheese. Then the woman served up four different things, roast meat, salad, cakes, and wine.
Just as they were about to sit down and eat, there was a knocking outside. The woman said: ‘Oh, heavens! It is my husband!’ she quickly hid the roast meat inside the tiled stove, the wine under the pillow, the salad on the bed, the cakes under it, and the parson in the closet on the porch. Then she opened the door for her husband, and said: ‘Thank heaven, you are back again! There is such a storm, it looks as if the world were coming to an end.’ The miller saw the peasant lying on the straw, and asked, ‘What is that fellow doing there?’ ‘Ah,’ said the wife, ‘the poor knave came in the storm and rain, and begged for shelter, so I gave him a bit of bread and cheese, and showed him where the straw was.’ The man said: ‘I have no objection, but be quick and get me something to eat.’ The woman said: ‘But I have nothing but bread and cheese.’ ‘I am contented with anything,’ replied the husband, ‘so far as I am concerned, bread and cheese will do,’ and looked at the peasant and said: ‘Come and eat some more with me.’ The peasant did not require to be invited twice, but got up and ate. After this the miller saw the skin in which the raven was, lying on the ground, and asked: ‘What have you there?’ The peasant answered: ‘I have a soothsayer inside it.’ ‘Can he foretell anything to me?’ said the miller. ‘Why not?’ answered the peasant: ‘but he only says four things, and the fifth he keeps to himself.’ The miller was curious, and said: ‘Let him foretell something for once.’ Then the peasant pinched the raven’s head, so that he croaked and made a noise like krr, krr. The miller said: ‘What did he say?’ The peasant answered: ‘In the first place, he says that there is some wine hidden under the pillow.’ ‘Bless me!’ cried the miller, and went there and found the wine. ‘Now go on,’ said he. The peasant made the raven croak again, and said: ‘In the second place, he says that there is some roast meat in the tiled stove.’ ‘Upon my word!’ cried the miller, and went thither, and found the roast meat. The peasant made the raven prophesy still more, and said: ‘Thirdly, he says that there is some salad on the bed.’ ‘That would be a fine thing!’ cried the miller, and went there and found the salad. At last the peasant pinched the raven once more till he croaked, and said: ‘Fourthly, he says that there are some cakes under the bed.’ ‘That would be a fine thing!’ cried the miller, and looked there, and found the cakes.

She also hid the parson in a closet on the porch. Then she opened the door and said, "How well you come home in this storm! It looks as if the world were coming to an end." The miller saw the little peasant lying on the straw and asked what he was doing there. The wife said, "The poor man begged for shelter from the storm, and I gave him bread and cheese and a place to lie down." The miller said he had no objection and asked his wife to prepare something for him to eat. She said she had only bread and cheese. The miller said, "That is all I want," and invited the little peasant to eat some more with him. The little peasant accepted and ate with the miller. Afterwards, the miller saw the skin lying on the ground and asked what was in it. The little peasant said it was a soothsayer. The miller asked if it could tell his fortune. The little peasant said it could, and that it would reveal four things but keep a fifth to itself. The miller asked for a prophecy. The little peasant pinched the raven's head, and it croaked. He said, "The first prophecy is that there is wine hidden under the pillow." The miller searched and exclaimed, "Ah! Here is the wine!" The little peasant pinched the raven again, and it croaked. He said, "The second prophecy is that roast meat is hidden in the tiled stove." The miller found it and cried, "Indeed, here is the roast!" A third croak revealed salad on the bed, which the miller found and said, "Here is the salad!" Finally, another croak revealed cakes under the bed, which the miller also found, exclaiming, "And here are the cakes!"

And now the little peasant and his wife had the cow for which they had so long wished, and they were heartily glad, but they had no food for it, and could give it nothing to eat, so it soon had to be killed. They were very sorry, but what could they do? They had no grain or hay, and the fields were bare. The cow was their only treasure, and now it was gone.

One day, as the peasant was walking through the forest, he came upon a strange old man who was sitting under a tree. The old man looked at him kindly and said, "Why do you look so sad, my son?"

The peasant told him all about his troubles—the cow, the hunger, and the hard times. The old man listened carefully and then said, "I will help you, but you must promise me one thing."

"Anything," said the peasant eagerly.

"If I give you a magic bean that will bring you great fortune, you must never tell anyone where you got it, and you must plant it with care."

The peasant agreed, and the old man gave him a single bean, shining and golden. The peasant thanked him and hurried home.

He planted the bean in his garden, and overnight, a great beanstalk grew, reaching up into the clouds. The peasant was amazed and decided to climb it. When he reached the top, he found a magnificent castle, where a giant lived.

The giant was fierce and terrible, but the peasant was clever. He sneaked into the castle and found a hen that laid golden eggs, and a harp that played by itself. He took them and climbed down the beanstalk.

With the golden eggs, the peasant and his wife had enough to eat and live comfortably. They were happy and never wanted for anything again. But the peasant remembered his promise to the old man and kept the secret of the magic bean.

One day, the giant discovered the theft and chased the peasant down the beanstalk. The peasant called to his wife to bring an axe, and together they chopped down the beanstalk. The giant fell and was never seen again.

From that day on, the peasant and his wife lived in peace and prosperity, grateful for the magic bean and the kindness of the old man. They learned that patience and cleverness could overcome even the greatest hardships.

events.title: The Fifth Prophecy: The Parson's Exposure and the Peasant's Reward
detailed_summary: The peasant and the miller sat down to eat the recovered feast, while the miller's wife, overcome with fear, retreated to bed, taking all the household keys with her.
The miller was very curious about the fifth prophecy, but the little peasant suggested they eat the first four items quickly, as the fifth was something ominous.
After their meal, they negotiated the price for the fifth prophecy, eventually agreeing on three hundred talers.
The peasant then pinched the raven's head once more until it croaked loudly.
The miller asked for the prophecy, and the peasant revealed that the raven said the Devil was hiding in the closet on the porch.
The miller declared that the Devil must be expelled and opened the house door.
The miller's wife was then compelled to surrender the keys, and the peasant unlocked the closet.
The parson rushed out as quickly as he could.
The miller exclaimed that the prophecy was true, as he had seen the 'black rascal' (referring to the parson, whom he mistook for the Devil) with his own eyes.
The peasant departed the following morning at daybreak with the three hundred talers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: And now the two sat down to the table together, but the miller’s wife was frightened to death, and went to bed and took all the keys with her.

events.text_segment: And now the two sat down to the table together, but the miller’s wife was frightened to death, and went to bed and took all the keys with her. The miller would have liked much to know the fifth, but the little peasant said: ‘First, we will quickly eat the four things, for the fifth is something bad.’ So they ate, and after that they bargained how much the miller was to give for the fifth prophecy, until they agreed on three hundred talers. Then the peasant once more pinched the raven’s head till he croaked loudly. The miller asked: ‘What did he say?’ The peasant replied: ‘He says that the Devil is hiding outside there in the closet on the porch.’ The miller said: ‘The Devil must go out,’ and opened the house-door; then the woman was forced to give up the keys, and the peasant unlocked the closet. The parson ran out as fast as he could, and the miller said: ‘It was true; I saw the black rascal with my own eyes.’ The peasant, however, made off next morning by daybreak with the three hundred talers.

events.title: The Peasant's False Claim of Wealth and the Villagers' Ruinous Greed
detailed_summary: Back home, the little peasant's fortunes improved significantly; he constructed a beautiful house, leading other peasants to speculate that he must have found a place where gold was abundant.
The little peasant was summoned before the mayor and ordered to explain the source of his newfound wealth.
He stated that he had sold his cow's skin in town for three hundred talers.
Upon hearing this, the other peasants, eager to achieve similar profits, hurried home, slaughtered all their cows, and skinned them, intending to sell the skins in town for a high price.
The mayor stipulated that his servant must be the first to sell her skin.
When the mayor's servant went to the merchant in town, she received only two talers for a skin.
When the other peasants arrived with their skins, the merchant offered them even less, remarking on his inability to use so many skins.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When she came to the merchant in the town, he did not give her more than two talers for a skin, and when the others came, he did not give them so much, and said: ‘What can I do with all these skins?’

events.text_segment: At home the small peasant gradually launched out; he built a beautiful house, and the peasants said: ‘The small peasant has certainly been to the place where golden snow falls, and people carry the gold home in shovels.’ Then the small peasant was brought before the mayor, and bidden to say from whence his wealth came. He answered: ‘I sold my cow’s skin in the town, for three hundred talers.’ When the peasants heard that, they too wished to enjoy this great profit, and ran home, killed all their cows, and stripped off their skins in order to sell them in the town to the greatest advantage. The mayor, however, said: ‘But my servant must go first.’ When she came to the merchant in the town, he did not give her more than two talers for a skin, and when the others came, he did not give them so much, and said: ‘What can I do with all these skins?’

events.title: The Peasant's Clever Escape from Execution by Tricking the Aspiring Mayor
detailed_summary: The peasants, angered by the little peasant's deception, sought revenge and accused him of treachery before the mayor.
The innocent-acting little peasant was unanimously condemned to death by being rolled into the water inside a barrel pierced with holes.
He was led to his execution, and a priest was brought to perform a mass for his soul.
The other villagers were required to stand at a distance.
When the peasant saw the priest, he recognized him as the parson who had been with the miller's wife.
He addressed the priest, saying, 'I freed you from the closet, now you free me from the barrel.'
At that moment, a shepherd, whom the peasant knew had long aspired to be mayor, approached with his flock of sheep.
The peasant then shouted loudly, 'No, I will not do it; if the whole world insists on it, I will not do it!'
The shepherd, hearing this, came closer and asked what the peasant was refusing to do.
The peasant claimed that they wanted to make him mayor by putting him in the barrel, but he did not want the position.
The shepherd, eager for the role, stated that if becoming mayor only required getting into the barrel, he would do so immediately.
The peasant affirmed that if the shepherd got in, he would indeed become mayor.
The shepherd willingly entered the barrel, and the peasant secured the top.
The peasant then took the shepherd's flock for himself and drove it away.
The parson went to the assembled crowd and announced that the mass had been completed.
The villagers then approached and began to roll the barrel towards the water.
As the barrel started to roll, the shepherd inside cried out, 'I am quite willing to be mayor.'
The villagers, believing it was the peasant speaking, replied that this was their intention, but first, he should explore the depths below, and they rolled the barrel into the water.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then the peasants were vexed that the small peasant should have thus outwitted them, wanted to take vengeance on him, and accused him of this treachery before the mayor.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the barrel began to roll, the shepherd cried: ‘I am quite willing to be mayor.’ They believed no otherwise than that it was the peasant who was saying this, and answered: ‘That is what we intend, but first you shall look about you a little down below there,’ and they rolled the barrel down into the water.

events.text_segment: Then the peasants were vexed that the small peasant should have thus outwitted them, wanted to take vengeance on him, and accused him of this treachery before the mayor. The innocent little peasant was unanimously sentenced to death, and was to be rolled into the water, in a barrel pierced full of holes. He was led forth, and a priest was brought who was to say a mass for his soul. The others were all obliged to retire to a distance, and when the peasant looked at the priest, he recognized the man who had been with the miller’s wife. He said to him: ‘I set you free from the closet, set me free from the barrel.’ At this same moment up came, with a flock of sheep, the very shepherd whom the peasant knew had long been wishing to be mayor, so he cried with all his might: ‘No, I will not do it; if the whole world insists on it, I will not do it!’ The shepherd hearing that, came up to him, and asked: ‘What are you about? What is it that you will not do?’ The peasant said: ‘They want to make me mayor, if I will but put myself in the barrel, but I will not do it.’ The shepherd said: ‘If nothing more than that is needful in order to be mayor, I would get into the barrel at once.’ The peasant said: ‘If you will get in, you will be mayor.’ The shepherd was willing, and got in, and the peasant shut the top down on him; then he took the shepherd’s flock for himself, and drove it away. The parson went to the crowd, and declared that the mass had been said. Then they came and rolled the barrel towards the water. When the barrel began to roll, the shepherd cried: ‘I am quite willing to be mayor.’ They believed no otherwise than that it was the peasant who was saying this, and answered: ‘That is what we intend, but first you shall look about you a little down below there,’ and they rolled the barrel down into the water.

When the small peasant awoke and found the ring gone, he was heartbroken. Without the ring, he was powerless against the peasants' cruelty.

Determined to regain his treasure, the small peasant set out on a journey to find the ring. He traveled through dark forests and over high mountains, facing many dangers along the way. At last, he came to a great castle where the ring was kept by a wicked sorcerer.

The small peasant, though afraid, entered the castle and confronted the sorcerer. Using his wit and courage, he tricked the sorcerer and reclaimed the magic ring. With the ring in his possession once more, he returned to his village.

Upon his return, the small peasant used the ring's magic to help the villagers, sharing his good fortune and teaching them kindness and fairness. The peasants, seeing his generosity and the power of the ring, repented their envy and cruelty.

From that day forward, the small peasant was respected and loved by all. The magic ring remained a symbol of wisdom and justice, reminding everyone that true strength lies not in power or wealth, but in kindness and cleverness.

events.title: The Final Deception: The Lure of Underwater Sheep and the Villagers' Demise
detailed_summary: After the execution, the peasants returned home.
As they were entering their village, the little peasant also arrived, calmly driving a flock of sheep and appearing quite pleased.
The peasants were amazed and asked him if he had come from the water.

The peasant affirmed that he had, explaining that he sank deep down until he reached the bottom, then pushed out the barrel's base and emerged into beautiful meadows filled with feeding lambs, from which he had brought back his current flock.
When the peasants inquired if there were more sheep there, he replied that there were more than he could possibly need.
The peasants then resolved to fetch sheep for themselves, aiming for a flock each, with the mayor declaring he would go first.
They all proceeded to the water together.
At that time, small, fleecy clouds, often referred to as 'little lambs,' were visible in the blue sky and were reflected on the water's surface.
Seeing these reflections, the peasants exclaimed that they could already see the sheep below.
The mayor pushed to the front, announcing he would go down first to assess the situation and would call them if conditions were favorable.
He then jumped into the water; the resulting splash sounded to the others as if he were calling them.
Consequently, the entire crowd of peasants plunged into the water after him, as a single group.
As a result, the entire village population perished by drowning.
The little peasant, being the sole survivor and heir, became a wealthy man.

events.title: Catherine's Culinary Catastrophes and Cleanup
detailed_summary: Frederick requested his wife, Catherine, to prepare a good meal and ale for his return from working in the fields.
Catherine started frying their only steak and then went to the cellar to fetch ale.
While tapping the ale, she worried that the unsecured dog might steal the cooking steak.
Her fear materialized; she rushed upstairs to find the dog escaping with the steak in its mouth.
Catherine pursued the dog across a field but failed to retrieve the meat, eventually giving up and returning home tired.
Upon her return, she discovered that the ale tap had been left open, causing the entire cask to empty onto the cellar floor.
To manage the spillage, Catherine decided to use a sack of fine meal to absorb the ale.
In her attempt to apply the solution, she accidentally knocked over the jug of ale she had initially collected, adding to the mess.
She then spread the meal all over the cellar floor, feeling pleased with how clean and neat it looked despite the series of mishaps.
When Frederick arrived and asked for his dinner, Catherine recounted the loss of the steak to the dog, the spillage of all the ale, and how the meal was used to clean up the cellar.
Frederick questioned her choices, and Catherine defended herself by stating she was unaware she was doing anything wrong as he had not previously instructed her otherwise.

events.text_segment:
There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married. One day Frederick said. ‘Kate! I am going to work in the fields; when I come back I shall be hungry so let me have something nice cooked, and a good draught of ale.’ ‘Very well,’ said she, ‘it shall all be ready.’ When dinner-time drew nigh, Catherine took a nice steak, which was all the meat she had, and put it on the fire to fry. The steak soon began to look brown, and to crackle in the pan; and Catherine stood by with a fork and turned it: then she said to herself, ‘The steak is almost ready, I may as well go to the cellar for the ale.’ So she left the pan on the fire and took a large jug and went into the cellar and tapped the ale cask. The beer ran into the jug and Catherine stood looking on. At last it popped into her head, ‘The dog is not shut up—he may be running away with the steak; that’s well thought of.’ So up she ran from the cellar; and sure enough the rascally cur had got the steak in his mouth, and was making off with it.
Away ran Catherine, and away ran the dog across the field: but he ran faster than she, and stuck close to the steak. ‘It’s all gone, and “what can’t be cured must be endured”,’ said Catherine. So she turned round; and as she had run a good way and was tired, she walked home leisurely to cool herself.
Now all this time the ale was running too, for Catherine had not turned the cock; and when the jug was full the liquor ran upon the floor till the cask was empty. When she got to the cellar stairs she saw what had happened. ‘My stars!’ said she, ‘what shall I do to keep Frederick from seeing all this slopping about?’ So she thought a while; and at last remembered that there was a sack of fine meal bought at the last fair, and that if she sprinkled this over the floor it would suck up the ale nicely. ‘What a lucky thing,’ said she, ‘that we kept that meal! we have now a good use for it.’ So away she went for it: but she managed to set it down just upon the great jug full of beer, and upset it; and thus all the ale that had been saved was set swimming on the floor also. ‘Ah! well,’ said she, ‘when one goes another may as well follow.’ Then she strewed the meal all about the cellar, and was quite pleased with her cleverness, and said, ‘How very neat and clean it looks!’
At noon Frederick came home. ‘Now, wife,’ cried he, ‘what have you for dinner?’ ‘O Frederick!’ answered she, ‘I was cooking you a steak; but while I went down to draw the ale, the dog ran away with it; and while I ran after him, the ale ran out; and when I went to dry up the ale with the sack of meal that we got at the fair, I upset the jug: but the cellar is now quite dry, and looks so clean!’ ‘Kate, Kate,’ said he, ‘how could you do all this?’ Why did you leave the steak to fry, and the ale to run, and then spoil all the meal?’ ‘Why, Frederick,’ said she, ‘I did not know I was doing wrong; you should have told me before.’
