simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
There were two brothers who were both soldiers; the one was rich and the other poor. The poor brother, when he left the army, took off his red coat and became a gardener. He planted a turnip seed, and it grew and grew until it became so large that it was unlike any turnip anyone had ever seen. It grew so big that it could not be pulled from the ground by one man alone, and it took a cart and two oxen to carry it.

The poor gardener did not know what to do with such a monstrous turnip. He thought to himself, "Shall I sell it? But who would buy such a thing? Or shall I eat it? But it is too large for me alone. Perhaps it will be a blessing, or perhaps a curse."

After much thought, he decided that the best thing was to take the turnip to the king and offer it to him as a gift. So he loaded the turnip onto a cart and went to the royal court.

When the king saw the enormous turnip, he was amazed and said, "What a monster of a turnip! I have never seen one so large. Tell me, did you plant a special seed, or are you a child of fortune?"

The gardener humbly answered, "Your Majesty, I am no child of fortune. I was once a poor soldier, and now I work as a gardener. My brother is rich and well-known, but I am poor and forgotten by all."

The king was moved by the gardener's words and resolved to end his poverty. He gave him great riches—gold, lands, and livestock—so that he became far richer than his brother.

events.title: The Rich Brother's Envy and Miscalculated Offering
detailed_summary: Upon learning how a simple turnip had brought his brother immense wealth, the rich brother felt intense envy.
He began to scheme about how he could achieve similar or greater fortune.
He resolved to be more cunning than his brother and assembled a valuable gift of gold and fine horses for the king.
He anticipated receiving a much larger reward in return, reasoning that if a turnip yielded so much, his expensive present must be worth considerably more.
The king accepted the rich brother's gift with grace.
However, the king declared that he could not offer anything in return more valuable or extraordinary than the giant turnip.
Consequently, the rich soldier was compelled to take the great turnip home with him in a cart.
Arriving home, he was consumed by rage and spite, unsure how to release his frustration.
Eventually, malevolent ideas formed in his mind, and he decided to murder his brother.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the brother heard of all this, and how a turnip had made the gardener so rich, he envied him sorely, and bethought himself how he could contrive to get the same good fortune for himself.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When he reached home, he knew not upon whom to vent his rage and spite; and at length wicked thoughts came into his head, and he resolved to kill his brother.

events.text_segment:
When the brother heard of all this, and how a turnip had made the gardener so rich, he envied him sorely, and bethought himself how he could contrive to get the same good fortune for himself. However, he determined to manage more cleverly than his brother, and got together a rich present of gold and fine horses for the king; and thought he must have a much larger gift in return; for if his brother had received so much for only a turnip, what must his present be worth?
The king took the gift very graciously, and said he knew not what to give in return more valuable and wonderful than the great turnip; so the soldier was forced to put it into a cart, and drag it home with him. When he reached home, he knew not upon whom to vent his rage and spite; and at length wicked thoughts came into his head, and he resolved to kill his brother.

events.title: The Murder Plot and the Gardener's Narrow Escape
detailed_summary: The rich brother engaged assassins to kill his poor brother.
After instructing them on where to set up an ambush, he approached his brother with a deceitful proposal.
He claimed to have discovered a hidden treasure and suggested they unearth it and divide it between themselves.
The poor brother, unaware of the treacherous plan, agreed to go with him.
While they were traveling together, the hired murderers attacked the poor brother.
They tied him up and were about to hang him from a tree.
Just as they were making their final preparations, the sound of an approaching horse startled them.
In their alarm, the murderers quickly forced their captive into a sack, head and shoulders together.
They then hung the sack by a cord from the tree, left him dangling, and fled the scene.
Despite his predicament, the man in the sack persistently worked until he managed to create an opening in the sack large enough to stick his head out.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So he hired some villains to murder him; and having shown them where to lie in ambush, he went to his brother, and said, ‘Dear brother, I have found a hidden treasure; let us go and dig it up, and share it between us.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Meantime he worked and worked away, till he made a hole large enough to put out his head.

events.text_segment:
So he hired some villains to murder him; and having shown them where to lie in ambush, he went to his brother, and said, ‘Dear brother, I have found a hidden treasure; let us go and dig it up, and share it between us.’ The other had no suspicions of his roguery: so they went out together, and as they were travelling along, the murderers rushed out upon him, bound him, and were going to hang him on a tree.
But whilst they were getting all ready, they heard the trampling of a horse at a distance, which so frightened them that they pushed their prisoner neck and shoulders together into a sack, and swung him up by a cord to the tree, where they left him dangling, and ran away. Meantime he worked and worked away, till he made a hole large enough to put out his head.

As they journeyed together, the villains sprang their trap, seizing the poor brother and binding him tightly. They prepared to hang him from a tree, but just as they were about to do so, the sound of a horse approaching startled them. In their haste, they thrust the poor brother head and shoulders into a sack, tied it securely, and hung it from a branch before fleeing the scene. Alone and desperate, the poor brother struggled within the sack until he managed to tear a hole large enough to push his head through, breathing fresh air and preparing to find a way to escape.

events.title: The Man in the Sack and the Curious Student
characters: Poor brother (Gardener, Man in the sack)
detailed_summary: The approaching horseman turned out to be a cheerful student, riding his horse and singing.
As the student passed beneath the tree, the man trapped in the sack greeted him.
The student, surprised, looked around but couldn't identify the source of the voice and asked who was calling him.
The man in the tree responded, proclaiming he was sitting in the "sack of wisdom."
He boasted of rapidly acquiring great and wondrous knowledge within the sack.
He asserted that, compared to his current seat, all academic learning was insignificant.
He claimed that with a little more time, he would possess all possible human knowledge and become wiser than anyone.

He described discerning celestial patterns, the laws governing winds, the number of grains of sand on the seashore, methods for healing the sick, and the properties of all simple substances, birds, and precious stones.
He enticed the student by suggesting that if he too were in the sack, he would experience and recognize the power of such knowledge.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When the horseman came up, he proved to be a student, a merry fellow, who was journeying along on his nag, and singing as he went.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Wert thou but once here, my friend, though wouldst feel and own the power of knowledge.

events.text_segment:
When the horseman came up, he proved to be a student, a merry fellow, who was journeying along on his nag, and singing as he went. As soon as the man in the sack saw him passing under the tree, he cried out, ‘Good morning! good morning to thee, my friend!’ The student looked about everywhere; and seeing no one, and not knowing where the voice came from, cried out, ‘Who calls me?’
Then the man in the tree answered, ‘Lift up thine eyes, for behold here I sit in the sack of wisdom; here have I, in a short time, learned great and wondrous things. Compared to this seat, all the learning of the schools is as empty air. A little longer, and I shall know all that man can know, and shall come forth wiser than the wisest of mankind. Here I discern the signs and motions of the heavens and the stars; the laws that control the winds; the number of the sands on the seashore; the healing of the sick; the virtues of all simples, of birds, and of precious stones. Wert thou but once here, my friend, though wouldst feel and own the power of knowledge.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: When the horseman came up, he proved to be a student, a merry fellow, who was journeying along on his nag, and singing as he went. As he passed beneath the tree, the man in the sack called out to him, "Good day, friend!" The student looked about in surprise, but could see no one, and asked, "Who is it that speaks to me?" "It is I," answered the man in the tree, "sitting here in the sack of wisdom." "In this sack," he went on, "I have learned more in a short time than all the scholars in the world have ever known. Compared to this seat, all the learning of the universities is but child's play. Give me but a little longer, and I shall know all that man can know, and be wiser than any man alive. I can discern the courses of the stars, the laws of the winds, the number of grains of sand on the seashore, the means to heal the sick, and the properties of all simple substances, birds, and precious stones. If you were here with me in the sack, you too would feel and know the power of such knowledge."

events.title: The Clever Exchange and the Gardener's Getaway
characters: Poor brother (Gardener, Man in the sack)
detailed_summary: The student, greatly astonished by what he heard, expressed his gratitude for encountering the man and asked if he could enter the sack for a short time.
The man in the sack, feigning reluctance, replied that he might permit a brief stay if the student offered a good reward and asked politely.
He added that the student would need to wait an hour below while he finished learning some remaining matters.
The student, finding the wait tedious and driven by a strong desire for knowledge, earnestly pleaded to ascend into the sack immediately.
The man in the sack pretended to concede to the student's request.
He instructed the student to lower the "sack of wisdom" by untying the cord holding it.
The student complied, let the sack down, opened it, and freed the gardener.
The student then eagerly declared his intent to ascend quickly into the sack.
As the student started to put himself into the sack feet first, the gardener stopped him, stating that was not the correct method.
The gardener then pushed the student into the sack headfirst, tied it securely, and hoisted the "searcher after wisdom" up into the air.
The gardener mockingly questioned if the student could feel wisdom coming to him and advised him to remain there peacefully until he became wiser.
With these words, the gardener mounted the student's horse and rode away, leaving the student suspended to contemplate wisdom until someone might rescue him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The student listened to all this and wondered much; at last he said, ‘Blessed be the day and hour when I found you; cannot you contrive to let me into the sack for a little while?’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So saying, he trotted off on the student’s nag, and left the poor fellow to gather wisdom till somebody should come and let him down.

events.text_segment:
The student listened to all this and wondered much; at last he said, ‘Blessed be the day and hour when I found you; cannot you contrive to let me into the sack for a little while?’ Then the other answered, as if very unwillingly, ‘A little space I may allow thee to sit here, if thou wilt reward me well and entreat me kindly; but thou must tarry yet an hour below, till I have learnt some little matters that are yet unknown to me.’
So the student sat himself down and waited a while; but the time hung heavy upon him, and he begged earnestly that he might ascend forthwith, for his thirst for knowledge was great. Then the other pretended to give way, and said, ‘Thou must let the sack of wisdom descend, by untying yonder cord, and then thou shalt enter.’ So the student let him down, opened the sack, and set him free. ‘Now then,’ cried he, ‘let me ascend quickly.’ As he began to put himself into the sack heels first, ‘Wait a while,’ said the gardener, ‘that is not the way.’ Then he pushed him in head first, tied up the sack, and soon swung up the searcher after wisdom dangling in the air. ‘How is it with thee, friend?’ said he, ‘dost thou not feel that wisdom comes unto thee? Rest there in peace, till thou art a wiser man than thou wert.’
So saying, he trotted off on the student’s nag, and left the poor fellow to gather wisdom till somebody should come and let him down.

The old man smiled and said, ‘If you will promise me to be very careful, and not to look inside, I will let you try.’ The student eagerly agreed, and the old man handed him the sack. The student took it and, with trembling hands, put it over his head. At first, he saw nothing but darkness, but soon the sack began to fill with the most wonderful sights: golden treasures, sparkling jewels, and magnificent palaces. He was amazed and delighted beyond measure.

But as the moments passed, curiosity overcame him, and he could not resist the temptation to peek inside. He lifted the sack slightly and looked in. The student was filled with regret and begged for forgiveness. The old man nodded and said, ‘Let this be a lesson to you: patience and trust are the keys to true wisdom.’

From that day forward, the student devoted himself to learning and understanding, never again seeking shortcuts or forbidden knowledge. And though he never saw the wonders of the sack again, he found a greater treasure in the knowledge he gained through perseverance and humility.

events.title: Hans's First Mishap: The Needle and the Hay-Cart
detailed_summary: Hans's mother inquires about his destination, and Hans states he is going to visit Gretel.
His mother instructs him to behave properly during his visit.
Upon arriving, Hans greets Gretel and indicates he has come to receive something, not to offer a gift.
Gretel gives Hans a needle.
For his journey home, Hans carelessly sticks the needle into a passing hay-cart.
When Hans returns, he informs his mother that Gretel gave him a needle.
Asked where the needle is, Hans explains he placed it in the hay-cart.
His mother scolds him for this foolish act, telling him he should have secured the needle in his sleeve.
Hans casually dismisses his error, asserting he will handle things better in the future.

events.title: Hans's Third Mishap: The Suffocated Goat
detailed_summary: The pattern continues with Hans setting off to Gretel's after the routine exchange with his mother regarding his trip and behavior.
He greets Gretel and makes his customary request for a gift.
Gretel gives him a young goat.
Attempting to apply his mother's advice for carrying the knife (putting things in his pocket), Hans ties the goat's legs and puts it into his pocket.
Tragically, the goat suffocates by the time Hans arrives home.
He informs his mother that Gretel gave him a goat.
Upon discovering the goat was placed in his pocket and died as a result, his mother rebukes him, stating he should have used a rope around the goat's neck to lead it.
Hans, with his usual nonchalance, promises to perform better in his next endeavor.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘Whither away, Hans?’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Never mind, will do better next time.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
"Whither away, Hans?" his mother called as he was about to leave.

"To Gretel's," Hans replied cheerfully.

"Remember to behave yourself and don't forget what I told you about carrying the knife," she reminded him.

Hans nodded and set off down the path. When he reached Gretel's house, he greeted her warmly.

"Good day, Gretel!" he said. "May I have a gift today?"

Gretel smiled and handed him a young goat.

Hans thought about his mother's advice to put the knife in his pocket to keep it safe. So, he tied the goat's legs together and carefully placed it into his pocket.

By the time Hans arrived home, the poor goat had suffocated.

"Mother," Hans said, "Gretel gave me a goat today."

His mother looked into his pocket and found the lifeless goat. "Hans! You should have tied a rope around its neck and led it properly," she scolded.

Hans shrugged and replied with his usual carefree manner, "I'll do better next time."

events.title: Hans's Fourth Mishap: The Bacon Dragged and Devoured
detailed_summary: Hans embarks on another visit to Gretel, preceded by the familiar dialogue with his mother.
He greets Gretel and voices his expectation of receiving a present.
Gretel gives Hans a piece of bacon.
Following his mother's latest advice (regarding the goat and using a rope), Hans ties the bacon to a rope and drags it behind him as he walks home.
This method proves disastrous as dogs are attracted to the bacon, follow him, and consume it entirely during his journey.
He arrives home holding only the rope, the bacon gone.
He narrates his visit to his mother and tells her about the gift of bacon.
Learning that he dragged the bacon, allowing dogs to eat it, his mother calls his actions ill-judged and tells him he should have carried the bacon on his head.
Hans once more resolves to improve his methods next time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘Whither away, Hans?’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Never mind, will do better next time.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Whither away, Hans?”

“I’m going to see Gretel.”

“Take care, Hans, and don’t forget what I told you last time.”

Hans nodded and set off. When he reached Gretel’s house, he greeted her cheerfully. “Good day, Gretel! I hope you have a present for me.”

Gretel smiled and handed him a piece of bacon.

Remembering his mother’s advice about the goat and the rope, Hans tied the bacon to a rope and dragged it behind him as he walked home.

But as he went along, dogs caught the scent of the bacon and began to follow him. One by one, they caught up and devoured the bacon entirely, leaving Hans holding only the empty rope.

When he arrived home, he told his mother about his visit and the gift he had received.

His mother frowned and said, “Hans, you were foolish to drag the bacon behind you. That’s why the dogs ate it. Next time, you should carry it on your head.”

Hans nodded thoughtfully, determined to do better on his next visit.

events.title: Hans's Fifth Mishap: The Calf on the Head
detailed_summary: Hans sets out for Gretel's house again, following the customary pre-departure conversation with his mother.
He greets Gretel and communicates his desire for a gift.
Gretel presents Hans with a calf.
Adhering to his mother's most recent instruction (to carry the bacon on his head), Hans attempts to transport the calf by placing it on his head.
The calf, understandably distressed, reacts by kicking Hans in the face.
Upon his return, Hans tells his mother that Gretel gave him a calf.
When he describes how he put the calf on his head and was subsequently kicked, his mother criticizes his action as foolish.
She explains that he should have led the calf by a rope and placed it in the animal stall.
Hans, true to form, promises to handle things more appropriately in the future.

events.title: Gretel Accompanies Hans and is Tied to a Rack
detailed_summary: Hans departs for Gretel's home yet again, after the now well-established exchange with his mother.
He greets Gretel and repeats his wish to be given something.
To Hans's surprise, Gretel announces that she will accompany him back to his home.
Interpreting his mother's advice about leading animals with a rope, Hans takes Gretel, ties her with a rope, leads her to the animal feeding rack, and secures her there.
He then goes to his mother and reports on his visit to Gretel's.
He clarifies that Gretel did not give him a tangible gift but instead came with him.
When his mother asks where Gretel is, Hans details how he treated her like livestock: leading her by a rope, tying her to the rack, and even scattering some grass for her.
His mother, appalled, tells him his behavior was wrong and that he should have cast friendly eyes upon Gretel.
Hans responds with a promise to 'do better,' notably omitting 'next time.'

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Whither away, Hans?”

“To Gretel’s,” said Hans.

“Again?” asked his mother.

“Yes, mother,” said Hans, “I want to see if she will give me something.”

When Hans arrived at Gretel’s, he greeted her and repeated his wish.

To his surprise, Gretel said, “I will come with you.”

Hans remembered his mother’s advice about leading animals with a rope. So he took a rope, tied it around Gretel, and led her to the animal feeding rack. There he fastened her securely.

Then Hans went back to his mother and reported, “I went to Gretel’s, but she did not give me anything. Instead, she came with me.”

“Where is Gretel now?” asked his mother.

Hans replied, “I led her with a rope, tied her to the rack, and even scattered some grass for her.”

His mother was appalled. “Hans, that was wrong. You should have looked upon Gretel with friendly eyes.”

Hans promised, “I will do better.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
‘Whither away, Hans?’ asked the old woman, peering out from beneath her tattered shawl as the young lad trudged down the dusty path. Hans, a simple boy with a heart full of dreams, paused and looked back with a wistful smile. ‘I am off to seek my fortune, good mother,’ he replied. ‘The world is vast, and I must find my place within it.’

The old woman nodded knowingly. ‘Many have set out with such hopes, but few return with their dreams fulfilled. Take heed, Hans, and be wary of the shadows that lurk beyond the village.’

Hans thanked her and continued on, the sun casting long shadows as he ventured into the unknown. The road wound through dense forests where the trees whispered secrets and the wind carried tales of old. As he walked, he came upon a fork in the path. To the left, the road was well-trodden and safe; to the right, it was overgrown and mysterious.

Remembering the old woman’s warning, Hans chose the right path, drawn by the allure of adventure. The forest grew darker, and the sounds of birdsong faded into silence. Suddenly, a rustling in the bushes startled him, and out stepped a small, scruffy dog with bright, intelligent eyes.

‘Well met, little friend,’ Hans said, kneeling to pet the creature. The dog wagged its tail and seemed eager to accompany him. Together, they pressed onward, deeper into the woods.

As dusk fell, they reached a clearing where a magnificent castle stood, its towers piercing the twilight sky. The gates were open, inviting yet foreboding. Hans hesitated but stepped inside, the dog at his heels.

Within the castle, he found a grand hall where a beautiful princess sat, her face etched with sorrow. ‘Who are you, stranger?’ she asked.

‘I am Hans, a humble traveler seeking my fortune,’ he replied.

The princess sighed. ‘I am cursed to remain here until someone braves the trials of the castle and breaks the spell.’

Determined to help, Hans agreed to face the challenges. The dog transformed into a noble knight, revealing itself as a guardian sent to aid him. Together, they navigated enchanted forests, solved riddles posed by ancient spirits, and overcame fears that lurked within their hearts.

At last, Hans reached the highest tower, where the source of the curse—a wicked sorcerer—awaited. With courage and wit, Hans confronted the sorcerer, breaking the spell and freeing the princess.

Grateful, the princess invited Hans to stay and rule by her side, but he declined, choosing instead to continue his journey, enriched by the lessons learned and the friendships forged.

And so, Hans and his faithful companion ventured forth, their story a testament to bravery, kindness, and the enduring quest for one’s destiny.

events.title: Hans's Final Cruelty and Gretel's Escape
detailed_summary: Hans, taking his mother's advice to 'cast friendly eyes' on Gretel with horrifying literalness, proceeds to the stable.
He commits a gruesome act by cutting out the eyes of all the calves and sheep he finds there.
He then returns to Gretel and throws these dismembered eyes in her face.
This cruel and shocking action deeply angers Gretel.
Filled with rage, Gretel manages to break free from the ropes binding her.
She immediately flees from Hans and his home, thereby definitively ending any possibility of her becoming his bride.

events.title: The Unconventional Student and a Father's Disownment
detailed_summary: An elderly count in Switzerland had a son who was perceived as unintelligent and incapable of learning.
The father, frustrated by his inability to educate his son, decided to send him to a renowned master for instruction.
After a year with the first master, the son returned home, having only learned to understand the barking of dogs.
The count, dismayed by this singular, unconventional skill, sent his son to a different master in another town.
Following another year of study, the son came back, this time reporting that he had learned to understand what birds say.
The father became extremely angry, berating his son for wasting time and learning nothing of practical value, and threatened to disown him if he failed with a third master.
The youth spent a year with a third master and returned, stating he had learned what frogs croak.
Overcome with fury, the father declared the youth was no longer his son, ordered his servants to take him into the forest, and kill him.
The servants, feeling pity for the youth, could not bring themselves to kill him and instead let him go, deceiving the count by presenting parts from a deer as proof of his death.

events.text_segment: An aged count once lived in Switzerland, who had an only son, but he was stupid, and could learn nothing. Then said the father: ‘Hark you, my son, try as I will I can get nothing into your head. You must go from hence, I will give you into the care of a celebrated master, who shall see what he can do with you.’ The youth was sent into a strange town, and remained a whole year with the master. At the end of this time, he came home again, and his father asked: ‘Now, my son, what have you learnt?’ ‘Father, I have learnt what the dogs say when they bark.’ ‘Lord have mercy on us!’ cried the father; ‘is that all you have learnt? I will send you into another town, to another master.’ The youth was taken thither, and stayed a year with this master likewise. When he came back the father again asked: ‘My son, what have you learnt?’ He answered: ‘Father, I have learnt what the birds say.’ Then the father fell into a rage and said: ‘Oh, you lost man, you have spent the precious time and learnt nothing; are you not ashamed to appear before my eyes? I will send you to a third master, but if you learn nothing this time also, I will no longer be your father.’ The youth remained a whole year with the third master also, and when he came home again, and his father inquired: ‘My son, what have you learnt?’ he answered: ‘Dear father, I have this year learnt what the frogs croak.’ Then the father fell into the most furious anger, sprang up, called his people thither, and said: ‘This man is no longer my son, I drive him forth, and command you to take him out into the forest, and kill him.’ They took him forth, but when they should have killed him, they could not do it for pity, and let him go, and they cut the eyes and tongue out of a deer that they might carry them to the old man as a token.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: An aged count once lived in Switzerland, who had an only son, but he was stupid, and could learn nothing. The count was very sorrowful on this account, and he did not know what to do with his son. One day, the count called his son to him and said, "My son, I have a great desire to see you wise and clever, but I fear you will never be so. However, I will give you a chance to prove yourself. If you can bring me a treasure that is worth more than all the gold in my castle, I will make you my heir and give you my lands." The son agreed and set out on his journey. He wandered through forests and over mountains, meeting many people and facing many dangers. One day, he came upon a little old man who was sitting by the roadside. The old man said, "Young man, why do you look so sad?" The son told him of his quest. The old man smiled and said, "I will help you, but you must promise to do exactly as I say." The son promised, and the old man gave him a small, plain-looking box. "This box contains a treasure more valuable than gold," he said. "But you must not open it until you return home." The son thanked the old man and hurried back to his father's castle. When he arrived, the count was eager to see the treasure. The son placed the box before him, but the count was disappointed to see it was empty. "There is nothing here," he said. The son replied, "Open the box, father, and you will see the treasure." The count opened the box, and to his amazement, a bright light filled the room. Inside the box was a tiny, glowing star. The star spoke, "I am the treasure of wisdom and knowledge. Whoever possesses me will be wise beyond measure." The count realized that his son had indeed brought him the greatest treasure of all. From that day forward, the son became wise and learned, and he ruled the land with kindness and justice.

events.title: The Youth, the Bewitched Dogs, and the Hidden Treasure
detailed_summary: The exiled youth, wandering, arrived at a fortress and requested shelter for the night.
The lord of the castle permitted him to stay in an old tower but warned him that it was perilous, as it was filled with savage dogs that barked incessantly and periodically devoured a human victim.
The entire region was distressed by these dogs, but no solution had been found.
The youth, showing no fear, asked to be allowed into the tower with some food to pacify the dogs, confident they would not injure him.
Given food for the animals, he was led to the tower.
Upon entering, the dogs did not bark at him but instead wagged their tails in a friendly manner, ate the food he offered, and left him completely unharmed.
The next morning, he emerged safely, much to everyone's surprise, and explained to the castle's lord that the dogs had communicated to him their plight.
He revealed that the dogs were cursed to guard a large treasure hidden in the tower and could not find peace until it was removed, also stating he learned from them how to accomplish this.
Those who heard this were overjoyed, and the lord promised to adopt the youth as his son if he successfully retrieved the treasure.
The youth descended into the tower again, performed the necessary actions as he understood them, and brought out a chest filled with gold.
Consequently, the howling of the wild dogs ceased, they vanished, and the land was relieved of its affliction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The youth wandered on, and after some time came to a fortress where he begged for a night’s lodging.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The howling of the wild dogs was henceforth heard no more; they had disappeared, and the country was freed from the trouble.

events.text_segment: The youth wandered on, and after some time came to a fortress where he begged for a night’s lodging. ‘Yes,’ said the lord of the castle, ‘if you will pass the night down there in the old tower, go thither; but I warn you, it is at the peril of your life, for it is full of wild dogs, which bark and howl without stopping, and at certain hours a man has to be given to them, whom they at once devour.’ The whole district was in sorrow and dismay because of them, and yet no one could do anything to stop this. The youth, however, was without fear, and said: ‘Just let me go down to the barking dogs, and give me something that I can throw to them; they will do nothing to harm me.’ As he himself would have it so, they gave him some food for the wild animals, and led him down to the tower. When he went inside, the dogs did not bark at him, but wagged their tails quite amicably around him, ate what he set before them, and did not hurt one hair of his head. Next morning, to the astonishment of everyone, he came out again safe and unharmed, and said to the lord of the castle: ‘The dogs have revealed to me, in their own language, why they dwell there, and bring evil on the land. They are bewitched, and are obliged to watch over a great treasure which is below in the tower, and they can have no rest until it is taken away, and I have likewise learnt, from their discourse, how that is to be done.’ Then all who heard this rejoiced, and the lord of the castle said he would adopt him as a son if he accomplished it successfully. He went down again, and as he knew what he had to do, he did it thoroughly, and brought a chest full of gold out with him. The howling of the wild dogs was henceforth heard no more; they had disappeared, and the country was freed from the trouble.

The youth wandered on, and after some time came to a fortress where he begged for a night’s lodging. The lord of the castle, a stern and proud man, looked upon the youth with suspicion but, seeing his humble demeanor, granted him shelter for the night. As the youth settled into a small chamber, he noticed a heavy iron door at the end of the corridor, behind which strange sounds seemed to echo. Curiosity overcame him, and he resolved to discover what lay beyond.

That night, as the castle lay silent, the youth crept to the iron door and found it unlocked. Pushing it open, he entered a vast hall where a magnificent dragon lay chained. Its scales shimmered like emeralds, and its eyes glowed with a fierce intelligence. The dragon spoke to the youth in a deep, rumbling voice, telling him that it had been imprisoned by the lord of the castle, who feared its power.

Undeterred, the youth returned to his chamber and devised a plan. At dawn, he approached the lord and offered to serve him faithfully if he would grant him a boon. The lord, amused, agreed.

The youth requested the key to the iron door, claiming he wished to see the dragon to better understand its strength. The lord, confident in his control, handed over the key. That night, the youth unlocked the chains and freed the dragon. In gratitude, the dragon bestowed upon the youth a magical sword and wings, enabling him to fly.

Together, they left the fortress, and the youth, now a hero, went on to have many adventures, his courage and kindness remembered in tales for generations to come.

events.title: The Journey to Rome and the Miraculous Ascension to Papacy
detailed_summary: Some time later, the youth decided to journey to Rome.
En route, he passed a marsh where frogs were croaking; listening to them, he understood their message and became deeply contemplative and sorrowful.
Upon his arrival in Rome, he found that the Pope had recently died, and the cardinals were deliberating over who should be his successor.
The cardinals eventually resolved that the next Pope should be identified by a divine, miraculous sign.
Just as this decision was made, the young count entered the church, and two snow-white doves suddenly flew down and settled on his shoulders, remaining there.
The clergy recognized this as the divine token and immediately asked him if he would accept the papacy.
He was uncertain and doubted his worthiness for such a high office, but the doves on his shoulders advised him to accept.
He agreed, was anointed and consecrated, thereby fulfilling the prophecy he had heard from the frogs, which had caused him such unease.
When it came time for him to sing a mass, he realized he did not know any of the words, but the two doves, still perched on his shoulders, whispered the entire service into his ear.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After some time he took it in his head that he would travel to Rome.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then he had to sing a mass, and did not know one word of it, but the two doves sat continually on his shoulders, and said it all in his ear.

events.text_segment: After some time he took it in his head that he would travel to Rome. On the way he passed by a marsh, in which a number of frogs were sitting croaking. He listened to them, and when he became aware of what they were saying, he grew very thoughtful and sad. At last he arrived in Rome, where the Pope had just died, and there was great doubt among the cardinals as to whom they should appoint as his successor. They at length agreed that the person should be chosen as pope who should be distinguished by some divine and miraculous token. And just as that was decided on, the young count entered into the church, and suddenly two snow-white doves flew on his shoulders and remained sitting there. The ecclesiastics recognized therein the token from above, and asked him on the spot if he would be pope. He was undecided, and knew not if he were worthy of this, but the doves counselled him to do it, and at length he said yes. Then was he anointed and consecrated, and thus was fulfilled what he had heard from the frogs on his way, which had so affected him, that he was to be his Holiness the Pope. Then he had to sing a mass, and did not know one word of it, but the two doves sat continually on his shoulders, and said it all in his ear.

events.title: The Cat's Humble Inquiry and the Fox's Arrogant Boast
detailed_summary: A cat encounters a fox in the forest, whom she regards as intelligent and highly respected.
She initiates a friendly conversation, inquiring about his well-being amidst challenging circumstances.
The fox, displaying considerable arrogance, scrutinizes the cat for a prolonged period before responding.
He condescendingly addresses the cat, questioning her audacity to inquire about him and belittling her knowledge and abilities.
The cat modestly states that she possesses only a single skill.
When the fox asks for details, the cat explains her sole art is the ability to escape pursuing hounds by climbing a tree.
The fox derides this singular skill, boasting that he is a master of a hundred arts and possesses a wealth of cunning tricks.
He expresses pity for the cat and offers to teach her how to evade hounds effectively.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It happened that the cat met the fox in a forest, and as she thought to herself: ‘He is clever and full of experience, and much esteemed in the world,’ she spoke to him in a friendly way.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: You make me sorry for you; come with me, I will teach you how people get away from the hounds.’

events.text_segment: It happened that the cat met the fox in a forest, and as she thought to herself: ‘He is clever and full of experience, and much esteemed in the world,’ she spoke to him in a friendly way. ‘Good day, dear Mr Fox, how are you? How is all with you? How are you getting on in these hard times?’ The fox, full of all kinds of arrogance, looked at the cat from head to foot, and for a long time did not know whether he would give any answer or not. At last he said: ‘Oh, you wretched beard-cleaner, you piebald fool, you hungry mouse-hunter, what can you be thinking of? Have you the cheek to ask how I am getting on? What have you learnt? How many arts do you understand?’ ‘I understand but one,’ replied the cat, modestly. ‘What art is that?’ asked the fox. ‘When the hounds are following me, I can spring into a tree and save myself.’ ‘Is that all?’ said the fox. ‘I am master of a hundred arts, and have into the bargain a sackful of cunning. You make me sorry for you; come with me, I will teach you how people get away from the hounds.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: It happened that the cat met the fox in a forest, and as she thought to herself: ‘He is clever and full of experience, and much esteemed in the world,’ she spoke to him in a friendly way. ‘How do you do, Mr Fox? What do you know about the world, you poor little creature?’ The cat replied modestly, ‘I have but one art, and that is to climb a tree to escape the hounds.’ The fox laughed scornfully. ‘Only one art! I have a hundred, and I am master of all. I pity you, little cat. Come, I will teach you how to escape the hounds.’

events.title: The Hunter's Arrival and the True Test of Cunning
detailed_summary: A hunter, accompanied by four dogs, suddenly appears on the scene.
The cat immediately utilizes her skill, deftly leaping up a tree and concealing herself among the highest branches and leaves.
From her safe vantage point, the cat calls out to the fox, urging him to deploy his proclaimed 'sackful of cunning'.
Despite the cat's taunt, the dogs quickly seize the fox, holding him firmly.
The cat then addresses the captured fox, highlighting the irony of his predicament.
She observes that his boasted hundred arts proved useless, and had he possessed her simple climbing ability, he would have avoided losing his life.

Had you been able to climb like me, you would not have lost your life.’

events.title: The Father's Directive and the Brothers' Departure
detailed_summary: A financially struggling father informed his four sons that he had no inheritance for them and they needed to go out into the world to find their own success.
He advised them to start by learning a trade or skill to see how they could advance.
The four brothers, equipped with walking sticks and small bundles, said goodbye to their father and left home together.
After traveling some distance, they arrived at a crossroads with four separate paths, each leading to a different country.
The eldest brother suggested they part ways there, with an agreement to reunite at that same spot in four years, after each had independently tried to make his way.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: ‘Dear children,’ said a poor man to his four sons, ‘I have nothing to give you; you must go out into the wide world and try your luck.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then the eldest said, ‘Here we must part; but this day four years we will come back to this spot, and in the meantime each must try what he can do for himself.’

events.text_segment: ‘Dear children,’ said a poor man to his four sons, ‘I have nothing to give you; you must go out into the wide world and try your luck. Begin by learning some craft or another, and see how you can get on.’ So the four brothers took their walking-sticks in their hands, and their little bundles on their shoulders, and after bidding their father goodbye, went all out at the gate together. When they had got on some way they came to four crossways, each leading to a different country. Then the eldest said, ‘Here we must part; but this day four years we will come back to this spot, and in the meantime each must try what he can do for himself.’

events.title: The Eldest Brother Learns Cunning Thievery
detailed_summary: As the eldest brother journeyed alone, he encountered a man who inquired about his destination and purpose.
The brother explained he was seeking his fortune and wished to learn a craft.
The man offered to teach him to become the most skilled thief ever.
The brother initially rejected the offer, deeming thievery a dishonest profession with a grim outcome (the gallows).
The man reassured him, explaining he would only teach him to steal items that were considered 'fair game'—things no one else could obtain or cared about, and where he wouldn't be caught.
Convinced by this, the young man accepted the apprenticeship and quickly became so adept that nothing he targeted could elude him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: So each brother went his way; and as the eldest was hastening on a man met him, and asked him where he was going, and what he wanted.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So the young man agreed to follow his trade, and he soon showed himself so clever, that nothing could escape him that he had once set his mind upon.

events.text_segment: So each brother went his way; and as the eldest was hastening on a man met him, and asked him where he was going, and what he wanted. ‘I am going to try my luck in the world, and should like to begin by learning some art or trade,’ answered he. ‘Then,’ said the man, ‘go with me, and I will teach you to become the cunningest thief that ever was.’ ‘No,’ said the other, ‘that is not an honest calling, and what can one look to earn by it in the end but the gallows?’ ‘Oh!’ said the man, ‘you need not fear the gallows; for I will only teach you to steal what will be fair game: I meddle with nothing but what no one else can get or care anything about, and where no one can find you out.’ So the young man agreed to follow his trade, and he soon showed himself so clever, that nothing could escape him that he had once set his mind upon.

events.title: The Second Brother Becomes a Star-Gazer
detailed_summary: The second brother also met a man who, upon learning of his quest, asked what trade he intended to pursue.
The brother admitted he hadn't decided yet.
The man proposed that the brother join him and become a star-gazer, describing it as a noble art enabling one to know all things by understanding the stars.
The brother was very pleased with this suggestion and became a highly skilled star-gazer.
When his apprenticeship ended and he was ready to depart, his master gifted him a special glass.
The master explained that with this glass, he could observe all events in the sky and on earth, ensuring nothing could remain hidden from him.

events.title: The Youngest Brother Learns Exceptional Tailoring
detailed_summary: The youngest brother also encountered a man who inquired about his aspirations.
The man suggested he become a tailor.
The young man initially refused, expressing distaste for the conventional image of a tailor spending long hours sitting cross-legged, laboriously working with a needle and goose.
The man clarified that his type of tailoring was entirely different and invited the brother to learn this unique craft.
Having no better options, the brother accepted the offer and learned tailoring thoroughly.
When he departed from his master, he was given a special needle, with the assurance that it could sew anything, whether as delicate as an egg or as tough as steel, leaving an imperceptible seam.

events.title: The Brothers' Reunion and Initial Skill Demonstrations
detailed_summary: Four years later, as agreed, the four brothers reconvened at the crossroads.
They greeted each other warmly and journeyed together to their father's home.
Upon arrival, they recounted their experiences and the unique crafts each had mastered.
One day, while sitting under a tall tree, their father expressed a desire to witness their skills.
He looked up and asked his second son, the star-gazer, to identify the number of eggs in a chaffinch's nest at the treetop.
The star-gazer used his glass, looked up, and confirmed there were five eggs.
The father then instructed his eldest son, the thief, to retrieve the eggs without alerting the bird sitting on them.
The thief skillfully climbed the tree and brought the five eggs to his father from under the unsuspecting bird, which remained undisturbed.
The father then placed one egg on each corner of a table and the fifth in the center, and directed the huntsman to slice all five eggs in two with a single shot.
The huntsman took his bow and, with one shot, accurately struck all five eggs as requested.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The huntsman took up his bow, and at one shot struck all the five eggs as his father wished.

events.text_segment:
After the space of four years, at the time agreed upon, the four brothers met at the four cross-roads; and having welcomed each other, set off towards their father’s home, where they told him all that had happened to them, and how each had learned some craft.
Then, one day, as they were sitting before the house under a very high tree, the father said, ‘I should like to try what each of you can do in this way.’ So he looked up, and said to the second son, ‘At the top of this tree there is a chaffinch’s nest; tell me how many eggs there are in it.’ The star-gazer took his glass, looked up, and said, ‘Five.’ ‘Now,’ said the father to the eldest son, ‘take away the eggs without letting the bird that is sitting upon them and hatching them know anything of what you are doing.’ So the cunning thief climbed up the tree, and brought away to his father the five eggs from under the bird; and it never saw or felt what he was doing, but kept sitting on at its ease. Then the father took the eggs, and put one on each corner of the table, and the fifth in the middle, and said to the huntsman, ‘Cut all the eggs in two pieces at one shot.’ The huntsman took up his bow, and at one shot struck all the five eggs as his father wished.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: After the space of four years, at the time agreed upon, the four brothers met at the four cross-roads; and having welcomed each other, set off towards their father’s home, where they told him all that had happened to them, and how each had learned some craft. One day, as they sat beneath a tall tree, their father looked up and said to his second son, the star-gazer, “Look yonder into the nest of the chaffinch that sits at the top of the tree, and tell me how many eggs are there.” The star-gazer took his glass, looked up, and said, “There are five eggs.” Then the father said to his eldest son, the thief, “Climb up and bring me those eggs without disturbing the bird that sits upon them.” The thief nimbly climbed the tree and brought down the five eggs, all the while the bird sat quietly upon them, undisturbed. The father then placed one egg on each corner of the table and the fifth in the center, and said to the huntsman, “Shoot and split all five eggs in two with a single arrow.” The huntsman took his bow, aimed carefully, and with one shot, split all five eggs in two as his father had commanded.

events.title: The Tailor's Mending Feat and Father's Commendation
detailed_summary: The father then turned to the young tailor, instructing him to sew the fragmented eggs and the young birds within them back together so perfectly that the shot would seem to have caused no harm.
The tailor took his special needle and meticulously sewed the eggs as directed.
Once the tailor had finished, the thief was tasked with returning the mended eggs to the nest, placing them back under the bird without its knowledge.
The mother bird continued to incubate the eggs, and after a few days, they hatched.
The young birds emerged with only a small red line across their necks, indicating where the tailor had sewn them.
The old man praised his sons, acknowledging they had used their time well and learned valuable skills.
He admitted he was unsure which of them deserved a prize and expressed a wish that an opportunity would soon arise for them to apply their talents meaningfully.

events.text_segment:
‘Now comes your turn,’ said he to the young tailor; ‘sew the eggs and the young birds in them together again, so neatly that the shot shall have done them no harm.’ Then the tailor took his needle, and sewed the eggs as he was told; and when he had done, the thief was sent to take them back to the nest, and put them under the bird without its knowing it. Then she went on sitting, and hatched them: and in a few days they crawled out, and had only a little red streak across their necks, where the tailor had sewn them together.
‘Well done, sons!’ said the old man; ‘you have made good use of your time, and learnt something worth the knowing; but I am sure I do not know which ought to have the prize. Oh, that a time might soon come for you to turn your skill to some account!’

events.title: The Quest to Rescue the Abducted Princess
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, the country was in turmoil because the king's daughter had been abducted by a formidable dragon.
The grieving king proclaimed that whoever rescued her would receive her hand in marriage.
The four brothers recognized this as a chance to use their skills and agreed to attempt to free the princess.
The star-gazer used his special glass and quickly located the princess, announcing he could see her on a distant rock in the sea, with the dragon guarding her nearby.
He approached the king and requested a ship for himself and his brothers.
They sailed across the sea until they reached the location.
There, they found the princess on the rock as the star-gazer had described, with the dragon asleep, its head resting in her lap.
The huntsman expressed concern that shooting the dragon might also harm the beautiful princess.
The thief then declared he would use his skill, and he stealthily stole the princess from under the sleeping dragon so quietly that the beast continued snoring, unaware.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Not long after this there was a great bustle in the country; for the king’s daughter had been carried off by a mighty dragon, and the king mourned over his loss day and night, and made it known that whoever brought her back to him should have her for a wife.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then I will try my skill,’ said the thief, and went and stole her away from under the dragon, so quietly and gently that the beast did not know it, but went on snoring.

events.text_segment: Not long after this there was a great bustle in the country; for the king’s daughter had been carried off by a mighty dragon, and the king mourned over his loss day and night, and made it known that whoever brought her back to him should have her for a wife. Then the four brothers said to each other, ‘Here is a chance for us; let us try what we can do.’ And they agreed to see whether they could not set the princess free. ‘I will soon find out where she is, however,’ said the star-gazer, as he looked through his glass; and he soon cried out, ‘I see her afar off, sitting upon a rock in the sea, and I can spy the dragon close by, guarding her.’ Then he went to the king, and asked for a ship for himself and his brothers; and they sailed together over the sea, till they came to the right place. There they found the princess sitting, as the star-gazer had said, on the rock; and the dragon was lying asleep, with his head upon her lap. ‘I dare not shoot at him,’ said the huntsman, ‘for I should kill the beautiful young lady also.’ ‘Then I will try my skill,’ said the thief, and went and stole her away from under the dragon, so quietly and gently that the beast did not know it, but went on snoring.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Not long after this there was a great bustle in the country; for the king’s daughter had been carried off by a mighty dragon, and the king mourned over his loss day and night, and made it known that whoever brought her back to him should have her for a wife.

The four brothers, who were all clever men, heard of this and said to one another, "Here is a chance for us to show our skill and courage. Let us try to rescue the princess and win her hand."

The eldest was a star-gazer; he took his special glass and looked far and wide, and soon he cried out, "I see the princess! She is on a rock in the middle of the sea, and the dragon is lying near her, guarding her closely."

He went to the king and asked for a ship to carry himself and his brothers to the place he had seen.

They set sail and after a long voyage reached the rock. There, just as the star-gazer had said, sat the princess, and the dragon lay asleep with its head resting in her lap.

The huntsman said, "If I shoot the dragon, I fear I may harm the princess as well."

Then the thief smiled and said, "Leave it to me." He crept silently to the dragon and, with great skill, stole the princess away without waking the beast, which continued to snore peacefully.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
Not long after this there was a great bustle in the country; for the king’s daughter had been carried off by a mighty dragon, and the king mourned over his loss day and night, and made it known that whoever brought her back to him should have her for a wife.

The four brothers said to one another, "Here is a chance for us to try our skill; let us go and see if we can set the princess free."

The star-gazer said, "I will look through my glass and see if I can find where she is."

He took his glass and looked far and wide, and soon he cried, "I see the princess! She is on a rock in the sea, and the dragon is lying near her, guarding her closely."

He went to the king and asked for a ship for himself and his brothers.

They sailed over the sea until they came to the rock, and there they found the princess just as the star-gazer had said, and the dragon was lying asleep with its head in her lap.

The huntsman said, "If I shoot the dragon, I may kill the princess too."

Then the thief said, "I will try," and he crept softly and gently and stole the princess away from under the dragon’s head, so quietly that the dragon went on snoring and never woke.

When he arrived, he found the dragon asleep, its great body coiled around the princess, who was unharmed but frightened. events.title: Dragon's Pursuit, Defeat, and Miraculous Escape
detailed_summary: Filled with joy, they quickly carried the princess to their boat, intending to reach their ship.
However, the dragon soon awoke, discovered the princess was missing, and pursued them, roaring through the air.
As the dragon positioned itself above their boat, preparing to seize the princess, the huntsman aimed his bow and shot it directly through the heart, killing it instantly.
Despite their success, they faced new danger as the enormous beast, in its fall, capsized their boat, leaving them to swim in the open sea amidst a few planks.
The tailor then took his needle and, with a few large stitches, quickly joined some of the planks together to form a raft.
Sitting on this makeshift raft, he sailed around, gathered all the scattered pieces of the boat, and expertly tacked them together, swiftly repairing it.
They were then able to reach their ship and return home safely.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then away they hastened with her full of joy in their boat towards the ship; but soon came the dragon roaring behind them through the air; for he awoke and missed the princess.

events.text_segment: Then away they hastened with her full of joy in their boat towards the ship; but soon came the dragon roaring behind them through the air; for he awoke and missed the princess. But when he got over the boat, and wanted to pounce upon them and carry off the princess, the huntsman took up his bow and shot him straight through the heart so that he fell down dead. They were still not safe; for he was such a great beast that in his fall he overset the boat, and they had to swim in the open sea upon a few planks. So the tailor took his needle, and with a few large stitches put some of the planks together; and he sat down upon these, and sailed about and gathered up all pieces of the boat; and then tacked them together so quickly that the boat was soon ready, and they then reached the ship and got home safe.

events.title: The Princess's Rescue, a Royal Dispute, and a Generous Reward
detailed_summary: Upon bringing the princess back to her father, there was widespread rejoicing.
The king announced to the four brothers that one of them would marry her, but they needed to decide amongst themselves who it would be.
This led to a quarrel among the brothers, each arguing their contribution was most vital.
The star-gazer contended that without him finding the princess, their skills would have been useless, so she should be his.
The thief countered that merely seeing her was insufficient if he hadn't stolen her from the dragon, claiming her for himself.
The huntsman asserted she was his because if he hadn't killed the dragon, it would have destroyed them all.
The tailor argued that if he hadn't repaired the boat, they all would have drowned, making her his by right.
The king intervened, acknowledging the validity of each claim.
He reasoned that since all four could not marry the princess, and because she was actually fond of someone else, it was best if none of them married her.
To compensate for their efforts and loss, he offered to give each of them half a kingdom as a reward for their skill.
The brothers agreed this resolution was preferable to continued quarreling or marrying an unwilling bride.
The king fulfilled his promise, granting each half a kingdom, and they lived contentedly, also taking care of their father, while the princess was ensured to be safe from future harm.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When they had brought home the princess to her father, there was great rejoicing; and he said to the four brothers, ‘One of you shall marry her, but you must settle amongst yourselves which it is to be.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: And the king then gave to each half a kingdom, as he had said; and they lived very happily the rest of their days, and took good care of their father; and somebody took better care of the young lady, than to let either the dragon or one of the craftsmen have her again.

events.text_segment: When they had brought home the princess to her father, there was great rejoicing; and he said to the four brothers, ‘One of you shall marry her, but you must settle amongst yourselves which it is to be.’ Then there arose a quarrel between them; and the star-gazer said, ‘If I had not found the princess out, all your skill would have been of no use; therefore she ought to be mine.’ ‘Your seeing her would have been of no use,’ said the thief, ‘if I had not taken her away from the dragon; therefore she ought to be mine.’ ‘No, she is mine,’ said the huntsman; ‘for if I had not killed the dragon, he would, after all, have torn you and the princess into pieces.’ ‘And if I had not sewn the boat together again,’ said the tailor, ‘you would all have been drowned, therefore she is mine.’ Then the king put in a word, and said, ‘Each of you is right; and as all cannot have the young lady, the best way is for neither of you to have her: for the truth is, there is somebody she likes a great deal better. But to make up for your loss, I will give each of you, as a reward for his skill, half a kingdom.’ So the brothers agreed that this plan would be much better than either quarrelling or marrying a lady who had no mind to have them. And the king then gave to each half a kingdom, as he had said; and they lived very happily the rest of their days, and took good care of their father; and somebody took better care of the young lady, than to let either the dragon or one of the craftsmen have her again.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The four brothers sat down together to consider the matter. Each was brave and noble, and each wished to win the hand of the princess. They decided to seek the advice of their mother, who was wise and kind. She told them, "The one who can prove his worth by performing a great deed shall be the husband of the princess." 

Encouraged by their mother's words, the brothers set out to accomplish something extraordinary. The eldest went to the forest to hunt the fiercest beast; the second sought to build a magnificent castle; the third aimed to find a treasure hidden deep beneath the earth; and the youngest, though the least experienced, wished to bring peace to the troubled kingdom.

Days passed, and each returned with tales of their endeavors. The eldest had slain a terrible dragon; the second had constructed a splendid fortress; the third had uncovered a chest filled with gold and jewels. But it was the youngest who told of how he had spoken with the people, listened to their woes, and helped to resolve their disputes, bringing harmony to the land.

The king listened to their stories and pondered. He saw that while strength, wealth, and grandeur were admirable, it was the youngest son's compassion and wisdom that truly benefited the kingdom. Thus, he declared, "The youngest shall marry the princess, for he has shown the greatest worth."

The brothers rejoiced, and the wedding was celebrated with great festivity. The youngest son and the princess ruled wisely and justly, bringing happiness to all their subjects.

events.title: The Merchant's Promise and the Quest for a Rose
detailed_summary: A merchant, preparing for a journey, inquired about his three daughters' desires for gifts.
The eldest daughter wished for pearls, and the second daughter asked for jewels.
The youngest daughter, named Lily, requested her father bring her a rose.
The father acknowledged the challenge of finding a rose during winter but committed to trying for Lily, whom he described as his prettiest daughter and a lover of flowers.
After successfully acquiring pearls and jewels for his two eldest daughters, the merchant searched extensively but in vain for a rose.
His attempts to find a rose in gardens during winter were met with mockery, with people questioning if he expected roses to grow in snow.
This situation greatly distressed him, as Lily was his most cherished child.
While journeying home, contemplating what gift to bring Lily, he arrived at an impressive castle.
Surrounding the castle was a unique garden, with one section appearing to be in full summer bloom while the other was stark and snow-covered.
He considered this a fortunate discovery and instructed his servant to approach a beautiful rose bed within the garden and retrieve one of the finest flowers.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A merchant, who had three daughters, was once setting out upon a journey; but before he went he asked each daughter what gift he should bring back for her.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘A lucky hit!’ said he, as he called to his servant, and told him to go to a beautiful bed of roses that was there, and bring him away one of the finest flowers.

events.text_segment:
A merchant, who had three daughters, was once setting out upon a journey; but before he went he asked each daughter what gift he should bring back for her. The eldest wished for pearls; the second for jewels; but the third, who was called Lily, said, ‘Dear father, bring me a rose.’ Now it was no easy task to find a rose, for it was the middle of winter; yet as she was his prettiest daughter, and was very fond of flowers, her father said he would try what he could do. So he kissed all three, and bid them goodbye.
And when the time came for him to go home, he had bought pearls and jewels for the two eldest, but he had sought everywhere in vain for the rose; and when he went into any garden and asked for such a thing, the people laughed at him, and asked him whether he thought roses grew in snow. This grieved him very much, for Lily was his dearest child; and as he was journeying home, thinking what he should bring her, he came to a fine castle; and around the castle was a garden, in one half of which it seemed to be summer-time and in the other half winter. On one side the finest flowers were in full bloom, and on the other everything looked dreary and buried in the snow. ‘A lucky hit!’ said he, as he called to his servant, and told him to go to a beautiful bed of roses that was there, and bring him away one of the finest flowers.

That will be hard to find, but I will try, for you are my prettiest daughter and love flowers." He brought pearls for the eldest and jewels for the second, but when he sought a rose he could find none. The merchant promised to fulfill their wishes and set off on his journey. After many days, he returned with the gifts for his daughters. Grateful, the prince asked for her hand in marriage, and they soon wed.

Thus, the tale teaches that true happiness comes not from riches or finery, but from a pure heart and gentle spirit.

events.title: The Lion's Bargain and Lily's Selfless Decision
detailed_summary: Upon securing the rose and attempting to leave, the merchant and his servant were suddenly confronted by a fierce lion.
The lion roared angrily, proclaiming that whoever had stolen his roses would be eaten alive.
The merchant pleaded for his life, stating he was unaware the garden belonged to the lion.

The lion declared that nothing could save the merchant's life unless he promised to give the lion whatever first greeted him upon his return home; agreeing to this would grant him his life and the rose for his daughter.
The merchant was hesitant, expressing his fear that it might be his youngest daughter, Lily, who loved him dearly and always ran to meet him.
The servant, greatly alarmed, suggested that perhaps only a cat or a dog would meet him first.
Ultimately, with a troubled conscience, the merchant relented, accepted the rose, and agreed to surrender to the lion whatever first met him on his return.
As he approached his home, his youngest and dearest daughter, Lily, was the first to meet him, running to kiss and welcome him, and her joy increased upon seeing the rose.
However, her father became deeply sorrowful and wept, explaining that he had acquired the flower at a steep price, having promised her to a wild lion who would tear her apart and consume her.
He recounted all that had transpired and insisted that she should not go, regardless of the consequences.
Lily, however, comforted her father, asserting that his given word must be honored.
She declared her intention to go to the lion and attempt to pacify him, hoping he might allow her to return home safely.
The following morning, she inquired about the route she needed to take, bid her father farewell, and set out courageously into the woods.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: This done, they were riding away well pleased, when up sprang a fierce lion, and roared out, ‘Whoever has stolen my roses shall be eaten up alive!’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The next morning she asked the way she was to go, and took leave of her father, and went forth with a bold heart into the wood.

events.text_segment:
This done, they were riding away well pleased, when up sprang a fierce lion, and roared out, ‘Whoever has stolen my roses shall be eaten up alive!’ Then the man said, ‘I knew not that the garden belonged to you; can nothing save my life?’ ‘No!’ said the lion, ‘nothing, unless you undertake to give me whatever meets you on your return home; if you agree to this, I will give you your life, and the rose too for your daughter.’ But the man was unwilling to do so and said, ‘It may be my youngest daughter, who loves me most, and always runs to meet me when I go home.’ Then the servant was greatly frightened, and said, ‘It may perhaps be only a cat or a dog.’ And at last the man yielded with a heavy heart, and took the rose; and said he would give the lion whatever should meet him first on his return.
And as he came near home, it was Lily, his youngest and dearest daughter, that met him; she came running, and kissed him, and welcomed him home; and when she saw that he had brought her the rose, she was still more glad. But her father began to be very sorrowful, and to weep, saying, ‘Alas, my dearest child! I have bought this flower at a high price, for I have said I would give you to a wild lion; and when he has you, he will tear you in pieces, and eat you.’ Then he told her all that had happened, and said she should not go, let what would happen.
But she comforted him, and said, ‘Dear father, the word you have given must be kept; I will go to the lion, and soothe him: perhaps he will let me come safe home again.’
The next morning she asked the way she was to go, and took leave of her father, and went forth with a bold heart into the wood.

events.title: Marriage to the Enchanted Prince and a Joyful Family Reunion
detailed_summary: It was revealed that the lion was, in fact, an enchanted prince.
By day, he and his entire court were transformed into lions, but in the evening, they regained their human forms.
When Lily arrived at the castle, the prince received her with such politeness and charm that she agreed to marry him.
A wedding feast was held, and they coexisted happily for a significant period.

The prince was only visible in his human state once evening arrived, at which time he would conduct his court; however, every morning, he would leave his bride and depart alone, his destination unknown to her until nightfall.
After some time had passed, he informed Lily that a grand feast was scheduled at her father's house the next day for her eldest sister's wedding.
He offered that if she wished to attend and visit her sister, his lions would escort her there.
Lily was greatly cheered by the thought of seeing her father again.
Upon her arrival, everyone was overjoyed to see her, as they had long believed her to be deceased.
She reassured them of her current happiness, stayed until the feast concluded, and then returned to the woods.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But the lion was an enchanted prince.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But she told them how happy she was, and stayed till the feast was over, and then went back to the wood.

events.text_segment:
But the lion was an enchanted prince. By day he and all his court were lions, but in the evening they took their right forms again. And when Lily came to the castle, he welcomed her so courteously that she agreed to marry him. The wedding-feast was held, and they lived happily together a long time. The prince was only to be seen as soon as evening came, and then he held his court; but every morning he left his bride, and went away by himself, she knew not whither, till the night came again.
After some time he said to her, ‘Tomorrow there will be a great feast in your father’s house, for your eldest sister is to be married; and if you wish to go and visit her my lions shall lead you thither.’ Then she rejoiced much at the thoughts of seeing her father once more, and set out with the lions; and everyone was overjoyed to see her, for they had thought her dead long since. But she told them how happy she was, and stayed till the feast was over, and then went back to the wood.

events.title: A Forbidden Wish and the Prince's Transformation into a Dove
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, Lily's second sister was to be married, and Lily received an invitation to the wedding.
This time, she insisted to the prince that she would not go alone and that he must accompany her.
The prince was unwilling, warning her that such an action would be extremely perilous.

He explained that if even the slightest gleam from a torchlight were to fall upon him, his enchantment would intensify, causing him to transform into a dove and compelling him to wander the world for seven long years.
Despite his warnings, Lily persisted, giving him no peace and assuring him she would exercise caution to prevent any light from reaching him.
Eventually, they set out together, taking their young child with them.
For his protection, she selected a large hall with substantial, thick walls for him to remain in while the wedding torches were lit.
Regrettably, no one noticed a small crack present in the door of the hall.

The wedding ceremony was conducted with great splendor. However, as the procession returned from the church, passing by the hall with their torches, a very small ray of light fell upon the prince through the crack.
In an instant, he disappeared. When his wife entered the hall and searched for him, she found only a white dove.

The dove communicated to her that he was condemned to fly across the face of the earth for seven years, but he would intermittently release a white feather to indicate his path, enabling her to follow him with the hope of eventually overtaking him and securing his freedom.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Her second sister was soon after married, and when Lily was asked to go to the wedding, she said to the prince, ‘I will not go alone this time—you must go with me.’
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: ‘Seven years must I fly up and down over the face of the earth, but every now and then I will let fall a white feather, that will show you the way I am going; follow it, and at last you may overtake and set me free.’

events.text_segment: Her second sister was soon after married, and when Lily was asked to go to the wedding, she said to the prince, ‘I will not go alone this time—you must go with me.’ But he would not, and said that it would be a very hazardous thing; for if the least ray of the torch-light should fall upon him his enchantment would become still worse, for he should be changed into a dove, and be forced to wander about the world for seven long years. However, she gave him no rest, and said she would take care no light should fall upon him. So at last they set out together, and took with them their little child; and she chose a large hall with thick walls for him to sit in while the wedding-torches were lighted; but, unluckily, no one saw that there was a crack in the door. Then the wedding was held with great pomp, but as the train came from the church, and passed with the torches before the hall, a very small ray of light fell upon the prince. In a moment he disappeared, and when his wife came in and looked for him, she found only a white dove; and it said to her, ‘Seven years must I fly up and down over the face of the earth, but every now and then I will let fall a white feather, that will show you the way I am going; follow it, and at last you may overtake and set me free.’

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Her second sister was soon after married, and when Lily was asked to go to the wedding, she said to the prince, ‘I will not go alone this time—you must go with me.’ The prince was unwilling, and warned her that it would be very dangerous. He told her that if even the smallest gleam of torchlight were to fall upon him, his enchantment would grow stronger, and he would be transformed into a dove, condemned to wander the world for seven years. But Lily would not be dissuaded; she pressed him so much that he finally consented, on the condition that she would be very careful to keep all light away from him. They set out together, taking their little child with them. For his safety, Lily chose a large hall with thick walls for the prince to stay in while the wedding torches were lit. Unfortunately, no one noticed a tiny crack in the door. The wedding was celebrated with great splendor, and as the procession returned from the church, passing by the hall with their torches, a small ray of light slipped through the crack and fell upon the prince. In an instant, he vanished. When Lily entered the hall to find him, she found only a white dove. The dove told her that he was doomed to fly across the face of the earth for seven years, but that he would drop white feathers along the way to mark his path, so that she might follow him and, if she could overtake him, set him free.
